column2: 一: one, one radical (no. 1)
column4: One down, 2041 to go. ;).
column5: To learn this one kanji, I recommend (#2000) this story : Bambi is in a cave, eating a side-dish of salad when trying to learn the kanjis. As he succeed to learn the kanji for "one", you get jealous and decide to shoot him with a slingshot. At this moment you hear the police coming, so you hurriedly burn all the proofs into a fire (so you remove the key-words Bambi, slingshot and fire from recommend). So that when the police arrives, the only remaining clue is a single horizontal bar.

column2: 二: two, two radical (no. 7)
column4: Two lines.
column5: Roman numeral II, written on its side.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
一: one; one radical (no.1)
一: one; one radical (no.1)
column4: One + two = three.
column5: THREE measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.

column2:
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: FOUR year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.
column5: I imagine a giant devouring a human in four bites. First the giant bites off the person´s head, then he bites the torso, then from the waist to the knees, and finally the giant plucks up the remaining portion of the human legs into his mouth. See the fourth bite falling in there?

column2: 二: two; two radical (no.2)
column4: 三 + two vertical lines = 5.
column5: This Kanji looks like a "3" Kanji with two added vertical lines. 3+2= 5.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.
column5: Six-Six-SIX ((666)) Mark of the Beast!! Imagine that dapper old beastly fellow summoning his top hat to himself. See it scamper over to him on a little pair of beastly legs.

column2:

column5: I wrote it upside down so I crossed it out.

column2: 八: eight, eight radical (no. 12)
column4: Hachi (eight) begins with the sound of the katakana "ha", and it´s approximately the same character.
column5: The valcano hasn´t erupted for 8 years.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
乙: the latter; duplicate; strange; witty; fishhook radical (no. 5)
column4: Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1　一 with the kanji of 8 八added. So think of it as 　一＋八＝九.
column5: Warning - naughty reminder A woman in the doggie style position, waiting for my NINE inches.

column2: 十: ten, ten radical (no. 24)

column5: I scared away ten vampires with a single cross!

column5: That dirty ceiling was painted WHITE a hundred times!

column4: It takes many drops of ten to get to a thousand.
column5: One T = one thousand.

column2:

卜: divination
column4: Roots are below the ground.
column5: A magic wand hanging below the ceiling.

column2: 工: craft; construction; katakana e radical (no. 48)
column4: The LEFT side of my brain posesses the faculties needed for logical crafts, like engineering.
column5: The left side of my brain, is for crafts.

column2: 口: mouth
column4: The right hand is for putting food in your mouth. (The other hand is for ass-wiping!).
column5: Always keep your right to free speech (mouth) by your side!

column2:
口: mouth
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: Pocky goes in the mouth.
column5: My GF lets me come in her mouth (pictogram).

column2: 大: big, big radical (no. 37)
column4: A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.
column5: Think of a large St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.

column2: 小: small, insignificant, small radical (no. 42)
column4: A little penguin with its wings at its side.
column5: A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he´s too little to ride the roller coaster.

column2: 月: moon, month, moon radical (no. 74)
column4: A month is longer than a day.
column5: Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air "mooning" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of month, considering that months were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to Hesig´s seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).

column2: 日: sun, day, sun radical (no. 72)
column4: Open the window, new day.
column5: Picture two halves of a 24-hr period: Day & Night.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
干: dry; parch
column4: A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year.
column5: A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308).

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
十: ten
column4: The sun up is early, well before ten.
column5: An early sun-flower looks like a miniature sun perched on a needlelike stems.

column2: 木: tree, tree radical (no. 75)
column4: If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.
column5: Pictograph of a tree.

column2:
木: tree; wood
木: tree; wood
column4: A grove has at least two TREEs.
column5: Two tree huggers saying that protecting the environment is grovey man...

column2: 山: mountain, mountain radical (no. 46)
column4: Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a mountain often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the mountain (see FRAME 775 for an example).
column5: YOU CAN´T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!

column2: 巛: river, river radical (no. 47)
column4: So as not to confuse this with river (#146) think of streamers falling down.
column5: There are three default I/O Streams in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.

column2: 土: earth, earth radical (no. 32)
column4: Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.
column5: King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.

column2:
穴: hole; aperture; slit; cave; den
工: craft; construction; katakana e radical (no. 48)
column4: The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things.
column5: Hole-craft is the way of making empty spaces, like the sky.

column2: 田: field, field radical (no. 102)
column4: A rice field divided into four parts.
column5: Ten people use their mouths to eat the yield of the rice fields.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
大: large; big
column4: If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.
column5: The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven.

column2: 生: life, life radical (no. 100)
column4: This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.
column5: Growing Up is just a Drop of our LIFE.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
化: change; take the form of; influence; enchant; delude; -ization
column4: The flowers change with the seasons.
column5: The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
早: early; fast
column4: Grass grows in earlier than flowers.
column5: This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.

column2: 中: in; inside; middle; mean; center
column4: I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood.
column5: Insect in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.

column2:
大: large; big
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: A large dog, dripping drool.
column5: If we remember large (#107) as a man with his arms outstretched, the drop represents man´s best friend - a dog.

column2: 人: human, human radical (no. 9)
column4: Behold Mister T (of "A-Team" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he´s sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he´s both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.
column5: [I appreciate some people´s occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].

column2:
夕: evening
口: mouth
column4: In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.
column5: In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my name.

column2: 女: woman, female, female radical (no. 38)
column4: To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a "kunoichi". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一(kanji, ichi=one).
column5: My mother taught me that a woman should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
column4: Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character.
column5: When it comes to choosing a MAN, I prefer brains over muscles.

column2: 子: child, seed, child radical (no. 39)
column4: A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).
column5: A pictograph of a child, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).

column2: 目: eye, eye radical (no. 109)
column4: There are 3 sections. Imagine the outer two being the whites of your eye. The middle is the pupil. Fill it in with imaginary color.
column5: 目_目.

column2: 耳: ear, ear radical (no. 128)
column4: Your ear is like the eye on the side of your head for seeing things, but there is hair around it that creates jagged lines.
column5: Pictograph, see book. * The primitive meaning can easily be extended to ear plugs.

column2: 口: mouth, opening, mouth radical (no. 30)
column4: Looks like a huge open mouth.
column5: Momma used to say: "Keep your trap shut!" This thing is shaped like a trap door.

column2: 手: hand, hand radical (no. 64)
column4: This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a hand with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.
column5: A hand is useful for 千一(1001) things.

column2: 口: mouth
column4: Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale´s mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.
column5: I´ll use my mouth to mend your leg, I´ll kiss it all better :).

column2: 目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant eyeball with legs...) Makes for easy stories later on.
column5: Eyes and legs are all you need to see the world.

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you´d be making sound.
column5: The tongue wagging in a mouth produces a very high-pitched sound, breaking a nearby vase.

column2: 力: power, force, katakana ka radical (no. 19)
column4: I always refer to the power of the KATAKANA "KA".
column5: I have a very powerful muscle カ in my driveway!

column2:
气: spirit; steam radical (no. 84)
乂: mow; cut grass; subdue
column4: You´re reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you´ve been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.
column5: Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.

column2: 冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
column4: The shape of a Yen coin.
column5: A poor old man is almost killing himself trying to lift a huge glass hood with his cane (using it as a lever), to get to just one yen coin. Note : the kanji refers to a circular, round object, but also to the Japanese currency (pronounced "en").

column2: 入: enter, enter radical (no. 11)
column4: Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.
column5: Person enters stage left…

column2:
山: mountain
凵: open box enclosure; open box radical (no. 17)
column4: Suddenly, a cactus comes out of the ground with a sign that reads: exit. Now you can leave the desert! (Note: giving this primitive the meaning ´cactus´ can be useful later).
column5: The exit lays between these two mountains.

column2: 亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
column4: A vase that can´t stand up won´t be a vase for long.
column5: He was a stand up guy: he´d lend you the top hat he wears everyday if you asked, and he will turn everything upside down to help you find your tools.

column2:
人: person
木: tree; wood
column4: Mr T resting by a tree.
column5: Chuck norris rests againsts the tree, but wait, no... the tree rests and stands against him.

column2: 八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)

column5: Nasty story but it keeps the meaning true to the kanji. "BEFORE you stick it in a COW and SPREAD the legs (the bottom stroke of this cow looks like two legs) make sure she has HUMAN LEGS"-------------sorry, I´ll remove if I get enough reports, but will keep if I get more stars.

column2: 夕: evening,  katakana ta radical (no. 36)
column4: The evening is young, the moon is not full.
column5: In the evening, I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for "TA" (ie. "ta ta!").

column2: 木: tree; wood

column5: An axe cutting a tree to make books.

column4: A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.
column5: The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect sentences.

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
子: child; sign of the rat; 11PM-1AM; first sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.
column5: Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father? "Shut up! It builds character!".

column2:
小: small, insignificant
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
子: child; sign of the rat; 11PM-1AM; first sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字).
column5: Children in schoolhouses are there to study, nothing else!!!

column2:
木: tree; wood
交: mingle; mixing; association; coming & going
column4: With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試.
column5: Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).

column2:
木: tree; wood
寸: measurement; foot/10
column4: If you´ve ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you´ll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn´t escape the important scripted scenes.).
column5: Pfft. At it´s core, a town is just a bunch of wood glued together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
丁: street; ward; town; counter for guns, tools, leaves or cakes of something; even number; 4th calendar sign
column4: Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.
column5: Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. "Pillage the village, for the rice and and the tea." the street primitive on the right looks like a ´t´.

column2:
木: tree; wood
林: grove; forest
column4: The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that´s so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.
column5: Another tree planted within a grove turns it into a FOREST.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
止: stop; halt
column4: If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.
column5: The correct way of learning Japanese? First, stop everything you´re doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig´s book and work from there.

column2: 水: water, water radical (no. 85)
column4: The kanji for water is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes; constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig´s story doesn´t do this).
column5: For those having issues with this* "A 7K foot pool of water" Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.

column2: 火: fire, fire radical (no. 86)
column4: For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!
column5: A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.

column2:
玉: jewel; ball
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...
column5: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the "drop").

column2: 玉: jewel; ball
column4: To be king you have to be a real crafty one !
column5: The king unites heaven and earth. (imagine heaven being the top line over the soil).

column2: 口: mouth
column4: Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!
column5: There´s a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the cliff thing isn´t working for you... Just see it as a stone [いし] being hammered by a miner searching for jewel stones [ほうせき] ;).

column2: 竹: bamboo, bamboo radical (no. 118)
column4: Pandas like to eat bamboo. I´m using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^.
column5: Two reclining victims impaled on bamboo spheres...

column2: 糸: thread, string, thread radical (no. 120)
column4: I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I´ve opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as dainty (#1363) and accumulate (#1364).
column5: You´ll be seeing this one a lot. Seriously.

column2: 目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!
column5: Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.

column2: 車: cart, car, car radical (no. 159)
column4: My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.
column5: Rather than hobbling along with a walking stick to cross through a span, it´s much better to use a car. (Imagine an old man with a walking stick creeping along a span of road, and you, in a car, whizzing right by him. It´s funny ´cause it´s true.) Also, it´s important to include the word "through," so you know the walking stick goes right THROUGH the span.

column2: 金: metal, gold,  gold radical (no. 167)
column4: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn´t fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.
column5: Under the umbrella´s shade, the king sang, " Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!".

column2: 雨: rain, rain radical (no. 173)
column4: From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.
column5: Towel hung out on a line to ....oops, it´s rain.

column2: 土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground.
column5: There was red all over the soil after Little Red Riding Hood plunged a dagger into the wolf. Those two dots we see are wolfies animal legs we see, by the way (a la smithsonian).

column2: 月: month; moon
column4: The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.
column5: Once in a blue moon refers to a rare event. But originally "blue moon" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we´re talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.

column2: 日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: A white ray is a drop of sun.
column5: Even a small drop (´) of the sun (日) would make you see nothing but white.

column2:
米: rice; USA; metre
女: woman; female
攵: strike; hit; folding chair radical variant (no. 66)
column4: Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. "One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!".
column5: Women toil in the rice fields carrying heavy sacks of rice to be numbered and counted by the taskmaster.

column2:
夕: evening
夕: evening
column4: Two evenings too many!
column5: This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: "He who eats many prunes sits on toilet many moons".

column2:
小: little; small
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
column4: Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.
column5: Few usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.

column2: 一: one; one radical (no.1)
column4: I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor.
column5: We have "one" at the top and if you turn the kanji 90 degrees you will see arabic 4 shich means it has four zeros in front of it!

column2:
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
二: two; two radical (no.2)
十: ten
column4: Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.
column5: I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go.

column2:
幵: put together
彡: three; hair ornament; short hair or fur radical (no. 59)
column4: Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting shapes made out of Play-Doh, except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you really need both hands.
column5: With your two hands, outline the shape of a curvaceous woman. Is that a universally understood gesture? [Careful: mould (#680) which has two hands and soil/clay].

column2:
大: large; big
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: A large person with a big drop of sweat dripping off of him because he is so plump.
column5: Fat("plump") men always have small penises.....the kanji is a combination of "large" with a drop(representing the small penis between his legs).

column2:
糸: thread
田: rice field; rice paddy
column4: Dainty women would always rather work with thread than in a field.
column5: Spider-Man used to just be a dainty, brainy nerd.

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
厶: I; myself; katakana mu radical (no. 28)
column4: The Batcave is very wide and has a lot of elbow room for Batman to do his yoga.
column5: A wide cave has a lot of "elbow room".

column2: 長: long, grow, leader radical (no. 168)
column4: The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.
column5: The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here´s my story: The girl´s hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.

column2:
占: fortune-telling; divining; forecasting; occupy; hold; have; get; take
火: fire
column4: The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.
column5: You have to stimulate the G-spot with your magic wand in order to get her on fire. Or you can juste use your mouth...

column2:
九: nine
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: Nine plus a drop rounds it off to ten!
column5: Watch out for plump (#120). Here Heisig could have added a "t" and we would have had a much better keyword : rotund. Rotund is more specific than "round" which begs for confusion with circle (#1811). A dictionary search on "fat" or "round" doesn´t yield this kanji, but "rotund" does! Primitive suggestion: the Laughing Buddha is often depicted as a rotund, smiling bald man in robes with a largely exposed pot belly stomach (symbolizing plenitude).

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
父: father
column4: Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can´t give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.
column5: Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2).

column2:
小: little; small
兀: high & level; lofty; bald; dangerous
column4: A ray of light is not a wave but made of little photons with human legs.
column5: The ray from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people little - ha! look at them run around on their tiny legs!

column2: 勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
column4: A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an angle.
column5: The gates have been bound up together leaving no angle to get through...

column2:
言: say
十: ten
column4: A plot is a summary of a book that can be given in ten words.
column5: Say-ten´s (satan´s) evil plot.

column2:
十: ten
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital straightaway.
column5: I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back straightaway.

column2:
糸: thread
泉: spring; fountain
column4: This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen.
column5: Japan´s train lines are like threads that spring from Tokyo station.

column2: 天: heavens; sky; imperial
column4: Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.
column5: Do not mistake with LOSE 失.

column2:
弓: bow; bow (archery, violin)
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)
弓: bow; bow (archery, violin)
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)
column4: Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it´s wintertime and their bows are coated in ice.
column5: BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.

column2:
弓: bow; bow (archery, violin)
厶: I; myself; katakana mu radical (no. 28)
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.
column5: Legolas is so strong that he can even shoot down vast numbers of tiny insects at vast distances with ease.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
口: mouth
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
口: mouth
column4: Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.
column5: Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).

column2:
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
一: one; one radical (no.1)
口: mouth
column4: Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else.
column5: Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
木: tree; wood
見: see; hopes; chances; idea; opinion; look at; visible
column4: A wise parent lets their kids learn. A kid wants to try to eat the red pepper plant, the wise parent says "Try it and see for yourself".
column5: I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a parent standing on top of a tree watching what his or her kid is doing.

column2: 毋: do not; must not; be not; mother radical (no. 80)
column4: The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.
column5: This mama had twins, one mouth for each nipple.

column2: 父: father, father radical (no. 88)
column4: Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).
column5: Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.

column2:
女: woman; female
市: market; city; town
column4: Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!
column5: She´s old enough to be allowed to go to the market.

column2:
口: mouth
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: My elder brother was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.
column5: Mother, why is elder brother´s mouth between the neighbor girl´s legs?

column2:
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
弔: condolences; mourning; funeral
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
column4: Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.
column5: The younger brother was a horny dollar -chasing bastard.

column2:
女: woman; female
未: un-; not yet; hitherto; still; even now; sign of the ram; 1-3PM; eighth sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.
column5: Is your younger sister a woman? Not yet! Damn!

column2: 目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: Faced with his clone, our hero valiantly cut a mark on his forehead right above his eye so that his comrades could tell his true oneself from the enemy.
column5: To use an eyedropper by oneself, aim from above to put a drop into the eye.

column2: 又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: A good friend is always at your side. ---- I teach at a Japanese High School, and I often see chummy male students grabbing each other´s crotches in a joking manner. It´s still weird to me, but apparently reaching to your side and grabbing you neighbor´s crotch is a great way to express friendship.
column5: Think of a sex friend (a fuck buddy if you will). The benefit of such a relationship is that there will always be a crotch by your side. (the Japanese refer to such a friend as セフレ, just as we do).

column2:
人: person
本: book; present; main; origin; true; real; counter for long cylindrical things
column4: Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps).
column5: Mr. T works out his body then rips a book apart to test is body. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.

column2: 毛: fur, hair, fur radical (no. 82)
column4: I´ve heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That´s not hair, that´s fur!
column5: Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don´t like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.

column2:
豆: beans; pea; midget
頁: page; leaf
column4: The head of the family sits at the head of the table.
column5: Mr Bean´s head.

column2:
彦: lad; boy (ancient)
頁: page; leaf
column4: A lad's head still has a baby's face.
column5: When I was a lad, a pretty face was all it took for someone to get in my head, and I´d fill pages of lovelorn letters to them.

column2: 自: oneself
column4: The V shape is your neck on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. Yourself, or the rest of your body is below that!
column5: The mooses neck supports it´s big horns and long nose.

column2: 心: heart, heart radical (no. 61)
column4: The four chambers in the heart. In the West, we point to our head when asked about the mind. In the East, they point to the heart. So then, the radical for "state of mind"…
column5: Heart needs three drops of blood to work.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
寺: Buddhist temple
column4: When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it´s time to get up.
column5: In ancient Japan, TIME of ´´day´´ was announced at the ´´buddhist temples´´. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
羽: feathers; counter for birds, rabbits
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , laundry (#577), leap (#1285), outstanding (#2272), twinkle (#2534), shimmering (#2880). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.
column5: The poor farmer spends every weekday while the sun shines, plucking turkey feathers.

column2:
十: ten
早: early; fast
肉: meat
column4: There is mist as the moon fades away in the morning.
column5: Morning has come "ten" hours "early"!!! The "moon" is still in the sky!

column2:
尺: shaku; Japanese foot; measure; scale; rule
旦: daybreak; dawn; morning
column4: Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime.
column5: In a Zelda game, you can warp to the daytime if you play your shakuhachi to bring about nightbreak... or your ocarina if you don´t have a shakuhachi.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
人: person
夕: evening
column4: Actually, the lower-right primitive isn´t quite "walking legs." It´s a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town...
column5: Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed).

column2:
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: When something is entered by a dagger, it ends up being cut in several parts.
column5: (This kanji also has the meanings of "understand" and "minute"). It´s important to understand that were you to enter an hour with a dagger and cut it into parts, those parts would be minutes.

column2:
周: circumference; circuit; lap
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.
column5: Actually the week is like a never ending road where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the circumference is always the same. circumference (#317) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth -- all important for measuring all kinds of time periods.

column2:
三: three
大: large; big
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: In the springtime bonsai get plenty of sun.
column5: When it´s springtime you can only leave the bonsai out when the sun has gone down. Their little leaves can´t handle too much heat.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
自: oneself
夂: winter radical (no. 34)
column4: In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.
column5: I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)
火: fire
column4: In AUTUMN, the WHEAT looks the color of FIRE, meaning it´s time to harvest it.
column5: Every autumn the wheat is set on fire to clear the way for next year´s crop...

column2:
夂: winter radical (no. 34)
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)
column4: Don´t slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet.
column5: In winter my walking legs feel like blocks of ice.

column2:
人: person
一: one; one radical (no.1)
column4: My MEETING is at 7- but that´s NOW!
column5: (re: ruuku35) The meeting is not at quarter to seven but now!

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
木: tree; wood
斤: axe; 1.32 lb; catty; counter for loaves of bread; axe radical (no. 69)
column4: Don't confuse left primitive with catalpa (#1498). Every time the farmer cuts down the peppers from the red pepper plant, he has to use a brand new axe. This is because the spicy peppers cause the metal to erode very quickly, thereby rendering the axe completely useless.
column5: Axe-man grows a patch of red pepper plants in his back garden. He rubs red peppers on the edge of his axes, and this seems to keep them sharp like brand new.

column2:
十: ten
口: mouth
column4: Tombstone and cross on an old man´s grave.
column5: You get OLD fast if you have ten open mouths to feed.

column2:
門: gate; counter for cannons
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.
column5: We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.

column2: 亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
column4: Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare ten thousand (#64). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.
column5: I always keep my directions bound to the bottom of my top hat so I won´t lose them.

column2: 匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
column4: Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!
column5: In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.

column2:
十: ten
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
干: dry; parch
column4: South of my belt leads to happiness.
column5: In the south (Southern Alabama, Southern Africa, picture any south, but choose one and stick with it) "they measure happyness by the belt". If someone has a larger belly (and a longer belt), it is believed they are well fed and thus are happy.

column2:
木: tree; wood
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.
column5: The sun pierces through the trees as it rises in the east…

column2: 襾: west, west radical (no. 146)
column4: The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare sign of the bird (#1427) whiskey bottle about one third full).
column5: Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.

column2:
袁: long kimono
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.
column5: When traveling to a distant land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?

column2:
斤: axe; 1.32 lb; catty; counter for loaves of bread; axe radical (no. 69)
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...
column5: An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.

column2:
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
月: month; moon
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me.
column5: If you stand in front of a bull´s horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).

column2:
彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)
幺: short thread radical (no. 52)
夂: winter radical (no. 34)
column4: Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self behind.
column5: after a grub goes through the cocoon stage, it leaves its walking legs behind for a life of flight.

column2:
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
人: person
column4: Mr. T´s new belt is huge! When he´s inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground!
column5: How is a person ever supposed to get inside that girl when she´s wearing such a huge chastity belt? I guess that´s kinda the point, eh?

column2:
夕: evening
卜: divination
column4: A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in eminent (#51)).
column5: Outside in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
昜: open; sun
column4: You´re looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that´s easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to remember like this kanji.
column5: Don´t confuse with place (#1127). Think of location not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You´ve buried your piggy bank in the dirt in your backyard, but you can´t remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of location to find your piggy bank.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
也: to be (classical)
column4: Picture the ground as an extent of soil where scorpions are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying ´no trespassing, scorpion mines´ if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.
column5: The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the ground.

column2:
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
玉: jewel; ball
column4: In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).
column5: Just think of Japan, a country which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.

column2:
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
袁: long kimono
column4: A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).
column5: There was a homeless man living in a box at the park so I gave him a lidded crock filled with hot curry tied with a scarf...

column2: 口: mouth
column4: This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of valley: a valley mouth open under the umbrella of inner labia, with the outer labia parted above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will enter no further...
column5: Think of the classic anime 風の谷のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind). We see Nausicaa entering the valley mouth gliding on an umbrella.

column2:
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
予: beforehand; previous; myself; I
column4: These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains.
column5: The plains are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your computer´s battery beforehand, or you won´t get anything done.

column2:
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
白: white
小: little; small
column4: Follow the springs down the cliff and you will find a nice meadow.
column5: Sorry about this, but Heisig was stupid calling this kanji meadow, used in composite words the most common meaning is ORIGIN... To remember just think that life may have begun in pounds or springs in a land with many cliffs ... Just to answer correctly the review lessons think of meadow as the origin of a huge forest.

column2: 里: village, mile, village radical (no. 166)
column4: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.
column5: Hint: Heisig makes here a severe disservice to everyone by using a weird keyword for this character. You´ll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: House of the Parents.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)
column4: My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I´m wearing only a top hat...and a towel.
column5: At the MARKET you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
口: mouth
小: little; small
column4: Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings).
column5: The capital is where the powerful act formal wearing top hats, open their mouths, and get little done.

column2:
几: table; table enclosure; table or windy radical (no. 16)
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of WIND that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.
column5: The WIND usually carries things around in it - drops of rain or snow, and lots of insects.

column2:
雨: rain
彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)
column4: SNOW isn´t all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.
column5: Rain just soaks into the soil. Snow has to be swept away with a broom...

column2:
雨: rain
云: say
column4: Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).
column5: Every cloud is a potential rain cloud.

column2:
水: water
也: to be (classical)
column4: Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.
column5: Water scorpions loves to live in the pond.

column2:
水: water
毎: every
column4: Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.
column5: As depicted in the classic SF film Fantastic Voyage, every drop of water is a sea, if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with ocean (#549).

column2:
山: mountain
石: stone
column4: A mountain-sized stone is known as a boulder.
column5: Here we see mountain rocks rolling down the mountain, gathering into a single monstrous boulder crushing everything in its path. Think snowball effect, even if it wouldn´t work with rocks.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
生: life; genuine; birth
column4: The sun is the nearest star to the only planet with life - Earth.
column5: Sun is a star that has given life. Can´t say that of any other stars yet.

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
至: climax; arrive; proceed; reach; attain; result in
column4: You book a room in a love hotel called "Climax House".
column5: A simple room is made up of a roof, some walls, and a dirt floor.

column2: 戸: door, house, door radical (no. 63)
column4: Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling.
column5: A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door).

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
豕: pig; hog; pig radical (no. 152)
column4: Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.
column5: Man, ever hear of cleaning? This house is a pig sty.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
寸: measurement; foot/10
column4: At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.
column5: To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve.

column2:
甬: road with walls on both sides
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].
column5: Building on gorgon´s story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the traffic. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge chopseal that they utilize to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the road.

column2: 門: gate, gate radical (no. 169)
column4: Heisig´s stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the "sun" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you´ll get the stroke order exactly correct.
column5: The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... Bill Gates?

column2:
首: neck; counter for songs and poems
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that´s why I take the train! ).
column5: Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel´s neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it´s precious contents into the dust?

column2:
言: say
舌: tongue; reed; clapper
column4: Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.
column5: Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths.

column2: 口: mouth
column4: A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.
column5: This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.

column2:
竹: bamboo
合: fit; suit; join; 0.1
column4: The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the bamboo pieces fit together.
column5: For the frustrated housewife the solution came in form of a BAMBOO stick that FITS her well.

column2: 土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.
column5: When an enemy´s flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.

column2:
門: gate; counter for cannons
耳: ear
column4: Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.
column5: To distinguish from listen, you hear someone at the door (gate).

column2:
言: say
吾: I; my; our; one's own
column4: The simplest word to say is I.
column5: May I say a word about that?

column2:
言: say
売: sell
column4: Read the WORDS used to SELL things.
column5: People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don´t believe everything you read (読).

column2:
聿: brush; finally; self; relate; follow; here; fast; writing brush radical (no. 129)
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.
column5: The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her brush to write, she would stick out her tongue, just slightly.

column2:
言: say
己: self; snake; serpent
column4: A scribe writes down the words spoken by a snake (i.e. a lawyer).
column5: Snakes have no hands. So, when a snake needs to write down something, it has to call in a SCRIBE, who will write down all the sayings of the snake.

column2:
糸: thread
氏: family name; surname; clan
column4: All that threads you to your family name is a piece of paper. (birth certificate).
column5: I imagine a ridiculously expensive, and rather pointless, Japanese type of paper for writing letters, with one´s family name woven in fine thread somewhere in a corner.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
由: wherefore; a reason
凵: open box enclosure; open box radical (no. 17)
column4: You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.
column5: To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. [modified from johnskb´s].

column2:
糸: thread
会: meeting; meet; party; association; interview; join
column4: There´s never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why?
column5: When all the Threads finally Meet the Picture will emerge...

column2:
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
乂: mow; cut grass; subdue
column4: Can´t see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it´s written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.
column5: A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do.

column2: 工: work (radical no. 48)
column4: I consider craft to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I´ve personified it as Bender the crafty robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.
column5: I crafty.

column2:
孝: filial piety; child's respect
攵: strike; hit; folding chair radical variant (no. 66)
column4: In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it.
column5: You could say that the taskmistress is teaching you filial piety when she whips you and asks, "Who´s your daddy?!".

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
青: blue; green
column4: Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather´s cleared up!
column5: When we speak of clearing up we easily think of both the sun and blue skies. But in another since to clear up is the absence of weather. And therefor the reason weather has no place in its writing.

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Think with your brain NOT your heart.
column5: To think is to use your brain over your heart.

column2:

丂: obstruction of breath (qi) as it seeks release; variant of other characters
column4: Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.
column5: Even though he had the old man Mr. Wilson within the sights of his slingshot, Dennis the Menace considered what he was doing and stopped.

column2:
矢: dart; arrow
口: mouth
column4: I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!
column5: [know; wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口] If you know the answers, they will fly like darts from your mouth.

column2: 手: hand
column4: Spinal tap: "Every other band´s amps go to ten. But you see my extra stroke of genius - these go to eleven.".
column5: A TEN year old had a STROKE of GENIUS and wrote this joke: 何歳ですか？　　　。。。天才です！.

column2:
玉: jewel; ball
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
column4: The king of LOGIC is the computer.
column5: Computers are ruled by logic (it is the king of computers).

column2:
竹: bamboo
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
廾: twenty; 20; twenty or letter H radical (no. 55)
column4: Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It´s not as easy as a calculator, but you don´t need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands.
column5: Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You´d be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs.

column2:
人: person
乍: though; notwithstanding; while; during; both; all
column4: Mr T.´s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he´s a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.
column5: When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, "I don´t know about y´all foos, but I´m gonna make a raft.".

column2:
二: two; two radical (no.2)
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: In the beginning were just two who walked on human legs.
column5: In the beginning God created woman, and God asked her how she liked his work. Woman replied, "Well, you know how I have two eyes, two arms, two legs... it seems redundant to have three breasts. It would look more symmetrical with two." God nodded, and the middle breast fell off... and it was good. Woman picked up the breast and said, "Thank you, God! But what do I do with this useless boob?" And God created man. That´s why the women today only have two boobs to match their two human legs.

column2: 食: eat, food, food radical (no. 184)
column4: That umbrella looks good enough to eat!
column5: Umbrella + Good: Let's go eat at that restaurant - the table with the umbrella looks good.

column2: 肉: meat, meat radical (no. 130)
column4: Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.
column5: A person´s inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat.

column2: 火: fire
column4: Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail "feathers". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though.
column5: The top part is half a comb (see frame 1920) with an extra vertical stroke to account for a sturdier version used to comb a horse mane. As a primitive I used the theme of the Trojan Horse. Not the modern computer viruses, but the large wooden horse which led to the demise of Troy and of the Trojans. Either its size (much greater than a live horse), or the fact that it conceals things into its belly, will set it appart from the horse primitive that came in frame 568 ("noon").

column2: 牛: cow, cow radical (no. 93)
column4: A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.
column5: A cow bleeds vermilion when you cut off two of it´s legs.

column2:
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
田: rice field; rice paddy
火: fire
column4: The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.
column5: Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!

column2: 火: fire
column4: There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock.
column5: The BIRD let loose a WHITE ONE from it´s TAIL FEATHERS...right on my new car!

column2: 羽: feather, wing, feather radical (no. 124)
column4: Pictograph. Easy enough.
column5: These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.

column2:
口: mouth
鳥: bird; chicken
column4: A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds.
column5: This kanji is not limited to the chirp of a bird, but stands for the sound of any kind of animal. Picture a very weird bird that can imitate with its mouth (a bird with mouth, heh) the voice of many different animals: Meeow! Woof! Mooo! Cuack!!! (Maybe the bird has Kirby powers and obtains the abilities of the animals it eats).

column2: 夂: winter radical (no. 34)
column4: BARLEY beverages give GROWN UPs teetering WALKING LEGS.
column5: "Grown up" barley, i.e. beer, is what gets you tottering legs.

column2: 米: rice, rice radical (no. 119)
column4: Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.
column5: Two drops of rice in a tree, simple.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
人: person
木: tree; wood
column4: Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. That´s why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a wood-en toothpick supporting a paper umbrella with flowers printed on top.
column5: When I drink herbal tea I like to drink it under a parasol. If it´s too hot I go "ho, ho, ho !!" (katakana ホ).

column2:
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
巴: comma-design
column4: Ever look closely at mosaics? They contain a bunch of images bound up into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their colour.
column5: Bound up in the Rubik´s cube are the 6 different colours.

column2: 黄: yellow, yellow radical (no. 201)
column4: The salad did not look very appetizing... The sprouts were yellow and there were animal legs sticking out of it.
column5: I order a salad with sprouts. I´m asked if I´d like to add chicken. Yes please. My salad then arrives . . . . topped with these horribly gnarled yellow things. Chicken feet! (animal legs) ugh.

column2:
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
火: fire
column4: If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black.
column5: If your parent´s home catches on fire, it will turn black.

column2: 米: rice; USA; metre
column4: You horny bastard, don´t come, at least not yet!
column5: Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not "poking through". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out.

column2: 彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)
column4: I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast.
column5: To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.

column2:
刀: sword; saber; knife
帚: broom
column4: A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).
column5: Well, the boss man warrior upon his homecoming has set aside his spear. Remember the lady (#1151) (who put aside her broom and apron)? I wonder what they´re doing now?

column2:
止: stop; halt
少: few; little
column4: When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.
column5: When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again.

column2: 土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!
column5: The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.

column2: 止: stop
column4: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it´s some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
column5: If you don´t remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, you´re beyyond help!

column2:
水: water
舌: tongue; reed; clapper
column4: Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It´s because "watery tongues" loosen lips!
column5: I´m sure I can get her pretty lively and wet using my tongue.

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)

column4: Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.
column5: The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.

column2:

column5: A "samurai" will never sell his "crown" (king), even it meant having both his "human legs" chopped off!

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
干: dry; parch
column4: Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).
column5: Noon is the hour of the horse.

column2:
水: water

column4: Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.
column5: Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness.

column2: 弓: bow, bow radical (no. 57)
column4: My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.
column5: I have a BOW made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn´t happy!

column2:
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
口: mouth
column4: Write mouth two -times.
column5: Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).

column2:
人: person
云: say
column4: At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business meeting in a very special room where the walls are ... meeting. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these meetings, he´s the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.
column5: The only thing created in most meetings is a lot of hot air. Imagine a cloud of it rising to the roof.

column2:
糸: thread
且: moreover; also; furthermore
column4: A common thread associates the knick-knacks on your knick-knack shelf. Souveneirs from Spain on one, from Japan on the other.
column5: Watch this: http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg The leader of the Spiderman association has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.(Zactacular).

column2:
舟: boat; ship
㕣: a marsh at the foot of the hills; name of a river
column4: A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.
column5: Aargh, hard to keep this separate from boat. How about this: the phrase "shape up or ship out!" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He´s riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley).

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
月: month; moon
column4: The sun makes the moon bright.
column5: The sun and the moon are brightest objects in the day and night, respectively.

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.
column5: Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees.

column2:
七: seven
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: The seven samurai used their swords to cut their opponents.
column5: Seven swords cut better than one.

column2:
雨: rain
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days

column5: This kanji was invented by the first Chinaman to discover electricity. He was so unfortunate, he stepped on an electric eel and got struck by lighting at the same time.

column2:

column4: Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother.
column5: Who does every person want to lie down with? Yo´ MAMA!

column5: He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.

column2:

column4: Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.
column5: Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. The target is so small, in fact, that if someone does manage to hit it, the operator turns in surprise and says, "Whoa, really?! (本当?!)".

column2:
厶: I; myself; katakana mu radical (no. 28)
口: mouth
column4: When someone´s elbow is above your mouth he/she is probably standing on a pedestal.
column5: After training your whole life, you manage to get a bronze medal in the Olympics. You´re extremely proud of your accomplishment as you step up to receive your medal. The guy in first place is up on a pedestal, towering above you, his elbow level with your mouth. Being a smug bastard, he "accidentally" knocks his elbow into your mouth, causing you to bleed and lose a tooth. Just cause he won the gold doesn´t mean he can place himself on such a high pedestal and do whatever he wants!

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)

column5: There we were at the concert...her voice was like a dove...her dress sparkled...then suddenly, a tree fell on her.....

column2:
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
厶: I; myself; katakana mu radical (no. 28)
column4: I always open the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don´t want to touch the door with my hands.
column5: I always enter the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don´t want to touch the door with my hands.

column2:
弓: bow; bow (archery, violin)

column2:

column5: Can-can dancers are supposed to be big-bosomed girls who dance. Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a song, so audience of men is yawning in boredom.

column2: 刀: knife, sword, knife radical (no. 18)
column4: This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.
column5: If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there sword in his ass!

column2:

田: rice field; rice paddy
column4: The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.
column5: They take turns alternating between wheat and rice in this field…

column2: 用: use (radical no. 101)
column4: To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!
column5: I´ll confuse this with use (#990), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, "utilize" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize "utilize" when you´re trying to puff up what you´re saying and sound important. So: "BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!" I´m seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.

column2:
人: person
可: can; passable; mustn't; should not; do not
column4: What can Mr T do? ´You mean: what can´t MR T do, you fool´.
column5: What can´t Mr. T not do?

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
亅: feathered stick; barb radical (no. 6)
column4: Today, the program "Sesame Street" is brought to you by the letter "T".
column5: Two streets make a T-intersection.

column2: 廿: twenty; 20
column4: 3 tens = generation.
column5: They SAY a generation is ten+ten+ten years, with the big first ten providing a grounding, and the next ten providing a little more grounding for the final ten. But I wish the next generation didn´t always SAY "yo!". (ON reading is SEI, KUN reading is yo).

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)

column4: Primatives celing; belt; mountain as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.
column5: Both of Tiger Wood´s initials is the logo on his belt...

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
玉: jewel; ball
column4: A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.
column5: Although this kanji´s meaning hasn´t caused me much trouble, I´ve had problems remembering the direction of the drop above king, since drops at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the drop in jewel (#256). Both of them use the king primitive and include a short drop stroke going from the top left to bottom right.

column2:
千: thousand
木: tree; wood
column4: It´s a hay ride! You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.
column5: [ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have wheat silage surplus.

column5: Your halberd doesn´t have a handguard? You should have thought of that beforehand (i.e., before you were missing your hand).

column2:

column5: Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.

column2:
人: person
士: gentleman; samurai; samurai radical (no. 33)
column4: Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them.
column5: [+fuaburisu] Mr T attends to Tom Cruise in the Last Samurai, who is doing hara-kiri. Imagine Tom Cruise outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while Mr T looks patiently on. "I pity da foo....no, really.".

column2:
人: person
也: to be (classical)
column4: Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio (people are scorpions to other people).
column5: It´s one or the other: fight Mr. T, or be thrown into the scorpion pit.

column2:
人: person
弋: piling; ceremony radical (no. 56)
column4: Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It´s best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to "mediator" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one.
column5: Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.

column2:
人: person
主: lord; chief; master; main thing; principal
column4: When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery.
column5: Mister T dwells in a big brass candlestick, the flame of which serves as a beacon for the boats in the nearby harbour. Sometimes in the morning, Mister T has to clear the wax that has landed and solidified in front of the door.

column2:
人: person
吏: officer; an official
column4: Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo!
column5: Mr. T uses the officer as a punching bag.

column2:
人: person
系: lineage; system
column4: Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all.
column5: The person in charge usually must come from a long standing lineage of persons in charge.

column2:
人: person
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
口: mouth
column4: Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory.
column5: Mr T, like many holywood stars, has a butt double who is used only for scenes where T´s buttocks are exposed (he has issues with bearing his behind). The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn´t he´s rambling on about pity and foo.

column2:
人: person
玉: jewel; ball
column4: The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro´s story. "fat" makes a more vivid image for me.).
column5: The king takes up the whole space under his umbrella.

column2:

column5: Skeleton army rank and file. Dudes made of bones carrying sabres.

column4: HELP! Someone´s pinned under this bookshelf and it´s gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!
column5: Can you help me move this shelf? I don´t have the muscle to do it alone.

column2:

column2:

column2:

column4: Referring to a scene in the movie "The Matrix" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of "spare change", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as "shape" or "turn into".
column5: Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.

column2:

column5: That´s the homeless ward of the city. Wolverine lives in a cardboard box there.

column2:
匚: box-on-side enclosure radical (no. 22)
矢: dart; arrow
column4: Easily confused: Dr. (#47), doctor (#1694), examination (#1673), check-up (#1724), medicine (#1736). To avoid confusion I renamed this medic, and picture the medic from Team Fortress 2 returning to his box of darts in the supply cupboard every time his syringe gun is empty.
column5: This DOCTOR prefers to use DARTS instead of syringes for injections. Here, he pulls out his BOX of DARTS, and the child on the examination table squirms.

column2:

column5: If you want the soil stains gone from your clothes, then you´ll need to put some elbow grease into cleaning them.

column2:

column4: I think of an anti-hero (Dirty Harry etc.) for this primitive, whose trademark for disposing of villians is not an honorable fight, but a kick in the crotch and then a shove off a cliff (perhaps whilst the villain´s back is turned).
column5: Many cultures are so anti-sex you´d think they just want people to throw their crotches over a cliff.

column2:

又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: You put your ear next to a womans crotch...and somehow, from it, you hear the words "Take me....".
column5: Fuaburisu´s with a twist: You know that classic trick where someone pretends to take something out of an someone else´s ear (such as a coin). Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s crotch out of their ear. Very painful!

column2:
