column4: The bird house is the brothel (someone else said so) and of course everyone is welcome - thay accept any crotch.
column5: A birdhouse is a whorehouse that will accept any crotch even those with STDs. (Image: a birdhouse whorehouse with every kind of bird coming and going. Some old madam at the front hole accepts everyone, even the nasty old crows).

column2:

column5: When certain nickname snares to people´s mouths, they will call you that way forever.

column2:

column4: There´s a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well old boy," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago".
column5: The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth.

column5: Your ability to resist FATE can be fit on a postage stamp.

column5: People who live in harmony with nature live in the country. they are yokels or hillbillys. See Billy-bob sitting on the porch in their denhim dungarees a sheaf of wheat, sticking from their mouth.

column2:

The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution.
column5: Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he´s trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, "hey, we can still make a deal.".

column2:

column5: This kanji depicts a classic enviornmental problem: erosion. Erosion occurs when all of the soil washes of the side of the cliff, eventually causing the cliff to disappear, leaving a slope (an anti- cliff if you will) in its place.

column2:

column5: If you want to commence a relationship, just put a woman on a pedestal and she´ll love ya forever.

column5: A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.

column4: It´s funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman relaxing. Cheapest place to do that is in one´s own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? 家で休暇を取るは安いですね。.
column5: You can only relax, when you have woman under roof to do all chores.

column2:

column5: People who decide to renovate (ooh, that´s a fancy word, let´s say "mend") their houses must be very determined DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see DEtermine).

column2:

column5: On this rather boring ´big brother´ type reality show, they have locked up bonsai inside a house and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.

column5: A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: "house with a spine, Shinto shrine"!

column4: Don't mix up with cool (#1404), when the cool boys order each other around. This kind of cold has to do with weather. When its cold outside, I stay at home and have hot celery soup with chicken legs to keep out the ice. 寒い　＝　さむい　＝cold.
column5: Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn´t get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.

column5: シュウ　The original meaning of this character was "sandbar", and for me this conjures up images of the Mississippi River, which is very wide with many sandbars and which was used to define the borders in ten American states. Picture Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer floating by state after state as they adventure down the mighty Mississippi, occasionally beaching their raft on sandbars.

column2: 干: dry; parch

column2:

column5: The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.

column5: Back in caveman days, courts were held in caves. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the courtyard (the yard outside the cave court ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.

column2:

column2:

column2:

column2:

column5: Strong EMOTIONS don´t stay hidden. They march right out of one´s heart (below) and out one´s mouth (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of emotion it is!).

column2:

殳: pike; windy-again radical (no. 79)

By the way, for those of you looking for a less anachronistic image for the missile primitive as a modern rocket, try a slingshot. it´s a crotch (originally a tree branch) that sends missile projectiles flying into/like the wind. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers...
column5: If you use the primitive "semen" (flying in the wind from your crotch) instead of missile then all kanjis with this primitive will hilariously create a perfect story.

column5: Try PICKING UP a girl by trying to FIT your FINGER in you know what... let me know how that works.

column5: In Kyaiktiyo, there is rocking stone which sits on the edge of a cliff, and there is a Buddhist temple built on the top of it. You can rock the stone by pushing it with your finger, but it still holds in place. It´s true, see here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyaiktiyo.

column2:

column5: When a bundle of taskmasters organize something chances are it won´t be done correctly because they are constantly arguing.

column2:

column5: After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.

column2:

column5: For those who don´t know the expression, "salad days" means the time of one´s youth. (originally from Shakespeare´s Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose "salad" as the name for the radical just for this phrase...

column2:

column2:

Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow "Atsui! It´s so sultry!".

羊: sheep
木: tree; wood
column4: The oldest profession: prostitution. I was once in a brothel in Amsterdam where the working girls had a group of businessmen blindfolded and hanging upside down in a row, not yet spanked and whipped, but waiting eagerly.
column5: A bunch of kids are hanging upside down in a row on the monkeybars. Naturally, they haven't chosen a profession, at least not yet.

column2:
木: tree; wood
羊: sheep
水: water
column4: Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice.
column5: This is -Sama, a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you´d definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive.

column2:
木: tree; wood
黄: yellow
column4: A tree went all yellow. It died and fell down, ending up sideways.
column5: In a horrible accident, a yellow schoolbus gets wrapped sideways around a tree.

column2:
木: tree; wood
喬: high; boasting
column4: The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco.
column5: A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, "Don´t worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you." The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, "What are you doing with that wood?" "I´m trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels.".

column2:
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)
欠: lack; gap; fail; yawning radical (no. 76)
column4: Is this store lacking ice? Let´s try the next one, then.
column5: A rapper called "Ice" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. Next...

column2:
止: stop; halt
米: rice; USA; metre
凵: open box enclosure; open box radical (no. 17)
column4: Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you´ll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.
column5: My dentist used his foot and a shovel to dislodge the rice stuck between my teeth.

column2:
歹: bare bone; bad; wrong; death radical (n. 78)
匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
column4: Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they´re out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.
column5: Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of death), carrying a spoon made of human bones instead of a scythe.

column2:
水: water
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: Icicles start with 1 frozen drop of water.
column5: A drop in temperature turns water into an icicle.

column2:
水: water
夬: decide; determine; archery glove
column4: Decide! "Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?" I asked.
column5: To decide if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in water. If they don´t drown they are a witch and can be sent to the guillotine.

column2:
水: water
由: wherefore; a reason
column4: The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field.
column5: In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills.

column2:
水: water
皮: pelt; skin; hide; leather; skin radical (no. 107)
column4: Waves are the ocean´s pelt (skin).
column5: The Inuit used water-proof seal pelts for their kayaks, to travel the waves.

column2:
水: water
主: lord; chief; master; main thing; principal
column4: Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.
column5: Like water the hot wax poured down the side of the candlestick.

column2:
水: water
永: eternity; long; lengthy
column4: With that much WATER (2 actually) you would need to swim for an ETERNITY.
column5: If you don´t know how to swim, you´ll be in that water for eternity.

column2:
水: water
羊: sheep
column4: This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.
column5: Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across oceans of water in order to recover the fleece of a certain sheep.

column2:
水: water
㐬: a cup with pendants; a pennant; wild; barren; uncultivated
column4: INFANT Moses placed in the WATER and sent down the current of the STREAM.
column5: A water-breathing infant (genetically modified?) is caught in a flood, and drifts with the current, apparently enjoying himself in the process.

column2:
水: water
肖: resemblance
column4: To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER.
column5: You need a few drops of water to extinguish the candle.

column2:
水: water
㓁: a net; net-like; radical 122
木: tree; wood
column4: If the groper´s "tree" goes up the girl´s miniskirt too deep, he´ll ejaculate fluid. (Sorry it´s kinda coarse but it works.).
column5: Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself.

column2:
水: water
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
皿: dish; a helping; plate
column4: If you leave water out in the sun in a dish, naturally it will get warm.
column5: To distinguish from warmth (#1949), which refers to warm weather, remember that this means warm objects or feelings. Imagine a plastic kiddy pool in the backyard full of lukewarm water. The kiddy pool is shaped like a huge dish, and it's been under the sun all day - that's why the water is warm now.

column2:
水: water
巷: fork in road; scene; arena; theater
column4: During a deluge, all the poor snakes get washed into the harbour.
column5: All throughout the deluge Noah had been kicking himself for forgetting to bring any snakes onto the Ark. It wasn´t until the deluge had finished, and Noah had brought the Ark safely back to the harbour that he realised that the snakes had been under the Ark all along.

column2:
水: water
胡: barbarian; foreign
column4: This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.
column5: Water reflects the old moon in the lake.

column2:
水: water
昜: open; sun
column4: Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!
column5: Hot water is a phrase that can mean "getting into trouble." This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it´s water that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your piggy bank is empty!

column2:
水: water
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
口: mouth
夫: husband; man
column4: Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat/water into learning the kanji. For right-hand kanji primitive - The dumb Western husband of a Japanese woman buys her flowers to apologise, after he opened his big mouth and said "kanji are a stupid writing system"..
column5: In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.

column2:
山: mountain
灰: ashes; puckery juice; cremate
column4: Burn enough charcoal and you´ll have a mountain of ash.
column5: You get charcoal from volcano ("fire mountain", 火山) ashes.

column2:
牛: cow
勿: not; must not; do not; be not
column4: The cow´s "thing" is tied in a knot! ouch.
column5: A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.

column2:
玉: jewel; ball
求: request; want; wish for; require; demand
column4: Someone files a request to see the family jewels and, to their surprise, you show them your balls!
column5: The KING REQUESTS your presence at the ball ... game.

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off).
column5: Cogito ergo sum. Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it´s often mistranslated as "where" when in fact it´s an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.].

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth.
column5: I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in "moshi moshi" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say "hello, this is X speaking.".

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
介: jammed in; shellfish; mediate; concern oneself with
column4: One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.
column5: A famous philosopher once said that his world consisted of all the things he could jam into his brain.

column2:
火: fire
田: rice field; rice paddy
column4: Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.
column5: When creating a farm, the prospective farmer must first set fire to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the fields. Fire before fields to make a farm.

column2:
疒: trailing sickness; sick radical (no. 104)
丙: third class; 3rd; 3rd calendar sign
column4: Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).
column5: If you hang around a third class hospital, you´ll get ill with the sickness everyone else has.

column2:
癶: dotted tent radical (no. 105)
二: two; two radical (no.2)
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there´ll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.
column5: I spent some time in her TEEPEE...just the TWO of us...but I looked between her HUMAN LEGS and I saw a nasty DISCHARGE...so I made my 出発　rather hastily.

column2:
癶: dotted tent radical (no. 105)
豆: beans; pea; midget
column4: When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.
column5: When I was a kid I went out camping in a teepee. I ate beans for dinner, and afterwards I produced so much gas that my teepee actually ascended in the air!

column2: 皮: skin, skin radical (no. 107)
column4: A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.
column5: To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to "just remember it" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼（かれ him）波（なみ wave）and so on.

column2: 皿: dish, dish radical (no. 108)
column4: Three dishes stacked side-by-side in a dishwasher.
column5: Pictograph of a dish with a three-layer cake slice on it.

column2:
木: tree; wood
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: The prime minister is having inter-course behind that tree! All you can see are his eyes poking out from the righthand-side of the tree.
column5: ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other´s aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, neck (#70)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)".

column2:
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
小: little; small
column4: In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie´s boyfriend. He has lovely blue eyes, a girlfriend who is as thin as a straightened out fish hook. But, down where it counts, he has very little to show...
column5: After sticking a fishhook in your eye, the yakuza boss probably has little more to do to convince you to move to a different prefecture.

column2:
十: ten
具: tool; utensil; means; possess; ingredients; counter for armor, suits, sets of furniture
column4: A compass is a tool with a needle on top that points to true north.
column5: Ten tools are all a true craftsman needs.

column2:
羊: sheep
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.
column5: Someone who is donning a disguise does that in order to pull the wool over your eyes.

column2:
矢: dart; arrow
豆: beans; pea; midget
column4: He is so short so he has to throw darts from the table.
column5: Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.

column2:
石: stone
幵: put together
column4: My stones are so huge that it takes two hands to polish them!
column5: You use two hands to polish a stone: one to hold it and the other to rub it.

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
乙: the latter; duplicate; strange; witty; fishhook radical (no. 5)
column4: Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away.
column5: You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
申: have the honor to; sign of the monkey; 3-5PM; ninth sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus´ latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .
column5: Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him.

column2:
月: month; moon
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
column4: A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.
column5: There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
畐: to fill; roll of cloth
column4: This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah.
column5: Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)
少: few; little
column4: An hourglass filled with wheat counts time. A few wheat seeds drop every second.
column5: I´ll be with you soon... please wheat a few seconds.

column2:
穴: hole; aperture; slit; cave; den
九: nine
column4: Most research scientists have 9 holes.....two nostrils, two ears, a mouth, and four eyes...... :-).
column5: Scientiest are researching , and have already found nine black holes !

column2:
音: sound; noise
早: early; fast
column4: In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention.
column5: Ash Ketchum stood up early in the morning, and said, "Pikachu, let´s go get us another badge!".

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
column4: The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.
column5: The movie Zoolander is a little JUVENILE and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson standing on the desk, hitting the computer like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer...).

column2:
竹: bamboo
田: rice field; rice paddy
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: Flute is made of bamboo sprout.
column5: You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.

column2:
竹: bamboo
弔: condolences; mourning; funeral
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
column4: The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future.
column5: Bamboo bling is the newest Asian Rapper, No. 1 on the charts right now.

column2:
竹: bamboo
聿: brush; finally; self; relate; follow; here; fast; writing brush radical (no. 129)
column4: Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush.
column5: Bamboo would make an excellent writing brush as the ink could flow through the hollow center like an ink pen...

column2:
竹: bamboo
寺: Buddhist temple
column4: The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc.
column5: So what´d you see in Japan? - "Bamboo, temples...etc.".

column2:
竹: bamboo
相: inter-; mutual; together; each other; minister of state; councillor; aspect; phase; physiognomy
column4: The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you´ve mastered this kanji.
column5: I think of a box made of inter-locking of bamboo strips.

column2:
糸: thread
及: reach out; exert; exercise; cause
column4: This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a "class of students" or "classroom," but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend´s answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge.
column5: We can almost see the outstreched hands of the lower classes wearing just a few threads in this kanji.

column2:
糸: thread
冬: winter
column4: This winter is so cold that spiderman´s web gets brittle! Could this be the end of spiderman?
column5: The thread of life begins with the spring and ends with the winter.

column2:
糸: thread
彔: to carve wood
column4: When you attend a green tea (緑茶=りょくちゃ) ceremony, you can cherish the threadwork on the kimonos people don, the broom-like whisk (茶筌 =ちゃせん) you use to grind up your tea, and the delicious rice cakes you eat with your tea!
column5: In summer, all of Japan turns green with the green threads that fan out like brooms to later produce grains of rice. An easy image if you have ever looked out the window of the train to see all the summer rice paddies...

column2:
糸: thread
東: east
column4: You practice your Japanese skills in a discussion thread with lots of people from the Far East (since many of the people who are interested in studying Japanese are Asian).
column5: Spidey stays on the east side of the city to practice. The West Side is too dangerous.

column2: 羊: sheep, sheep radical (no. 123)
column4: Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.
column5: Our Lord and King put on ears and a tail to become a lowly sheep for the slaughter.

column2:
羊: sheep
大: large; big
column4: I guess this kanji proves it´s not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.
column5: A Sheep on top of a dog is NOT a beautiful thing.

column2:
羽: feathers; counter for birds, rabbits
白: white
column4: Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...
column5: Learning is all about adding more feathers to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure white feather you´ll receive when you have learned the kanji!

column2:
老: old man; old age; grow old
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it´s 者 who can 忍 great 拷!
column5: Back in the day, the old man used to be someone. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child´s Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
厶: I; myself; katakana mu radical (no. 28)
月: month; moon
column4: Bringing up your offspring means raising them from infant until they are meat ready to be harvested. What, cannibalism is in poor taste? Forget I ever brought it up. But bring up will forver be infant meat to me. I want my baby back baby back baby back ribs!
column5: I will bring up my infants to eat meat. I´ll not endure any vegetarian children in my house!

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
古: old
column4: Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.
column5: The derivates from opium poppies such as morphine can be used to tame the suffering of the old.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
何: what
column4: TSA guard: What´s in the baggage?! It´s just flowers, I swear!
column5: Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her flowers, but she brushes you off and says "here, carry my BAGGAGE." Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, "what?".

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
洛: Kyoto; the capital
column4: Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.
column5: [It´s been suggested on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079) that flower across the full width of the kanji and water on the left below it should have its own keyword; seaweed is a popular choice. See also dilute (#227), clan (#1912), seaweed (#2035). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers falling through the sky -- suddenly each one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori seaweed to carry them safely down.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
世: generation; world; society; public
木: tree; wood
column4: On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.
column5: The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
楽: music; comfort; ease
column4: New-age medicine involves using things like music and flowers (aromatherapy) as treatment.
column5: Oh man, this medicinal marijuana is making me hear MUSIC and see FLOWERS everywhere...

column2: 皿: dish; a helping; plate
column4: Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.
column5: Image: Holy Grail with a drop of Jesus blood on it.

column2:
二: two; two radical (no.2)
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
column4: When I was GROWING UP, the SURFACE of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it.
column5: (Thanks to zerOrange) I grew up underground, and whenever I went to the surface I wore a scarf to avoid scrutiny.

column2:
言: say
寺: Buddhist temple
column4: A poem is a temple of words.
column5: WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That´s why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.

column2:
言: say
周: circumference; circuit; lap
column4: To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what´s being said.
column5: words + circumference The most catchy tunes are words the go round and round the circuference of your head and you can´t get it out of your mind.

column2:
言: say
炎: inflammation; flame; blaze
column4: Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone´s words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.
column5: Internet discussions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!

column2: 口: mouth
column4: If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL.
column5: I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let´s call this one Mr. Bean! He´s an easy character to build stories with.

column2:
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
貝: shellfish
column4: Tied up, the shellfish had to accept defeat!
column5: Defeat is defined by a shellfish in binds.

column2:
走: run
己: self; snake; serpent
column4: Be careful when you´re RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and ROUSE a sleeping SNAKE. Then you´ll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!
column5: Nothing will rouse you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you´ve never run before!

column2:
足: leg; foot; be sufficient; counter for pairs of footwear
各: each; every; either
column4: When pirates try to hide, it´s always easy to find them. Their wooden legs leave distinctive prints, showing where each is hiding and the exact path he took.
column5: I have a wooden leg for each type of path. One with a rubber stopper at the end for absorbing shocks on paved paths, and one with a wide foot to distribute weight better on mud paths.

column2: 身: body, body radical (no. 158)
column4: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than someone (#1256) is that the story is full of body descriptions.
column5: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.

column2:
車: car
云: say
column4: The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.
column5: Just a note to remember the cloud primative: The name of Goku´s pet cloud that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is Nimbus. The katakana-ization of this is {ニム}バス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.

column2:
車: car
圣: holy; sacred
column4: Fact: this kanji is used to denote a certain class of vehicles in Japan whose engines are under a certain size (less than 750cc I think) and are called light vehicles here. Imagine a so-called light vehicle or a light-truck with a load of spools driving down a road ever so lightly, careful not to let any of the spools roll out onto the street.
column5: I want to tread lightly on the environment.... That´s why I CAR-SPOOL to work everyday.... I know, lame.

column2:
曲: bend; music; melody; composition; pleasure; injustice; fault; curve; crooked; perverse; lean
辰: sign of the dragon; 7-9AM; fifth sign of Chinese zodiac; shin dragon radical (no. 161)
column4: Imagine if you could bend a dragon to your will. Helpful in war, yes, but also a boon for agriculture. The dragon could use its sharp claws to plough the ground, and use its firey breath to clear the land. But first you'd have to bend the dragon to your will -- not an easy task.
column5: It's a good agricultural sign when, as the farmer is bending down, he discovers some plants arranged in the sign of the dragon. It means the weather and earth will be supportive of the crops.

column2:
反: anti-
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Pretty obvious: to return is to turn back on the road you´re on and go the opposite way.
column5: In "The Return of the anti-hero", Clint Eastwood kicks the villain in the crotch, pushes them off the cliff and onto a busy highway. A tiring movie franchise to say the least....

column2:
𠂤: None
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans.
column5: Maestro primative = James Bond. Here he gives chase down the road to the bad guys. I´m thinking of the car chase in ´The Man with the Golden Gun´ - NOT pursue (#539). I think about ´Race N Chase´ (a scalextric type toy)...there were no pigs in ´Race N Chase´, only cars.

column2:
天: heavens; sky; imperial
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: The St Bernard with devilish animal horns must be non other than Cerberus, guard dog of the netherworld. In this frame Cerberus is seen along the road to hell, escorting those who have been sent off to join Hades in his realm.
column5: The woolly mammoth got quite a send off before he wandered up that road never to be seen alive again.

column2:
束: bundle; sheaf; ream; tie in bundles; govern; manage; control
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the bundled sticks in the middle of the road. (dingomick).
column5: Uh oh. The stork just dropped the bundle of joy in the middle of the road. Somebody save it, quick!

column2:
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Why did the turkey cross the road? To advance to the other side, of course.
column5: [re: raulir] Animals on the road: Turtles escape (#283) and Pigs pursue (#539), while the Turkeys advance (looking very formidable indeed).

column2:
斿: to swim; to move freely; to rove
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.
column5: There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean "drive slowly", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play.

column2:

辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).
column5: Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
口: mouth
邑: village; rural community; right village radical (no. 163)
column4: Within the city walls, this section of town was so noisy that we had to muzzle them up.
column5: The section within the city walls where dogs must be muzzled by law...

column2:
者: someone; person
邑: village; rural community; right village radical (no. 163)
column4: In a metropolis people are just puppets inside city walls, there is no individuality if you live so close together.
column5: A vision of a futuristic METROPOLIS: standing at the window of your 400th floor apartment, hand in hand with your LOVE DOLL, gazing out at the gigantic CITY WALLS that you can never escape.

column2:

column4: To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.
column5: I imagine a bartender serving whiskey to his patrons, and using that snake-like sprayer to distribute soda water into each glass.

column2:
水: water
酉: west; bird; sign of the bird; 5-7PM; tenth sign of Chinese zodiac; sake radical (no. 164)
column4: Sake is just watered down whisky.
column5: Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.

column2:
千: thousand
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
column4: The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.
column5: To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very heavy vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first "wheel" is a bit bent. http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html.

column2:
金: gold
失: lose; error; fault; disadvantage; loss
column4: Iron is a metal that gradually becomes lost due to oxidation and rust.
column5: Compare with pig-iron (#270). In moving from pig-iron to iron, some of the metal´s maleability is LOST. (The only difference between the two kanji is that IRON has knee-less, unbending legs, while PIG-IRON (270) has very supple, bendable legs.).

column2:
金: gold
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
column4: Like gold, silver is a metal.
column5: Not sure why Heisig find the right side so troublesome. My grandma´s hairpin (just before long (#1920)) is made of silver, the metal that best reflects sun light. I´m sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements (sun and hairpin) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order.

column2:
門: gate; counter for cannons
幵: put together
column4: Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands.
column5: To open the gate, use your both hands.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)

column4: The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city.
column5: To reach the pinnacle of kanji perfect you need to attend the Heisig Inst.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
昜: open; sun
column4: A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people´s eyes, far below.
column5: The Pinnacle is environmentally friendly. They collect solar power through sunshine on their piggybank shaped solar arrays.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
皆: all; everything
column4: All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don´t have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!
column5: Some stupid kid has pushed all the buttons in the elevator. As it stops at all storeys you reach a pinnacle of impatience. Finally you reach your storey, the last one, at the pinnacle of the building.

column2:
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
木: tree; wood
column4: Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!
column5: Gather the turkeys for Thanksgiving. Gather the trees for Christmas. In that order...

column2: 面: face, face radical (no. 176)
column4: If you´re wearing a mask, a hundred eyes can look at you but none of them will know who you are.
column5: When Jim Carrey puts on The Mask, he can make it seem like he has 100 eyes popping out of his head.

column2:
是: just so; this; right; justice

column5: You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The topic---FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!

column2:

column4: My experience with Japanese enkais (dinner parties): plenty to drink drink drink, but a severe lack of food, T_T.
column5: When you lack food, just drink something to fill you up.

column2:

column5: A building that eats bureaucrats!!!!!!!!

column2:

column4: Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station.
column5: A homeless horse playing the flute at the station to make a dime.

column2:
自: oneself
畀: to give
column4: An Egyptian embalmer reaching both hands into the dead pharaoh´s nose and yanking out handfuls of brain.
column5: I sneezed so hard that through my NOSE I blew out my BRAINS into BOTH HANDS.

column2:

丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: [Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer´s face, he says "Negative".
column5: One below zero is a negative number.

column2:

彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)
亅: feathered stick; barb radical (no. 6)
column4: This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.
column5: A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.

column2:
人: person
寸: measurement; foot/10
column4: 賀 TO EVERYONE WHO MADE IT TO 千 kanji!! Remember, after this, you´ll be 読ing japanese novels, the news, and the internet like a native. 吉 to ALL of you in your amazing japanese 往. :).
column5: If a PERSON ADHERES to something, they stick to it like GLUE.

column5: These are your orders, declares the general at the meeting as he stamps them with his chop-seal. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one´s they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.).

column2:

column5: Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn´t wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!

column5: Note: this is not gate but actually a variation of door and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.

column2:

column5: The marquis moves to a warmer climate after he gets old enough to need a walking stick to get around.

column5: Mr. T borrowed a copy of Cinderella and won´t give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic.

column4: Halt fool - Mr T acting as a bouncer at the pavillion.
column5: Mister T makes a halt at the African pavilion at the World´s Fair. He eats all the snacks on offer, and chats up the ladies - "“I pity da foo who does not halt by your pavilion, it´s the best !".

column2:

column5: Mr.T, sir, how do you stay so healthy? I asked. "Simple, foo," he answered, "you gotta build the body up by bodybuilding!".

column2:

column5: Chuck Norris´s rules are easy to live by, just be on his side.

column5: Mr T, move. Mr Ts new exercise video called "Work it suckaz". Here is shouting "move it work it move work it!".

column5: Mr. T´s bright idea is to get a hundred million kids to vow not to use drugs. "C´mon, foo! Sign the paper!".

column2: 八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: When your wife´s LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come.
column5: A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.

column2:

column4: In the olden times, a newborn babe came out legs first.
column5: Only 18 and already got a newborn babe. Young girls are so quick to spread their legs these days...

column2: 八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)

column5: The conjoined twins, who are always together, have trouble eating together because one is a vegetarian, eating salad and the other is a avid meat eater, eating chicken legs.[Thanks fuaburisu!].

column2:

column5: The hill is so steep that you almost have to have animal legs to walk on it. However, the soldiers have no problem because they´ve been trained to march there.

column2:

column4: Coding is a tool which you can use to bend the computer to your will.
column5: Think "codex" (mnemonic help) or "code of laws", or even Leonardo Da Vinci´s code. Here I see a codex as a tool used to bend the masses into submission. Picture a huge codex book lifted down on crowds to bend them down in submission. Another: if you bend to the code without asking questions, you are a tool!

column2:

column5: A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.

column5: 1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!

column5: Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the brain, and you receive the chop seal if you have the power to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered chop seal and vertical placement.

column5: Watch for doctor (#1694), the sooner the better! In fact this kanji refers to someone well "learned", with extensive knowledge. This could apply to any kind of field. The kanji 医 ("doctor") is directly related to medicine. I would suggest to take away completely the idea of medicine here, and use a popular character whose name includes the keyword such as "Dr. Who", "Dr. Jekyll", even "Dr. Dobb´s" if you´re into programming.

column4: Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.
column5: Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was harden, which kept it pent in until it grew old enough to evolve into Butterfree..

column2:

column4: A famous ninja once pressed his two hands and saber into the soil of his temple, before going onto a mission from which he never came back. Think of some sort of signature that he left behind him. The mould of his two hands and saber has since become a popular attraction in the area.
column5: As a PUNISHMENT they made me lay face down in the DIRT leaving a nice imprinted MOULD of my whole BODY.

column2:
尚: esteem; furthermore; still; yet
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse.
column5: In most communities you will be hauled into city hall if you use the ground as an outhouse.

column2:

column4: In the old days, salt was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone reclining on the ground, mouth to plate, getting every last grain of that delicious salt.
column5: The eccentric explorer lay down on the earth 土, opened his mouth 口, and licked it. "As I suspected!" he said, "It's salt. Something to spice up our dishes 皿 with!"

column2: 士: scholar, bachelor (radical no. 33)

column5: A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn´t soil himself.

column2:

column5: Imagine an apple on walking legs on stage singing "It´s not unusual to be loved by anyone" (Tom Jones). Keyword can be confused with uncommon (#1797).

column2: 大: large; big
column4: Even though it is argued size is not important, I´m sure most women would like their husband to have a big one.
column5: Homer Simpson, as a primitive.

column2:

column4: The drop falling here is the husband´s toupee... he´s already lost his hair once, now he´s losing it again. Such is life, I suppose.
column5: Note: Heisig´s stroke order is wrong. It´s the same as vermilion, drop first. Homer loses/drops his wedding ring.

column4: A woman is fond of her child.
column5: Jane Fonda carrying a Vietnamese child. Pro-war protesters hold signs, "I´m not fonda Jane!"...

column2:

column2:
子: child; sign of the rat; 11PM-1AM; first sign of Chinese zodiac

column4: Your grandchild is the child of your DNA.
column5: Your child continues the family lineage by passing on your DNA, giving you a grandchild.

column5: Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household.

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
口: mouth

column2:

column4: I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at.

column2:

column2:

column5: Noob players make no distinction between what games they play, whether it´s the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of Wool-craft!

column2:

column5: Wolverine (sheaf, see reap (#1488)) hopes they invent linen sheets that he won´t keep shredding in his sleep.

column2:

廿: twenty; 20
巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)
column4: Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).
column5: You´re tired from walking the tour at this cavern and there´s no benches to sit down on, so you take a towel and sling it up into a hammock-like seat using the stalagmites. (Big no-no).

column2:
丗: thirty
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)
column4: First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the "number 1" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan´s #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it´s royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king´s kimono.
column5: Beautiful "Miss Housewife Japan" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
氐: name of an ancient tribe
column4: I put all those useless business cards at the bottom of a cave.
column5: In the deepest bottom of this cave complex, spelunkers leave their calling cards to prove they made it all the way.

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
付: adhere; attach; refer to; append
column4: A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see government office (#591)).
column5: Even if a municipality is in a cave, you have to adhere to its policies.

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
隶: extend; give; cast; slave radical (no. 171)
column4: A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).
column5: People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health).

column2:
聿: brush; finally; self; relate; follow; here; fast; writing brush radical (no. 129)

column4: Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it´s just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.
column5: A construction worker´s classic morning. Stretch, brush his teeth, and then start to build.

column2:
彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)
圣: holy; sacred
column4: Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.
column5: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson´s Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in stalk (#715), suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), sutra (#1360).

column2:
彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)

column4: Junior is GOING to RUN the family business one day...
column5: The junior employee is always RUNNING around GOING here and there for his superiors.

column2:

旦: daybreak; dawn; morning

column4: To gain more knowledge of what´s goin on in the world I´m reading column after column of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I´m glued to it till nightbreak.
column5: Imagine fat people......they avoid going outside to exercise and stay glued to their TV set until nightbreak....so of course they gain weight.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
column4: You swear you´ll be in love forever, but invariably there comes a time when your heart is divided.
column5: For this kanji I invariably got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost heart, but decided to stick (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly); 2) fishhook; 3) two drops. Now I invariably get it right.

column2:
今: now
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Someone wishing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.
column5: Remember in the Wizard of Oz when the tin man wished for a heart and the wizard gave him that dinky little clock instead?

column2:
爪: claw; nail; talon

column5: The man is about to enter the ´birdhouse´ (brothel) when he remembers his true love at home, and, following his heart, uses his walking legs to go straight home.

column2:

戈: halberd; arms; festival car; float; tasselled spear radical (no. 62)

column5: The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.

column2:

column5: So there´s this fiesta in downtown Compton. It´s a simple party, but someone invited people from the wrong gangs and the simple fiesta turns into an all-out turf war.

column2:

column4: It´s the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they´re not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.
column5: Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It´s even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!

column2:

column5: What raises mankind above others is the wisdom of an owl, the use of tools, and his hand with an opposable thumb. (compare with reputation (#1939)).

column5: This is a Meiji reformation taskmaster, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a snake in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).

column2:

column2:

column2:

column5: Samurai(s) once received their fee in the form of rice that had been carefully weighed in a measuring cup beforehand.

column2:

column5: The national flag is the banner of a country; stored in a whicker basket at night and taken out to the flagpole in the morning.

column2:

column5: Anyone who´s been to Kyoto doesn´t need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a sunny day in the old capital, and there´s no better scenery.

column5: Do your utmost - seize(take) the day.

column5: The ambitions of kings often result in dead bodies.

column2: 木: tree; wood

column5: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (末) vermilion (朱).

column2: 木: tree; wood
column4: The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.
column5: There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let´s try something ridiculous: The man lived by himself in the wilderness, with no females within miles. So, his only way of relief was to stick his extremity into a small hole in a tree.. The poor guy. Which horizontal stroke is the extremity? The longer one or the shorter one? That, my friends, is up to your own imaginations. I´d prefer not to dwell on that point, myself. ;).

column2:
木: tree; wood
乙: the latter; duplicate; strange; witty; fishhook radical (no. 5)
column4: Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.
column5: Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for "Paper Money" w/ the reading さつ (千円札＝1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 ("trump" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to "hook you in" so to speak.

column2:
木: tree; wood
才: genius; years old; cubic shaku
column4: A TREE GENIUS is a LUMBER jack. Duh.
column5: Just when the were about to turn the last tree into lumber, the Lorax (the tree-genie) jumps out and puts a stop to the whole affair.

column2:
木: tree; wood

column5: Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn´t content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles.

column2:
木: tree; wood
公: public; prince; official; governmental
column4: Following up with the "entering public restrooms" story for the right-hand primitive: public restrooms always reek of pine tree scented disinfectant.
column5: A pine tree is a public tree: they are frequently planted in public squares, in commemoration of the respect Conficius held for them.

column2:

column4: If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.
column5: Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…

column2:

木: tree; wood
column4: The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there´s no room for the students any more.
column5: Students are like young trees. They tend to flourish in the schoolhouse.

column2:
安: relax; cheap; low; quiet; rested; contented; peaceful
木: tree; wood
column4: I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.
column5: If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good plan to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!

column2:
木: tree; wood
毎: every
column4: Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn´t know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree´s genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums.
column5: EVERY Japanese person asks you if you like UMEBOSHI. No I say, I prefer to eat my PLUMS fresh from the TREE.

column2:
木: tree; wood
戒: commandment
column4: The ten commandments were heavy. So to help carry them, Moses made a wooden contraption; the ark of the covenant.
column5: Think of a complex wooden contraption capable of giving you a two-handed fiesta.

column2:
木: tree; wood
亟: fast; quick; sudden
column4: Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.
column5: (modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using decay (#1243). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for decay (#1243)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor.

column2:
木: tree; wood
票: ballot; label; ticket; sign
column4: Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots.
column5: Large wooden signposts are planted on peoples lawns, with the faces of their representatives all saying: "Vote [1] Me!" for the upcoming ballot.

column2:
木: tree; wood
幾: how many; how much; how far; how long; some; several
column4: An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many ´anythings´.
column5: To avoid confusing with contraption (#677), focus on the "ism" of mechanism. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish; mechanism here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable tree (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching abacus that smashes enemies between its giant beads.

column2: 欠: yawn, lack, yawn radical (no. 76)
column4: To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.
column5: When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.

column2:
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
林: grove; forest
止: stop; halt
column4: A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.
column5: A little like a calendar, your CV records your footsteps through time.

column2:
歹: bare bone; bad; wrong; death radical (n. 78)
戔: damage; remain; slight
column4: The remainder of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade).
column5: Throwing all those coins (see coin (#368)) was a really bad idea; people got mad with greed. The only remainders left were the bones of those that was on the float.

column2:
乂: mow; cut grass; subdue
木: tree; wood
殳: pike; windy-again radical (no. 79)
column4: X marks the spot on the tree where the missile hit. No doubt, it was meant to kill us.
column5: I suppose when this kanji was made, it was most effective to kill your enemies with sheafs of wood used as missiles.

column2:

母: mother
column4: If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it´s poison in the stuff you get from her breasts.
column5: You can use silicone implants to to make your breasts "grow up" but if they leak, it's poison.

column2: 氏: clan, clan radical (no. 83)
column4: Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.
column5: The family name is important to me! Drop me from a building, torture me with a fishhook, I´m keeping my one family name. Hook me with a second fishhook, I refuse to change my family name.

column2: 氏: family name; surname; clan
column4: All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.
column5: How many of you know what "vox populi" means?

column2:

column5: Robin Hood holds his rich victim at arrowpoint and kindly requests that he hands over his grains of rice.

column2:

台: pedestal; a stand; counter for machines and vehicles
column4: Build a moat around your pedestal to protect your reign of power.
column5: From his water pedestal Neptune reigns over his Sea Empire.

column2:

去: gone; past; quit; leave; elapse; eliminate; divorce

column5: There already was a system (#418) for butchering cows, a technique (#421) for turning smoke into flowers - why can´t there be a method of about the same relevance for making water gone? Evaporation anyone?

column2:
水: water

column4: Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying.
column5: She stood up to leave the room when her eyes started to water...

column2:

戔: damage; remain; slight
column4: The water can´t be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.
column5: The water isn´t shallow enough to ford (#372). We´ll have to cross by float!

column2:
水: water

column4: This story is quite lascivious, sorry... Now, imagine you are at a 混浴　（こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen (温泉), and you are watching a woman bathe. Just picture the water dripping down her cleavage (that valley in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間.
column5: The mountain man uses the water from the valley to bathe.

column2:
水: water
青: blue; green
column4: Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.
column5: Bottles of water claim to be pure. They´re generally in blue containers, because blue makes you feel like its that much more pure.

column2:
水: water
廿: twenty; 20
column4: Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.
column5: I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I´m afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now.

column2:
水: water
魚: fish
column4: You need WATER and FISH for fishing.
column5: If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water).

column2:
火: fire
丁: street; ward; town; counter for guns, tools, leaves or cakes of something; even number; 4th calendar sign
column4: Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.
column5: A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
一: one; one radical (no.1)
火: fire
column4: When I enter the wooden tub heated by flames in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into nothingness.
column5: In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into nothingness.

column2:
月: month; moon
犬: dog
火: fire
column4: Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = "hotdog". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don´t want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr´s. Thanks!).
column5: There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. (I use hot dog for this primitive (meat of a dog over a cooking fire). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.).

column2:
火: fire

column4: Ah, there´s no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a burning strawman. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen.
column5: Too lofty (#2095)尭 a career choice for the strawman becoming a baker. He was fired soon after starting his first shift. Literally!...

column2:

火: fire
column4: SHINING FLAMES illuminate!
column5: The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we illuminate the night.

column2:
埶: art
火: fire
column4: Heat up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for "atsui" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather).
column5: Just a comment on Erikkusan's story: Although one of the pronunciations of this kanji is "atsui" this isn't the atsui that you feel in Tokyo in August, (which is Frame 1260's "sultry' 暑). This atsui is the one when you touch something hot, like a fry pan. Another reading of this is "netsu," which is the "fever" this fat man may feel after planting the rice seedlings.

column2:
牛: cow
攵: strike; hit; folding chair radical variant (no. 66)
column4: Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to "start breeding, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.
column5: Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don´t differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture.

column2:
牛: cow
寺: Buddhist temple
column4: Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef.
column5: The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred cow relieving itself inside a Buddhist Temple. "Well, isn´t that special".

column2:

column4: If you were to stand up all the products you have accumulated over the course of your entire life on top of one another, the result would probably be as tall as a cliff.
column5: The salesman is standing on the cliff´s edge. "Buy my products!! Buy my products! Or else I´ll take my own life"! Man, that´s selling on pressure.

column2:

column4: I managed to hit the bull´s eye by throwing my white ladle.
column5: A white, bound up, drop in the center is the bull´s eye. (why Heisig had to use "ladle" instead of the original two primitives that make up "ladle" I´ll never understand!).

column2:

目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor

column5: Success (or survival?) method for accelerated juggling course: focus on a few nitroglycerine filled juggling balls flying OVER your eyes ---(I have trouble with this few primitive that can be anywhere in a kanji. To build in its location in the story is important somehow).

column2:

column5: When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager.

column2:

column5: In western political elections (US), peoples ballots will often depend on religion and at which altar the prospective president prays.

Some settling of contents may have occurred." well they only say that because they don´t want to be blamed by people getting really disappointed after they see what a small volume of cereal the box really contains.

column2:

Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off.
column5: Spiderman and a fan have a competition to see who can tie up the most enemies fastest. Spidey´s using his webs and the fan is using an aerosol can of silly string. So far they are tied.

column4: Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can´t see: they both crash all the time.
column5: I used to hate birds.They´re loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a pegasus. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to look up. I saw it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.

column5: The words of the devil incite rumours and false explanations.

column5: Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It´s good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy´s "War and Peace" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you´d very quickly run out of fruit).

column5: An animal with huge ears like a rabbit, and a body fat like a pig... ¡An ELEPHANT! For the "phenomenon" connotation you could use Dumbo, or Joseph Merrick (the "elephant man")

column4: Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don´t confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004).
column5: This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there´s actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells.

column5: As a prize for being the 1,000,000th person to use the restaurant´s outhouse, I got all the clams I could eat.

This Kanji is the "Union" in Soviet Union and the "United" of United Nations (the countries that "go along with each other" at least some of the time).

Members of Blue-man group jump into the wrestling ring of contenders for tag-team wrestling. Though the other contenders are screaming, the blue men never say anything - they are a very quiet bunch, that Blue-man group. Primitive order: blue man group's first and main characteristic is being blue and quiet; only later did they decide to become wrestling contenders.

人: person
