column4: It is always Mr. T´s responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone´s luggage because he´s so strong.
column5: In pregnancy (#507), the woman was the porter for the first nine months. Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it. Can´t you just see him here as the new porter, wearing a harness with a his little dude (who already has a little matching mohawk)?

column2:
人: person
以: by means of; because; in view of; compared with
column4: Mr. T finds that living by means of dragging a plow is similar to slavery.
column5: A Mr T impersonator is becoming similarer (more like) by means of plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals.

column2:
人: person
小: little; small
column4: You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.
column5: This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol ">" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means "two much" (more than 2) or "two little". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!).

column2:
人: person
襾: cover; place on top of; west radical variant (no. 146)
column4: In the West, people have no value. Only money is important.
column5: What might it mean for a person in the old west to be of value? Their face is on a "Wanted!" poster, of course. Imagine the reward...

column2:
人: person
呆: be amazed; disgusted; shocked
column4: Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying "I pitty da foo who don´t protect the trees!".
column5: Tip: Heisig later combines mouth and tree into 呆 dumbfounded (#2181). Story: Your person (Mr. T. or whoever) is dumbfounded when told to protect the bad guys rather than fight them.

column2:
攸: relaxed; at ease; place
彡: three; hair ornament; short hair or fur radical (no. 59)
column4: Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick.
column5: You may not have known it, but Mr. T is into discispline. Not just self discipline, in order to get into shape, but what he really likes is when the Task master spanks him with her walking stick. Don´t tell Mr. T I told you. I pity da fool, and da fool would be me!!!

column2:
人: person
表: surface; table; chart; diagram
column4: Superficial people (ie those who are only concerned about the surface) are obsessed with expensive bags.
column5: Do you know why every person in Japan has a Louis Vuitton bag? After the 1985 JAL air crash that killed 520 people (the world´s worst). An image on tv of the crash showed Louis Vuitton bags (whose LV logo covered surface was somehow impervious) litering the crash site. From that point on they stuck in Japanese people´s mind´s as durable and high quality. (True story).

column2:
人: person
固: harden; set; clot; curdle
column4: This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : "Middle English, single, indivisible". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he´s had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. "I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units.".
column5: Mr. T insists that people be individual. He appears on television, saying, "Being an individual is hard! But you gotta do it! Harden yourself, and be individual!".

column2:
人: person
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
用: utilize; business; service; use; employ
column4: Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.
column5: An RPG where you´re using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.

column2:
人: person
象: elephant; pattern after; imitate; image; shape; sign (of the times)
column4: Statues of people are made the same size as statues of elephants.
column5: One of the most famous statues is of course the Statue of Liberty, which is known for the first thing a person sees when coming into New York. However, did you know that the first thing a person used to see (between the years of 1885 to 1896) was actually a huge elephant statue on Coney Island? It's true too... ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island - search Coney Island Elephant).

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)

column4: The king has eaten too much and has to get a new belt again. See his fat rolls hanging over?
column5: This is a belt with a non-adjustable jeweled buckle. Everytime you go back to the leathersmith telling him to move the buckle because you´ve packed on a few pounds (but that this is the last time!), he says "Again?!? Weren´t you just here last month?".

column2:

column4: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.
column5: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry. This gives the government a chance to censor the news: they cut up unwanted stories with a sabre. Therefore, only state-approved stories are published.

column2:

column5: It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.

column2:

column5: Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn´t have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he´s part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, "Moo!".

column2:

column5: In Japan, the JR railway ju-hachi-kippu seasonal discount ticket can be cut into quarters with a dagger and shared with your friends. (its actually sort-of true).

column2:

column5: So many video games have a "boss" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your halberd to beat the taskmaster with the huge, bulging muscles.

column5: I can eat nails.

column4: The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation.
column5: During the German occupation, this Nazi officer´s occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : "the occupation´s spine schools"). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also "barracks; camp; encapment". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#824) and employ (#1083). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 "detention barracks".

column2:

column5: Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the cause is that you kept the dog pent in the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.

column2:

column4: When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you´re well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.
column5: A pent-in group will naturally be more cohesive, or "glued together.".

column2:
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)

column4: The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.
column5: For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives.

column2:
人: person
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: Genie in the bottle does exist but you need to dig deep into the soil to find one.
column5: You wipe the soil from the bottle, only to have a genie float out above you, saying: ´I am the genie in a bottle, what is your wish?´ So now you know that they do exist.

column2:

column5: To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it.

column2:

column2:

column5: The long awaited report, 'Maximising Male Happiness In The Workplace' concluded that making bikinis, with only a stamp sized piece of cloth covering the crotch, compulsory for attractive female staff, was the most cost-effective means of achieving this aim.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
竟: end; finally
column4: In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger.
column5: This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the boundary of your land and theirs. When they approach the boundary, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn´t any better than their own and they head back home.

column2:

column5: (I´m really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. "Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!".

column2:

column5: The LADY of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who´s a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?).

column5: Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.

column5: In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.

column5: It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. set (#1064).

column5: This FLAG BELONGS to the terror group called the GNATS, oftern seen wearing explosive BELTS. My opinion is they all BELONG in jail.

column2: 巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)

column5: The first rule of the Hitch-Hiker´s Guide to the Universe is "DON´T PANIC!" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the linen sort.

column2:

column5: Maestro is such as expert, he can conduct even with a towel hanging from the ceiling in front of him.

column2:

column5: In the outhouse toilet you´d usually hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it´s already gone, which is usually the case, simply use the towel.

column2:

column5: By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.

column2:

column4: The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.
column5: Rename the "beforehand" part to be glove (because you have to wear gloves beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable cave. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the preface. But he can´t get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on gloves, shivering, but still unable to start his preface.

column2:

column5: This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, grace is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a graceful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.

column4: This guy has an attitude problem – lots of ability, but his heart´s not in it.
column5: Having a good attitude means believing in your heart that you have the ability to do anything - like memorizing more than 2000 kanji, for example.

column4: It took him awhile, but Data finally got ACCUSTOMED to his nipple/breast piercings. They were constantly rubbing up against his shirt and his heart-shaped locket. Picture Data, shirtless, squeezing his nipples in front of Picard and saying "Yes, at first they were a bit shelly, but I´ve grown quite ACCUSTOMED to them". That last bit should do it for you.
column5: Some hardcore monks have a state of mind that has become accustomed to their self-torture through piercing themselves.

column5: I bet you all know the Maneki Neko, or beckoning cat, who with its raised fingers tries to seduce all good things (success, happiness and harmony) to its owner.

column5: CHIKAN!! These are the perverts who use their fingers to touch standing women on crowded trains.

column2:

column5: I tried to propose to my girlfriend, but the ring was too small to fit her finger. Instead of saying yes, she just uttered an annoyed sigh. So I rushed to the jeweler where he made it bigger. But now it was too big, so I rushed back to make it smaller. This spiel kept going on until the ring was finally just so. Her eyes lit up and she said yes.

column5: A special branch of the military called the Needle Crotch Unit. Their only weapon is the needle embedded in their crotches, and they´re quite adept at using them.

column5: Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there.

column5: Indiana Jones is an enemy of taskmasters in search of antique artifacts.

column5: When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.

column2:

column2:

column4: The sun is not an easy place to get to.

column5: Having spent all day stringing together grains of rice he suddenly had an outburst, "I can take it any longer!".

column2:

column5: Don´t confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping twigs. A twig is always the kind of wood that snaps when the hunter´s walking legs just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter´s presence.

column2:
木: tree; wood

column4: The tree´s primary branch is known as the bough.
column5: Differentiate between BOUGH and branch (#711): ´branch´ is smaller, and can also refer to the branch of a store (支店), which has nothing to do with a tree. But a BOUGH is a main part of a tree, perhaps where the trunk splits into several large boughs, and so it logically utilizes the 木 radical.

column2:

column5: The result of the inverstigation of the missing Trees? Why, most of them had become shelfs!

column2:
木: tree; wood

column5: A man measures his own status by the size of his woody...and compares it to each one he sees.

column2:
木: tree; wood

女: woman; female

column5: The tree in Japan that represents both wisdom (the owl) and femininity (the woman). This is a sakura (さくら), or cherry tree.

column2:

"He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!" The autopsy examination revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case.
column5: Don´t confuse with exam (#1278), test (#354), evaluate (#1487). Think of examination as a doctor´s examination. You´re having problems getting wood in bed. You go in for a doctor´s examination. The doctor shoves an icepick into your manhood as part of the examination.

column2:
木: tree; wood
冓: put together; inner palace
column4: Ideal posture is standing tall like a tree and having a V shape like a funnel
column5: I fell out of a tree and broke my neck. So they put one of those white funnels around my neck to correct my posture.

column2:

column2: 匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)

(In order to remember that the drop is at the top, think that the drop must come from the topmost water in order for its effects to be true).

column2:

column5: I kept confusing this with stream. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial river. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow River in China (黄河), and the other is the Milky Way (銀河). Now I either think of the Little Engine that could dragging a bunch of stuff down a river in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way.

column2:

column5: I imagined some kind of liquid (water) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?

column2:

column2:

column2:

column5: (rgravina) To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her Spiderman underwear (to remember the position of thread), even when she went into the water.

column2:
巛: curving river radical (no.47)
火: fire

column2:

column4: Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn´t be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true.
column5: Nazi propaganda. Picture the printing blocks producing very one-sided (Aryan), anti-Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town.

column2:

column2:

column2:
石: stone

column2: 示: altar, display (radical no. 113)

column5: I´ll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!, she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE.

column2:

column4: The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.
column5: The urns of ancestors are kept on shelves next to the altar.

column2:

示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
column4: Similar to radical tyro´s story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably "no smoking" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).
column5: Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol "for sacremental purposes" and share it with his kin (きん).

column2:

column5: Many people are making the shift from white to whole wheat bread.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)

column4: The extent to which some people will go to create ´wheat displays´, or as some call them ´crop circles´, is truly amazing.
column5: The wheat crop has come in, and the mouth of the king is gobbling it all up. Everyone is waiting to see... to what extent will the king manage to eat it this year?

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)

column4: Nobody likes the tax man, so here it is only fitting that the person who comes over to take some of your wheat is depicted here as a devil. Keep in mind that in feudal societies there was no kind of money to speak of, so taxes were paid by serfs in wheat to the devils who came over to keep them poor.
column5: This is an easy one. Taxes is like the devil taking away your hard earned wheat.

column2:

column5: A bamboo fabrication is a mediocre substitute for wood.

column2:

column5: "Uh, why is your rice blue?" "It's been refined! And by 'refined' I mean it's been in the back of my fridge for a few months.".

column2:
三: three
糸: thread

column2:

column2:

column2:

糸: thread

I prefer to think of the manga compilations as the individual comics (serials from the anthologies) bound together with a coarse thread down the spine, produced quickly and put on the market. Good way to recycle those pulpy manga, and since when has the consumer not gotten screwed in Japan? ;-).

column2:

When Neo asks to learn this ability the child replies, " Remember the truth Neo, there is no spoon." Neo Proceeds to the kitchen pondering these words of wisdom. The Child smiles mischeviously and pulls a second spoon hidden up his sleeve in the crook of his elbow. "That´s right Neo," the child laughs, "there is no spoon...there are two spoons!".

One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty.

Note : there will also be a kanji for "rowboat" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for "rowboat" has a generic meaning of "a small boat". In any case, the kanji for "rowboat" will not appear as a primitive in the book.

column5: I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and proclaim it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. Imagine the SPAN of hours spent under a ROOF practising that! It must surely be worse than trying to get through Heisigs RTK - count yourself lucky.

column2:

Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...
column5: How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.

column4: A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting groped by perverts on the train. The fingers of course, a crown (her too short skirt) and her legs below (which to be honest are pretty thick like tree trunks).
column5: Note: The combination "crown +human legs" appears seven times in Heisig. In four cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) the crown is above the human legs, and in the other three cases (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. The naming is inconsistent, so I call the first pattern "Miss World" (who is wearing a crown she won due to her attractive human legs) and the second "garter" (one human leg passes through the crown and wears it as a garter).

column2:

column4: In mathematics, a conjecture is a mathematical statement which has been proposed as a true statement, but which no one has yet been able to prove or disprove. Have you heard of the Finger-Turkey conjecture ? It states that if turkeys had fingers, they would be able to count. Be sure to imagine a turkey with fingers at the tip of its wings, counting from one to ten.
column5: In the midst of conjecture on whether it was done or not, mom stuck her fingers in the turkey to check.

column5: Luke skywalker points his fingers and uses the force to maneuver the goods through the tree branches and up over the tree.

column2:

Their formation is so humongous they block the warmth for a good 10 minutes while they pass over. Mnemonic for the migrating ducks primitive : the migrating ducks stick together like the best of friends, flying together as one (fifth stroke), they are not easy prey for the great eagles / vultures.

column2:

column5: Perhaps the most common appearance of this kanji is in the word 温泉 (おんせん, onsen), a Japanese hot spring. The kanji is an excellent image of someone enjoying a Japanese hot spring: a little white towel on top, water below. (This helps keep all associations: spring, little and onsen).

(thanks Elktapestry).

You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in).

column2:

column5: Marge´s dream: to exchange Homer for another husband for just one day.

column2:
貝: shellfish
曽: formerly; once; before; ever; never; ex-
column4: Presents represent money that was formerly yours.
column5: Imagine if the number of presents you get increases with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one shell as a present, but the next year it increases to two shells as presents, and so on, increasing and increasing so by the time you´re elderly, the number of shells you´ll get as presents will have increased to an awful lot of presents. GOT IT YET? PRESENTS = SHELLS + INCREASE.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
溥: far and wide
column4: A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.
column5: Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as:: dilute (#227), fall (#299), clan (#1912), and seaweed (#2035).... (落 薄 藩 藻) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like seaweed or watering can) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like Sino 満 and Full 満, where the water primitive is larger than the flower primitive.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
米: rice; USA; metre
大: large; big
column4: In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It´s very dangerous, so they´ve trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he´s adding more drops of rice as necessary.
column5: 奥さん　（おくさん) is a common way to say "wife". In the innermost core of the house, the bored pent up housewife drops her chores and consumes so much rice she becomes a very large housewife.

column2:
言: say
吉: good luck; joy; congratulations
column4: WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.
column5: Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!

column2:
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: Crotch to crotch is how many pairs spend their private time together. . .
column5: The animals boarding Noah´s Ark all came in pairs – but Noah had to carefully check the two crotches in each pair to ensure that the animals were of different sexes and thus able to further their species after the flood.

column2:
朿: thorn
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS.
column5: The BELT TREE has THORNS like SABERS.

column2:
辟: false; punish; crime; law
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
column5: Primitive for Ketchup: When the taste is too spicy your mouth has basically given up trying to handle it ..or in other words raised the white flag of surrender. But unlike war , putting Ketchup on it will usually solve the problem. Wall(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
小: small, insignificant
凶: villain; evil; bad luck; disaster
column4: When I am in trouble, my state of mind is on two sides: 1. The wise part of me (owl) 2. The villain part of me (villain) Think of the devil and the angel on your shoulders in a troubled situation.
column5: The owl villain is the one that troubles me most of all the super-villains. He´s just so smart... you never know what he´ll do! Definitely enough to put you in a troubled state of mind.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
亡: deceased; the late; dying; perish
巛: curving river radical (no.47)
column4: After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.
column5: Laying waste is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like flowers, more like deceased flowers, and it´s flushed down into a stream of sewage. Use "waste" to avoid destroy (#365) demolition (#400).

column2:
石: stone
更: grow late; night watch; sit up late; of course; renew; renovate; again; more and more; further
column4: A stiff drink on the ROCKs after it GROWS LATE is a way to unwind after a long day...
column5: Stones are so stiff that even if you spent all day straining trying to change their shape, it would grow late far before you ever accomplished your task.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
column4: You can´t bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.
column5: I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.

column2:
代: substitute; change; convert; replace; period; age; counter for decades of ages, eras, etc.; generation; charge; rate; fee
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
column4: A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.
column5: A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 "bag", and although the later really refers to a "straw sack", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a "plastic bag" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book).

column2:
圭: square jewel; corner; angle; edge
寸: measurement; foot/10
column4: The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.
column5: A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.

column2:
臣: retainer; subject
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
貝: shellfish
column4: An intelligent man is neither slave to his crotch nor to money. But an intelligent slave will know how to use his/her crotch to make money.
column5: Every intelligent man is a slave to two things, his: 1) crotch, and 2) money.

column2:
肉: meat
宛: address; just like; fortunately
column4: Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don´t forget it.
column5: In Iraq people are having their addresses tattooed on their bodies, usually their arms, so they can be identified if they are killed. (true story).

column2:
車: car
交: mingle; mixing; association; coming & going
column4: The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles.
column5: Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets.

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
木: tree; wood
column4: The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.
column5: (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a bed.

column2:
矛: halberd; arms; festival float
木: tree; wood
column4: [tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I´ll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree...
column5: Use a halberd to tenderize a tree: halberds can chop, poke, and slash, so it´s all good!

column2:
尸: corpse; remains; flag radical (no. 44)
共: together; both; neither; all; and; alike; with
殳: pike; windy-again radical (no. 79)
column4: Mr. President in his palace, ordering missiles to be fired at a harmless enemy in order to unite us together under the flag.
column5: Mr. President! We all stand here together under a national flag. One thing is certain: we´ll never give in. We are launching nuclear missiles now to implement mutually assured destruction protocol.

column2:
水: water
農: agriculture; farmers
column4: The agriculture of Florida is concentrated on making concentrated orange juice. Just add water! Imagine a can of FCOJ, dumping it into a pitcher and adding water.
column5: Concentrated water is going to revolutionize the agriculture! Just add water... oh wait...

column2:
戸: door; counter for houses; door radical (no. 63)
月: month; moon
column4: The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don´t ever try this. Use your foot).
column5: The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm´s story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below.

column2:
雨: rain
令: orders; ancient laws; command; decree
column4: The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.
column5: Despite the rain, the zero pilot flies on. He has kamikaze orders.

column2:
水: water
白: white
column4: Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.
column5: When I go to an OVERNIGHT party, all I need is a bit of water and some of that hard white. (crack). (not really, but come on. much easier to recall than white sheets).

column2: 廿: twenty; 20
column4: Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny.
column5: Girls are kinda sweet and sexy until they reach their twenties. So 20 minus ONE.

column2:
手: hand
帚: broom
column4: Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.
column5: FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily SWEEP the floor.

column2:
手: hand
屈: yield; bend; flinch; submit
column4: If you dig with your fingers hard enough, soil eventually yields.
column5: When you dig, you´d better hope that whatever you´re digging into yields to your fingers. If not, you´re bound to lose some nails.

column2:
車: car
欠: lack; gap; fail; yawning radical (no. 76)
column4: Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness.
column5: If your car has really soft seats, you may start yawning and eventually fall asleep at the wheel (imagine that this seat is a huge soft beanbag that nearly swallows the driver, and it will be easier to remember).

column2:
水: water
冘: to move on; doubtful
column4: (thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn´t have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend´s schemes.
column5: This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling "Eureka! Eureka!" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29.

column2:
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)
東: east
column4: Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!
column5: The ice will stay frozen until the sun is visible through the trees.

column2:
亦: also; again
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: The romance between Snow White and Prince Charming started when Snow White took a bite of poison apple and her heart stopped.
column5: A childhood romance: a boy takes a red apple to school to try to win the heart of his beloved.

column2:
交: mingle; mixing; association; coming & going
邑: village; rural community; right village radical (no. 163)
column4: The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the outskirts of town, just past the city walls.
column5: The city walls mark the outskirts of the inner city, where it begins to mingle with the suburbs.

column2:
肉: meat
要: need; main point; essence; pivot; key to
column4: If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It´s the part of the body that needs massaging.
column5: To the puritans reading this site - please stop reporting stories that have anything to do with sex! Although (as wrightak said) this kanji really refers to the hips, Heisig clearly chose the keyword ´loins´ because it was anatomically close enough, and the primitives lent themselves to an easy-to-remember story. Just because you´re all sexually repressed doesn´t mean other people won´t benefit from a story such as "the part of the body people need more than any other are the loins".

column2:
足: leg; foot; be sufficient; counter for pairs of footwear
甬: road with walls on both sides
column4: The winner of the long jump competition was disqualified when they found he used a pogo stick tied to his leg to jump further.
column5: The high jumper has his wooden leg fitted with a pogo stick, and can now jump even higher. (See my note at traffic (#1408) for pogo stick). EDIT (2 years later): Keyword "jump" leads to confusion later on (see cjon256´s post), "Dancing" would be better (but be sure to keep it distinct from dance (#1774)). New Story: I was no good at dancing due to my wooden leg... until I had it fitted with a pogo stick!

column2:
王: king; rule; magnate
人: person
彡: three; hair ornament; short hair or fur radical (no. 59)
column4: It's rare to see the king carrying his own parasol - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for umbrella + shape = parasol and to Peppi for the story idea).
column5: Tip: umbrella + shape : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "parasol" (because it is the same shape as an umbrella). REF: rare (FRAME 1723) , check-up (#1724), measles (#2574), fallible (#2720).

column2:
犬: dog
夾: insert between
column4: A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular.
column5: In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS.

column2:
口: mouth
契: pledge; promise; vow
column4: This means eat/drink/smoke. Maybe you make a pledge to stop gutsing/binging/puffing, but your own mouth is tempting you to put something in it.
column5: I make my mouth pledge to consume less.

column2:
水: water
容: contain; form; looks
column4: Think of what happens when the snow on top of the mountains melts: it turns into water and flows down onto the rooftops of all the houses in the valley below.
column5: [melt; dissolve; thaw] An ice cube is melting, loosing the water it contained.

column2:
水: water
戻: re-; return; revert; resume; restore; go backwards
column4: I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.
column5: Tears are watery (water + re).

column2:
匚: box-on-side enclosure radical (no. 22)
儿: legs radical (no. 10)
column4: This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL´S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He´s probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).
column5: Imagine a magician doing that trick where he puts his assistant in a box and proceeds to saw her in half. Don’t the human legs sticking horizontally out of the box remind you of an equal sign?

column2:
金: gold
兌: exchange
column4: Pointed is the metal devil´s pitchfork.
column5: The Horny teenager who worked part time at a gold smelting plant always had uncontrollable errections that pointed out all the time, this is not a good thing to have when you work in a gold smelting plant, surely he will one day end up with a Goldmember!

column2:
水: water
余: too much; myself; surplus; other; remainder
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.
column5: A true artisan mixes his own paint from water and soils on a scale in careful proportions.

column2:
車: car
干: dry; parch
column4: Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else.
column5: Small flats (garages) for cars help keeping them dry.

column2:
口: mouth
丩: to join or connect the vine
column4: There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.
column5: You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to SHOUT lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the shouts are 4 letter words.

column2:
十: ten
早: early; fast
乞: beg; invite; ask
column4: During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief.
column5: Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the drought. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a drought.

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
斤: axe; 1.32 lb; catty; counter for loaves of bread; axe radical (no. 69)
column4: Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe.
column5: A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the altar, his battle axe at the ready.

column2:
水: water
干: dry; parch
column4: The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off.
column5: When you sweat your clothes become soaked with water, prompting you to hang them to dry on a clothesline.

column2:
水: water
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don´t wring them damp first they will take days to dry!
column5: If your things are damp, lay them up in a row under the sun and let the water evaporate. (thx Raichu)...

column2:
口: mouth
关: frontier pass; close; relation
column4: The mouth of the wooly mammoth was so big and furry that plants would actually grow and blossom there.
column5: From the mouth of the hell hound blossoms, not flowers, but evil spawns of DOOOOOOM.

column2:
刀: sword; saber; knife
口: mouth
column4: A man is easily seduced by a mouth to his "sword.".
column5: To seduce is to make a sword of one´s mouth.

column2:
肉: meat
旨: delicious; relish; show a liking for; purport; will; clever; expert
column4: Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious.
column5: Fat is the most delicious part of the flesh. (Note this refers to physical fat, not the concept of obesity obese (#494)).

column2:
肉: meat
几: table; table enclosure; table or windy radical (no. 16)
column4: When you expose your flesh to the wind it gets textured: goosebumps!
column5: The moon´s lack of wind preserves its texture.

column2:
金: gold
屯: barracks; police station; camp
column4: The metal hook is too dull to even pierce an earthworm....
column5: From the earthworm´s perspective, it most be pretty dull when you are put in a metal bowl, just waiting for being put on the hook on the fishing trip the next day.

column2:
水: water
尼: nun
column4: TV gets weirder and weirder... Now they´re doing mud wrestling shows with nuns splashing around in the water. What will they think of next?
column5: Water monks live in a den, but water nuns live in the MUD.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
禺: long-tailed monkey
column4: If you behave badly at THE PINNACLE, JIMINY CRICKET will send you to sit in the corner.
column5: Oh how the pious fall from their lofty pinnacles! Jiminy Cricket now deals drugs on the street corner.

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
十: ten
column4: Eating spicy food makes you stand up ten times faster than usual, ´cause you just need to get something to drink!
column5: Eating spicy food makes you stand up as if you had sat on a needle.

column2:
麻: hemp; flax
石: stone
column4: If you grind the hemp you are bound to get stoned quicker.
column5: You must GRIND the HEMP collected in the grove by your cave on solid STONE to make the best ropes.

column2:
女: woman; female
生: life; genuine; birth
column4: When women marry, they adopt the surname of their husband, signifiying the start of a new life together. (adapted from gorgon).
column5: Woman change their surname when they "start their new life".

column2:
竹: bamboo
同: same; agree; equal
column4: Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS. Should the story be more complicated?
column5: Fully-grown bamboo consists of a number of cylinder-like sections, all exactly the same.

column2:
米: rice; USA; metre
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
column4: A sage is using rice to fill up a vase, but as an exercise in patience, he´s doing it grain by grain.
column5: There´s a contest...whoever guesses the number of grains of rice in a vase wins.

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
且: moreover; also; furthermore
column4: The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.
column5: Making tatami mats from rice field waste was Japan´s crowning achievement, but for some reason other countries just shelved the idea.

column2:
虍: tiger spots; mottled; tiger or tiger crown radical (no. 141)
胃: stomach; paunch; crop; craw
column4: Ending up in a tiger´s stomach is not good for your skin, as it´s full of stomach acids.
column5: They say, "there's more than one way to skin a cat", but if you try to skin a tiger you might end up in its stomach.

column2:
水: water
羽: feathers; counter for birds, rabbits
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: At the laundry you stuff your large futon (made from turkey feathers) in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the water spurting out the side.
column5: When turkeys do the laundry, they put their feathers in water (they don´t have clothes).

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
荅: adzuki beans; thick
column4: In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.
column5: Pictograph-o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of soil on the left, and a little concrete pagoda in the front with flowers behind it. (To my eye, the fit looks a lot like a little pagoda anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though...).

column2:
水: water
弗: dollar
column4: Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes).
column5: When his daughter used a lot of water for her shower, the father could practically see the dollar signs, so he was seething with anger.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
果: fruit; reward; carry out; achieve; complete; end; finish; succeed
column4: This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit.
column5: Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.

column2:
巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)
冒: risk; face; defy; dare; damage; assume (a name)
column4: If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports.
column5: Originally the first cap was a turban which was a towel wrapped around the head to keep the sun out of the eyes.

column2:
木: tree; wood
古: old
column4: A tree withers away as it gets old.
column5: When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).

column2:
水: water
京: capital; 10**16
column4: When you´re a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing.
column5: The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so refreshing!

column2: 舟: boat, boat radical (no. 137)
column4: I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.
column5: Cinnabar (丹) colored boat, the extra drop signifying that the paint hasn´t dried yet. The stick represents the oars.

column2:
竹: bamboo
付: adhere; attach; refer to; append
column4: I dropped my token down the drain, so I used a piece of bamboo with chewing gum on the end to retrieve it.
column5: At the arcade, Mr. T adheres a bamboo rod to his token so that he can put it in the machine and pull it out repeatedly.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
曽: formerly; once; before; ever; never; ex-
column4: Like the saying goes, Hate just begets Hate. A state of mind that just increases and increases until it explodes.
column5: Data´s one true emotion is hate for Prince´s music. (Image: Data hunched over hands to his ears and screaming while Picard bobs to Purple Rain).

column2:
止: stop; halt
月: month; moon
column4: A secret agreement between a covert gov´t agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology.
column5: NASA and Armstrong made an agreement: They´d never tell anyone that no-one actually stepped foot on the moon.

column2:
火: fire
品: goods; refinement; dignity; article; counter for meal courses
木: tree; wood
column4: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (FRAME 215) , maneuver (#671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: It´s been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire.
column5: The parchment says you need fire to make goods from trees.

column2:
玄: mysterious; occultness
田: rice field; rice paddy
column4: The livestock are disappearing! I´ve placed Gandalf over the rice field to protect them.
column5: This mysterious rice field grows not only rice, but livestock too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
方: direction; person; alternative
column4: Little boys always head in the direction of mud and dirt.
column5: Boys thoughts often head in dirty directions.

column2:
手: hand
夾: insert between
column4: 挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip..
column5: Fingers sandwiched between a pair of scissors. Don´t move or else!

column5: Sirens in the swamp play eerie music on their shakuhachi flutes to lure you in - you follow the enchanting music then its too late as you get trapped in the swamp!

column5: Aiding and abetting: You are accuse of abetting a drug dealer, by smuggling drugs in migrating ducks. Of course, this means you have to stick your fingers in their mouths.

column2:

column4: Under their banner, volunteers are requesting alms for scorpion sting victims.
column5: ALMS for the poor cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl.

column2:

column2:
魚: fish

column4: The freshest fish is caught in the middle of the night while most people are "counting sheep." (If you´ve ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).
column5: This one´s easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, "F", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, "SH", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.

column2:
臣: retainer; subject

column5: The slaves are reclining on the floor when the overseer comes in. They tell him "We´re not goofing off, a dish fell and broke and we´re cleaning it off the floor".

column2:

column4: At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. ("I can´t believe what I´m hearing!" you say).
column5: In the courthouse the judge decides your hearing with a roll of the dice.

column2:

column4: I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.

column5: You're out hiking looking at the SCENERY, suddenly out of the corner of your vision you see a large SHADOW's indistinct SHAPE... could it be a grizzly? (cmp shade (#1592)).

column2:

column4: Your car has missles?! That beats mine, hands down.
column5: Think 3 methods of attack all combined into 1 kanji: 1. Vehicle to transport troops 2. Once troops have disembarked they have their missiles 3. If they run out of missiles they resort to hand to hand combat to beat the enemy.

column2:

column4: Mr T´s assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - "Stay on my left, foo!".
column5: On your right is your "right-hand man" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything...

column2:

亥: sign of the hog; 9-11PM; twelfth sign of the Chinese zodiac
column4: In the nucleus of the acorn, all the DNA is stored -- the building blocks for a new tree.
column5: The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.

column2:
鬲: tripod
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: I have created the element "old camera" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject´s point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air.
column5: I´ve seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It´s a venus flytrap, btw).

column2:
水: water
歩: walk; counter for steps
column4: The new Ford Jesus. It can do everything except WALK on WATER.
column5: A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.

column2:

column4: People´s voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they´re from by how they talk.
column5: My hometown is a ghost town, any sounds echoes and echoes.

column2:
言: say
青: blue; green
column4: People who try to solicit you to buy things come up to you and just start taking out of the blue
column5: That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he´s blue in the face. There´s a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say "No Soliciting".

column2:
工: craft; construction; katakana e radical (no. 48)
攵: strike; hit; folding chair radical variant (no. 66)
column4: Aggression is the craft of a good dominatrix.
column5: AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.

column2:
山: mountain
奇: strange; strangeness; curiosity
column4: This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with mountain in place of soil. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives stone and strange. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which promontory is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names.
column5: A promontory is a small, strange mountain that juts out into the sea.

column2:
叔: uncle; youth
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: Creepy uncle volunteers as gymnastics coach so he can eye the team from below.
column5: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when COACHing...

column2:
人: person
崔: cliff; bluff; precipice
column4: And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling Mountain Turkeys. "I pity da foo who don´t have a Mr. T grill!".
column5: Mister T sponsors a meeting in the mountains (he´s an hermit), talking over a megaphone “I pity da foo who does not come to my event !”. The old turkey comes, and Mister T catches it and cooks it for dinner, muahaha.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: I like to think of this as a fist with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug reaches out to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you.
column5: Reach out and fist someone (Do you see the person primitive?).

column2:
离: rare beast; strange; elegant
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: I´ve finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I´m about to fight him. But what´s this? He´s suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!
column5: The left side isn't too hard---a top-hatted villain whose villainy involves belts around elbows? Clearly he's a drug dealer. And the best way to detach yourself from the drug dealer's influence is to go cold turkey.

column2:
手: hand

column5: >_< Don´t you hate when your aunt (who is an antique) PINCHES your cheeks with her antique fingers?

column2:

column5: If you want to increase your fiber intake, just leave on those threads that are used to sew up the stuffed turkey and eat them too.

column5: The traditional New Year´s baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a rice field. They stick sparklers in the ground for the bases so they can be seen, and to be more festive.

column2:

column5: It's easier if you think of the USA as the HOME COUNTRY. To the northern border you have it protected by BUSHES, while to south you have it protected by CITY WALLS (or a 800 mile long fence).

column2:

column5: Apart from meaning DISPATCH, this kanji can mean "to give (to someone lower than you)," "to do," and to even "have intercourse." STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to DISPATCH some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO´S baton? You don´t wanna know...

column2:

column2:

column2:
人: person
大: large; big
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
小: little; small
column4: A colleague implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your colleague helps you to erect your pup tent during a company outing. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as companion (#19), friend (#704), consort (#1203) and comrade (#1637). That is why I chose to have the person element pictured as someone (the colleague in this case) helping with the work of building the pup tent.
column5: Mr. T began working in a japanese compagny. As he sees that his colleague accept to do some extra work during the week-end and even sleep at the office, he says to them: "I pity da fool who work during week-end! You might as well install a pup tent in the office and forget about your home".

column5: So, we´ve walked on the moon, but it´s going to take a pirate with a wooden leg, with a huge supply of cooling water to land on the sun and take that "one small step for a man".

column5: Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.

column2:

column5: Mr. T was briefly a rapper, that is an M.C., that is a master of CEREMONIES (the origin of the phrase). But he sang only RIGHTEOUS songs, no cursing or anything like that. (all true: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_rBidCkJxo ).

column2:

米: rice; USA; metre
column4: A poor chinese fisherman could expect to inherit: the thread for his pole, a hook for catching something to eat, and some rice to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006).
column5: Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it´s all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. (thanks Nukemarine).

column2:

But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.
column5: Food fight! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue.

column5: During the interment ceremony, the grandchildren placed flowers over the dead body while the widow sat praying with two hands.

column2:

column4: You can try and evade them, but they´ll ketchup with you on the road... Sorry, couldn´t resist it.
column5: In order to evade the bear, you lie down on the road, put ketchup on yourself, and play dead.

column5: In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying "Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!".

column5: When you start down the road of cocaine, you´re sure to feel some pretty bad URGEs soon.

column5: The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to beguile women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts.

column2:

column4: Sam and Frodo were steadfast companions even as Mount Doom crumbled above them.
column5: September 11. [lol it also has 11 strokes], whoever reported this story is a loser, get alife. This is the best story on the website.

column2:
耳: ear
十: ten
网: net; net or net crown radical (no. 122)
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: I promise to use my ear to do nothing but listen ... stick a needle in my eye, cross my heart and hope to die! (Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct).
column5: Listening to others is different from hearing [1626] with the ear. One must allow the words to pierce through the eyes (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the heart...a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, "You´re not listening to me, are you?" He replies, "I heard every word you said. You said..." “Yes, but you´re not listening.".

column2:

column5: Before you undress I should warn you -- the sight of flesh brings out the devil in me.

column5: If you are afflicted with severe heartburn, eating a spicy shish kebab will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your heart.

column2:
糸: thread
帝: sovereign; the emperor; god; creator
column4: The sovereign appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a thread around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn´t like, she starts pulling the thread and tightens it around his throat.
column5: (astridtops) Spiderman managed to get behind the sovereign. (pick your favourite nowadays country ruler who isn´t doing a good job). Spidey has tightend a web around the sovereing´s throat. As long as the sovereign says what spidey whispers, he will be fine. Sovereign yelping : ´ we will draw are troops back! and we will spend more money on healthcare, schools and less on wars!´ Spidey whispering: ´ If you continue at this pace, you might be doing good things AND the people will like you.´.

column2:
幸: happiness; blessing; fortune
丸: round; full (month); perfection; -ship; pills; make round; roll up; curl up; seduce; explain away
column4: Tenacious-D is happy band led by a fat man. (It´s Tenacious-D time, ya muthafucka´, gwaoh!).
column5: To be tenacious, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don´t discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn´t drive you to give up). The most tenacious person of all time was happy round Buddha!

column2:
戸: door; counter for houses; door radical (no. 63)

(I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.).
column5: Once upon a time... Oh hell, you´re just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your fingers.

column5: Do me from behind, says the bird, as she shakes her tailfeathers.

column4: Hand job or "shakuhachi", choose.

Mr. T sold all his jewelry to give as reparations to slave families. The governent tried to honor his charity by giving him a prize, but it was a shitty outhouse filled with clams.

column2:

Can´t you just picture this ridiculously polite S&M picture? A businessman, who DOTH the bidding of his taskmistress, is climaxing and yelling out "お願い致します" while she whips and says "どう致しまして". (This kanji also means "to bring about" and "do humbly", which is perfect for this image).

Naturally, they COLLIDE when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick).
