column4: See suck (#689): if it´s too big to handle, just use your fingers instead...
column5: One of the first thing a baby can do with his hand is to reach out and grab your finger as if it was a little handle.

column2:
雇: employ; hire
頁: page; leaf
column4: I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD...when I look back, maybe that was not a wise career move.
column5: The people we employ are always turning their heads to look back. They don´t want to be caught playing solitare on company time.

column2:
言: say
公: public; prince; official; governmental
column4: Take care what words you say in public lest you be sued.
column5: [+radical_tyro] Socrates was giving a speech in public. Things were going rather well, until his robe opened a bit and people saw his, well, not-public area. He was promptly sued for public indecency. Certain things shouldn´t be made public in public, you know?

column2:
戈: halberd; arms; festival car; float; tasselled spear radical (no. 62)
廾: twenty; 20; twenty or letter H radical (no. 55)
column4: Two hands, fiesta.....when moses received the ten commandments with two hands, he went back down the mountain and threw a fiesta with the jews, celebrating the arrival of the commandments.
column5: When Moses returned with the commandments in his hands he saw that his people were throwing a fiesta. At first he was excited. Then he looked around and got pissed. "Awww, c´mon guys. Golden idols? Really?".

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
止: stop; halt
column4: And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others.
column5: Religious Republicans regularly go to the altar to pray for a stop to welfare.

column2:
小: small, insignificant
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
言: say
column4: This owl´s reputation skyrocketed after he created a tool in order to speak human words.
column5: By word of mouth, owl-luring tool (raise (#1938)) gained a reputation of amazingly effective and reliable device.

column2:
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
欠: lack; gap; fail; yawning radical (no. 76)
column4: Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.
column5: I would be delighted if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.

column2:
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
column4: Mnemonic "pegasus persuasion power". I think of the hippogriff from Harry Potter as being like a pegasus. To befriend a hippogriff, you have to persuade it you mean no harm, you can do this if you have "pegasus persuasion power".
column5: It would take a powerful argument to persuade me Pegasus was real…

column2:
馬: horse
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: Or more precisely: the team of horses are getting boisterous because one of them got bitten in the crotch by a horse fly. The kanji also means to roar, make up noise, to kick up a fuss and to make merry. Perhaps it is exactly the etymology behind this kanji.
column5: The hidden Greeks inside the Trojan Horse are getting boisterous as one of them is bitten in the crotch by a nasty insect. If they don´t shut up, the Trojans will hear them...

column2:
門: gate; counter for cannons
伐: fell; strike; attack; punish
column4: You only get through the gates into that person's fiesta if you are in the same clique.
column5: The felled souls of the world, cut down like trees, pass through the gates of hell and join the clique.

column2:
田: rice field; rice paddy
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai´s armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the "turtle samurai" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.
column5: It looks like a bird´s eye view of a tank (modern armor).

column2:
糸: thread
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that´s left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not "eels". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in waterfall (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as "eels". It is much better to call the right half of this character an "unbound tortoise".).
column5: When Spiderman fights the giant tortoise, he grabs a straw rope from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. However, the tortoise quickly tucks his head back into his shell to avoid the blow (hence no head on the tortoise).

column2:
手: hand
䍃: a vase; a pitcher; earthenware
column4: Primitive: A condor is like a vulture but twice the size and lives in mountainous regions (+1 Elphalpo). Story: I swing my fingers back and forth, trying to fend off the attacking condor.
column5: For the condor primitive: A condor is like a vulture, but twice as big and it lives near mountains (a suitable place for such a majestic bird). For swing: I´m sitting on a swing when a condor comes by and picks up the whole swing set with its big finger-like claws and now I´m swinging in mid-air. Weeeeeeeee!!!!!

column2:
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in rabbit (#2093).
column5: What is the rabbit´s excuse for being such a jerk? Well he was bound up for a whole day while being stepped on by peoples human legs in some make-up labratory. Yeah I think I can excuse him after knowing that.

column2:
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
无: nothing; not exist; crooked heaven radical (no.71)
column4: Distinguish from formerly (#501). Think of previously as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the waitress gives you unwashed silverware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.
column5: For the waitress primitive, I don´t really see the receipt. So instead, I imagine a waitress holding a plate above her head, using those legs to weave through the tables.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
火: fire
column4: Customer in restaurant asks you (waiter) what you recommend: "I recommend ze deer or ze 'eadless chicken. And I recommend you garnish it wiz some flowers." (let last six strokes = headless chicken).
column5: It is recommended that deers stick to eating flowers. If they try to eat birds, they may end up choking on them, like this one here. Note that the head (白) is gone and the visible part of the body which is normally written with a stroke of the head must by necessity be drawn with a stroke of the tail.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
米: rice; USA; metre
舛: dancing radical (no. 136)
column4: America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses.
column5: All the neighboring communities to the Pinnacle have a major problem. The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: ´Excuse me, I couldn´t help noticing the splendour of the flowers in your garden. Simply splendid. Ten out of ten.´ The villager gruffly replies: ´No it ´aint. It´s all muck. An´ I´m gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for silage.´.
column5: (I'm substituting greenhouse for silage. It is also full of all types of plants, and the shape resembles the windows that cover the building to let in the light.) See the splendor of the roses filling the greenhouse, beauty atop a stem of needles (thorns).

column2:
竹: bamboo
車: car
卩: seal radical (no. 26)
column4: This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.
column5: I just had a new bamboo-leaf pattern spray-painted on my car. Don't touch it, you'll leave fingerprints!

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
爪: claw; nail; talon
彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: The wheat farmer´s heart is calm (#1147) about the eagle not stealing his crops because of the broom scarecrow. But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it.
column5: Move the broom with a vulture perched on top, and you´ll find the concealed entrance to the heart of The Pinnacle.

column2:
折: fold; break; fracture; bend; yield; submit
口: mouth
column4: A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.
column5: I fold my mouth, therefore I am.

column2:
木: tree; wood
彡: three; hair ornament; short hair or fur radical (no. 59)
column4: Cedar is an evergreen tree that keeps its SHAPE all year long. That is, it doesn´t loose its needles/leaves in the winter.
column5: Cedar is a wood that keeps its shape. (This is true, it's rot resistant.).

column2:
釆: separate; divide; topped rice radical (no. 165)
尺: shaku; Japanese foot; measure; scale; rule
column4: Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I´d purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They´re so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he´s playing.
column5: An interpretive dance of some kind where somebody follows animal tracks, a shakuhachi providing the soundtrack, suggesting the tracker's thoughts and intentions.

column2:
爪: claw; nail; talon
女: woman; female
column4: Overly gentle women are vultures who want to marry you and steal your money - not true but an easy mnemonic!
column5: An eagle must be extra gentle to pick up a dainty woman in its sharp claws.

column2:
戌: sign of the dog; 7-9PM; eleventh sign of Chinese zodiac
女: woman; female
column4: The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!
column5: Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of "dignity" and "threaten." I can see how a march of women in Japan would be seen as intimidating by most men.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
口: mouth
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
豕: pig; hog; pig radical (no. 152)
column4: In Orwell´s ´Animal Farm´ the pigs overpowered every other animals. They crownded themselves as ruler of the farm and walked tall on their rear legs, a crime strictly forbidden in the animal republic.
column5: Ganon, the tall crowned pig, has been overpowering ther land of Hyrule for decades.

column2:
能: ability; talent; skill; capacity
火: fire
column4: Most don´t know it, but bears have the ability to walk on fire. They´re invincible creatures!
column5: Note : I don´t know why James Heisig put "bear" ahead of "ability" (next frame), but I sugget to skip this, learn the next kanji ("ability") then go back here and use ability as a primitive.

column2:
水: water
帯: sash; belt; obi; zone; region
column4: History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one´s karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren´t their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????
column5: A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.

column2:
彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)
山: mountain
兀: high & level; lofty; bald; dangerous
攵: strike; hit; folding chair radical variant (no. 66)
column4: The Column of 300 spartans were in a delicate situation. They had travelled in one line (using only their legs) to the mountain pass to face the fierce Persian task master.
column5: Telling your taskmistress (wife) why you are going mountain climbing without her is a delicate situation... "For one thing you have such beautiful legs and I don´t want to risk injuring them honey"...

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
夂: winter radical (no. 34)
生: life; genuine; birth
column4: You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs.
column5: A woman takes her bra off and what happens? Nine months later the hump in her belly pops out between her legs as a new life.

column2:
疒: trailing sickness; sick radical (no. 104)
正: correct; justice; righteous; 10**40
column4: Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness.
column5: A sickness can only be correctly diagnosed if the symptoms are identified correctly.

column2:
斬: beheading; kill; murder
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.
column5: Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.

column2:
肉: meat
干: dry; parch
column4: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).
column5: The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried liver to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.

column2:
口: mouth
奐: clear; bright
column4: Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I´m imagining lots of yelping.
column5: Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They´re so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up.

column2:
女: woman; female
少: few; little
column4: Exquisite women are few and far between.
column5: A geisha is an exquisite and delicate (another meaning of this kanji) women, however, even in the past there was only few of them.

column2:
十: ten
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
糸: thread
column4: A coaxial cord has a needle-like pin, a crown cap for screwing it in, and insulation made of thread.
column5: Spiderman has been captured and given the ultimate torture: they forced a crown of needles on his head and attached it to an electrical cord, which they are about to plug into an outlet...

column2:
龍: dragon; imperial
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
column4: The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for "dragon". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji "imperial dragon". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare "three-headed slingshot-snake" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment.
column5: You attack an old dragon 龍 and take his clothes. REF: dragon [old] (#2981).

column2:
豸: snake; legless insect; badger or clawed dog radical (no. 153)
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He´s a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver (since he always finishes second in the game of love).
column5: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He´s a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver.

column2:
木: tree; wood
丙: third class; 3rd; 3rd calendar sign
column4: This is a "design" as in a "pattern", not a verb as in "to design". The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it.
column5: Half Way!!!!

column2:
敬: awe; respect; honor; revere
馬: horse
column4: You stand in AWE at the 8th WONDER of the world, a huge TROJAN HORSE.
column5: This is another word for surprise. 驚く＝おどろく= surprise. The Trojans stood in awe of the magnificent Trojan Horse that they thought was a gift. But imagine their surprise (wonder) when a bunch of Greeks came rushing out of it! (To further cement the connection between the primitives, if needed: It´s a wonder that the Trojans managed to speak keigo 敬語 even then, saying "わたくしたちを殺さないでください!!お願い致します!!").

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
林: grove; forest
column4: (Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin´ a huge doob in a secret corner of the Batcave where he nurtures his hemp grove).
column5: Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!

column2:
齊: alike; equal; similar; Saito
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: When my medicine dose is way too large, I adjust it by cutting it into smaller pieces with my saber.
column5: We had to adjust his dose slightly, after he went on a rampage with a sabre.

column2:
水: water
頼: trust; request
column4: You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.
column5: You can never trust the water in the rapids, it will do everything it can to pull you under. Imagine a line of natives with bundles upon their heads all fighting the rapids to cross the river.

column2:
走: run
取: take; fetch; take up
column4: The gist of it is this: We take the money and run!
column5: Pickpocket advice: It´s simple, FIRST run, then take. Yeah, that´s the gist of it!

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
旧: old times; old things; old friend; former; ex-
column4: The Pinnacle is actually bound up by supports from olden times. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse.
column5: The Pinnacle is supported by pilings which were bound up in olden times. One day when the bindings rot away, the whole thing will collapse. (tweaking dihutensoa´s story to work a little better for me).

column2: 齊: alike; equal; similar; Saito
column4: Purification? I think of Japanese during new year's eve praying(saying sentences) in front of Itsukushima's shrine torii(fenceposts) and its altar. They expect to enter the new year totally purified.
column5: Kind of vulgar, but here the SCOTSMAN got tired of adjusting himself so decided try PURIFICATION. Sadly, he did it by straddling the ALTAR with his skinny LEGS.

column2:
母: mother
貝: shellfish
column4: Ariel the Little Mermaid´s clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.
column5: The sad fate of Mama shellfish was to be captured and pierced to make an earring.

column2:
人: person
山: mountain
column4: A HERMIT is a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS.
column5: After living as an hermit (recluse) for a while in the mountains, Mister T becomes an immortal mountain fairy ("fairy" is another meaning of this kanji).

column2:
尉: military officer; jailer; old man; rank
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.
column5: This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II "comfort women" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.).

column2:
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: Hesig should be BOUND for a DAY (or maybe 10 days - a decameron) for calling this Kanji DECAMERON. See martyrdom (#809).
column5: If you bind up ten days, you get a decameron.

column2:
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).
column5: You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your´s and your neighbours´ garden. But unfortunately, it´s not long until your rake splits in two.

column2:
匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh..
column5: It´s sooo delicious I could spoon it in all day.

column2:
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
卩: seal radical (no. 26)
column4: He scratches off the silver stamp and discovers that he is an instant winner.
column5: For instant postal delivery, buy a silver stamp!

column2:
木: tree; wood
卯: sign of the hare or rabbit; 5-7AM; fourth sign of Chinese zodiac; east
column4: Having decided to use SIGN OF THE HARE rather than RECEIPT and STAMP my mnemonic goes as follows: The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE´s ears.
column5: A strange thing about the japanese willow tree is, it grows eggs... but the eggs have no yokes. weird eh?

column2:
人: person
為: do; change; make; benefit; welfare; be of use; reach to; try; practice; cost; serve as; good; advantage; as a result of
column4: A person who claims he didn't do something while he actually did, is telling a falsehood.
column5: It depends on what your definition of do, uh, is, says Mr. T giving falsehood about his affair with a peacock.

column2:
襾: cover; place on top of; west radical variant (no. 146)
革: leather; become serious; skin; hide; pelt
月: month; moon
column4: In the old west, animal skins were made into leather and their flesh was eaten, thus using the whole animal, which viewed from the animal side could be taken as humans asserting complete hegemony over them. All your base are belong to us.
column5: In the Old West, cowboys had hegemony OVER the Indians despite their leathercraft and ability to navigate by the moon.

column2:
言: say
羊: sheep
column4: Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the sheep gives a very detailed worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. "We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you".
column5: Say! detailed sheep, not like that! DE-TAILED sheep. Got it?

column2:
手: hand
氐: name of an ancient tribe
column4: Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don´t know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.
column5: Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.

column2:
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
月: month; moon
column4: Compare the primitive positions of armpit (#870) and threaten (#871). When your triceps rest alongside your body, they fit snugly against your armpit. When you hold them above your body, however, your posture becomes quite threatening.
column5: Don´t threaten a warewolf. He´s three times as powerful ON a full moon.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
戊: 5th calendar sign
column4: The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers.
column5: When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it´s like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!

column2:
牛: cow
義: righteousness; justice; morality; honor; loyalty; meaning
column4: A cow that is righteous sacrifices her milk for the human race.
column5: Cows are truly righteous animals. They SACRIFICE their milk so that we can have some. And if they don´t have any left, they give a sheep a hand fiesta (good lord this is going too far) and give us that instead. What righteous cows.

column2:
足: leg; foot; be sufficient; counter for pairs of footwear
巨: gigantic; big; large; great
column4: You can step a long-distance if you have a leg that´s gigantic!
column5: You can step a long-distance if you have gigantic wooden legs (stilts).

column2:
牙: tusk; fang; tusk radical (no. 92)
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk. This mnemonic is meant to join RtK´s keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used "elegant" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character´s meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha´s Kanji Learner´s Dictionary).
column5: To not confuse it with grace (#606) or graceful (#721), think of the phrase "Goodness gracious." Like: "Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!".

column2:
食: eat; food
巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)
column4: [decorate; ornament; adorn; embellish] We decorate a table before eating, reclining a towel over it.
column5: Naked sushi: a lady reclining on a towel as decoration for the food laid out on her.

column2:
糸: thread
罔: net
column4: Spiderman traps The Rhino under the hood of his famous netting, where even Rhino´s horns can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even perish in there.
column5: You use a 糸 to make a net shaped like a hood. A stray animal got caught in it by its horns and perished.

column2: 龍: dragon; imperial
column4: Have you ever seen an asian DRAGON? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.
column5: If the poor villagers don´t provide him with a vase full of eels each day, the dragon will lay waste to the village.

column2:
敏: cleverness; agile; alert
糸: thread
column4: Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn´t beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man´s luxuriant garden.
column5: Venom is covered in a luxuriant and surprisingly clever symbiotic suit, but it´s also the taskmaster for his every evil act.

column2:
羽: feathers; counter for birds, rabbits
異: uncommon; queerness; strangeness; wonderful; curious; unusual
column4: The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with feathers only on its wings would be very uncommon.
column5: WINGS without any FEATHERS would be an UNCOMMON site. Well, unless you like to eat chicken WINGS alot.

column2:

舄: a shoe; the sole of a shoe; magpie
column4: Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. Lagoon is a shallow pond, thus easily warmed by sun, large-scale equivalent of a boiling cauldron.
column5: I stapled both sides of some tail feathers to a waterfall towering over the lagoon to give it a more tropical feel…

column2:
鬼: ghost; devil
未: un-; not yet; hitherto; still; even now; sign of the ram; 1-3PM; eighth sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: Ghosts have not yet left the world, they must still have a deep fascination with their past life on Earth.
column5: Here the "Ghostbusters" founder talks about his fascination for ghosts (picture Dan Arkroyd in the movie if that helps). He says he has a fascination for ghosts ever since he saw one as a teenager. Since then he´s been scouring all of the world, trying to capture them on tape, on video... A journalist asks "When will it end ? Aren´t you tired of chasing ghosts ?" "Oh no, not yet ! Not until I become a ghost myself anyway !".

column2:

兼: concurrently; and
column4: Naturally, if you´re dating more than one woman concurrently, they will certainly dislike each other!
column5: Attempting to court two women concurrently will make them both dislike you.

column2:

column4: The Scotsman goalkeeper adjusted himself. He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs.
column5: HINT: this kanji as a primitive can mean goalkeeper. The "fence posts" are goalposts, and the two goalkeepers wear plaid uniforms (this kanji also means uniform as in even), making them uniform with each other and distinguishing them as goalkeepers from the rest of the team.

column2:

column5: Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.

column2:
手: hand
雍: softening; mitigation
column4: A mysterious turkey with human fingers wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!
column5: Imagine Gandalf hugging a turkey....ouch! It bit off his finger!

column2:

巻: scroll; volume; book; part; roll up; wind up; tie; coil; counter for texts (or book scrolls)
column4: I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done.
column5: [RPG] You´re fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a scroll/quartersnake of protection, and he´s pent in a sphere of protection.

column2:
网: net; net or net crown radical (no. 122)
言: say
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: For Japanese, when the mind´s eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two penaltys to choose from. One, you can say I´m sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I´m sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ).
column5: There is a 3-way masterplan for every goalkeeper to prevent a goal at penalty shootout: 1. Look directly into the eyes of the player --- 2. Confuse him by screaming senseless words --- 3. Pull out you your saber and ... (that´s up to you).

column2:
水: water
戍: protection
火: fire
column4: Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.
column5: Use a water cannon to destroy a line of marching fire monsters. I keep mixing this one up with disaster (#167) and demolition (#400). Remember, you DESTROY monsters (think of the Godzilla movie "Destroy All Monsters!"). Fires and floods are natural DISASTERs. And DEMOLITION is something you carefully do while wearing protective garments. (vaguely based on stefanot´s balrog story).

column2:
石: stone
楚: whip; cane
column4: Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.
column5: A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the cornerstone has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious mending.).

column2:

肉: meat
column4: The rotting meat adheres to the cave walls.
column5: Smaller municipalities are well known for filling their budgets with pork (meat). Thats why they are also well known for being rotten.

column4: Shins are the part of the body that one uses instead of one´s eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!).
column5: Shins are the part of the body that Japanese traditionally sit on instead of their asses.

column2:

column5: That´s not ice...it´s my last drops and I´m exhausted! ;).

column2:
人: person
菐: None
column4: Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.
column5: Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it´s the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft; "ore" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use "ore" -- but when he´s one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it´s ME!".

column2:

column4: Don´t give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it´ll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those "Caution - Slippery Floor" signs up on the resultant puddle.
column5: Slippery surfaces are very dangerous for skeletons, since their bone feet slip easily... a few drops of water, and zweep! A large mess of bones to pick up and reassemble!

column2:
子: child; sign of the rat; 11PM-1AM; first sign of Chinese zodiac
瓜: melon

column5: Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan.

column2:

column5: This old China man glued shrubs to his body. The added intake of oxygen from the shrubs was, according to him, the secret of his longevity. Sometimes he would sit all day in meditation without moving, and the locals believed the old man had actually turned into a shrub !

column2:

column4: A stubborn person in the beginning gets something into their head and can´t change their mind.
column5: Picture a STUBBORN schoolboy, with his arms crossed and his book still open to the BEGINNING PAGE. Despite the teacher telling him to turn the page, he refuses and keeps his book on the BEGINNING PAGE.

column2:

column5: A gold chain with small seashells hanging on it is in fashion these days.

column5: When coloring something in you grab the crayon of choice to fill in the shapes.

column2:

column5: When the feds came to bust your little hemp grove, you jumped out the back side of the cave and tried to repel down with a hemp rope. Unfortunately, the rope chafed your hands and you fell .. ouch!

column2:

column2:

column5: Radiance is an army of rays.

column2:

column5: Kobe beef. The Japanese amass a fortune pampering livestock feeding them flowers, offering beer, playing music and giving them massages…

column2:

column4: The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.
column5: An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car´s wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.

column2:

column4: Your earnings allow you to bring home your daily bread (made of wheat, naturally).
column5: Hmm, EARNINGS. Think of the popular saying "Bringing HOME the bacon". Here, EARNINGS is the picture "Bringing HOME the bread(WHEAT) and the bacon (PIG).

column2:

column5: What a dilemna, you wore SUNGLASSES over your EYES when you went to the BIRDHOUSE so you wouldn´t be recognized - but now you can´t WINK at the girl you want!

column2:

column5: Cannon = stone projectile wrapped by a barrel.

column2:

column5: A bit nasty (but makes the whole thing much easier to remember) is to take the right side and call it a bearded clam. For erupt, you can make your own story about the mouth/opening on the left.

column2:
言: say
夸: boast
column4: The hunter´s boast: I say, it was a "big one", but the snare broke and it got away. (credit to many others before).
column5: A dog owner boasts about how obedient, not how smart, his Saint Bernard dog is. "Why, my dog will even walk right into a trap if I tell him to. Watch!" With a single word, "go!", his dog obediently runs into a snare trap hanging from the ceiling. In a flash, the dog is netted tightly and swinging from the ceiling. Don´t forget the ceiling!

column2:

column4: Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering.
column5: On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way.

column2:
牛: cow
生: life; genuine; birth
column4: Animal sacrifice = taking the life of a cow.
column5: In the 21st century, animal sacrifice is no longer really necessary. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)

column4: Think of REGULARITY in terms of bowel movements. Enough WHEAT in your diet will help your DROPS with improved REGULARITY.
column5: Eating plenty of wheat will improve regularity and help you lose weight.

column2:

column4: The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That´s why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.
column5: This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the standing element takes those little crown "winglets" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She´s standing on her crown rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her apron. I guess the sovereign´s servants have the day off.

column2:

column4: I named the right part legal prostitute has it represents a walker [walking legs] with the license. It´s easy to imagine a legal prostitute tempting a man with her mouth.
column5: Prostitutes in Amsterdam have a license to show off their walking legs and tempt customers with their mouths.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
且: moreover; also; furthermore
column4: Keeping porn on the pinnacle of a bookshelf can thwart snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).
column5: The shortness of the Japanese thwarts their attempts to reach the topmost (pinnacle) shelf without grabbing a chair.

column2:

大: large; big

column4: If you look into Japanese gardens they seem so peaceful - with their small bonsais and the white stones looking like rice grains.
column5: Simplistic and peaceful life: A bonsai to trim and enough rice to eat...

column2:

column5: If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.

column2:

菐: None

column5: Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp SLAP in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.

column2:

屈: yield; bend; flinch; submit
column4: (See dig (#1061)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch.
column5: Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it´s patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare.

column2:

column4: Chrysanthemum flower consists of many tiny petals, just like many rice grains bound up together.
column5: [+astgt] Chrysanthemum is a terrorist orginization whose sole objective is to tie up Condi Rice. One day, Condi Rice is standing outside when a group of chrysanthemum agents swoop in from the sides, bound her up with chrysanthemum rope, and dash off. They leave a lone yellow chrysanthemum flower on top of the bound Condi Rice as a sign to let her discoverers know who committed this brave and noble act.

column2:

column4: Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk.
column5: At the elegant cocktail party of VIP's, the spy, dressed like everyone else in formal evening wear, sneaks in and strangles his victim with a very thin wire - a thread. Afterwards he mingles in with the crowd and disappears.

column2:
糸: thread
彖: divination
column4: There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the pig was to take a broom and sweep up all of Spiderman´s leftover threads after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too.
column5: Certain people have an affinity for romantic partners who are handy with thread and a broom - it is of no consequence if they look like pigs. hmm...

column2:
口: mouth

column4: The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, "Gobble." Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.
column5: Sadly my mouth gets to taste turkey solely on Christmas Day.

column2:
肉: meat

column4: This kanji does not mean swell as in a inflammation. There is a different kanji for that meaning (腫れる). This kanji means swell as in, a tire swelling/expanding, your income swelling/expanding, dough swelling/expanding, etc. Johnskb's story is best b/c it does not involve swelling in the sense of inflammation, just general expansion of the stomach. STORY: "If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL/EXPAND and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet.".
column5: Which part of your body can change shape and, when it does, swells up and throbs like a drumb? Hmmm...

column2:
而: rake
寸: measurement; foot/10
column4: [akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.
column5: I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.

column2:

column5: Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags.

column5: Bambi was melancholy at the death of his mother, but is now in jubilation as he´s made friends with thumper.

column5: If you want to make your wild dogs fierce, feed them a child. Children are the holy grail of dogfood you know...

column5: People always seem to overdo it with their perfume. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap flowery perfume. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that floweriness as a compass - it tells me which direction they´re in.

Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system ("changing people´s hearts" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there´s no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one´s bad experiences).
column5: Judge: You will serve a penal sentence until indications show you have a heart.

column2:

column4: If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They´re basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...
column5: Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of "The Awl and the Sabre". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : "The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can´t use the sabre.".

column2:

column4: The shape of a sheriff´s badge makes it patent who he is.

column5: Ever seen those huge chess games in parks? The large wooden chess pieces need to be carted in a shopping trolley.

column2:

column4: Constancy is holding the same state of mind over a long span of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).
column5: Data is the epitome of constancy. As a robot, his consistency spans the entire day.

column2:

column5: Picture a major robbery where some dudes are breaking into a bank to steal their money. They get their man in the vault through the ceiling - now he´s hanging from a rope a few feet from the ground (like in the movies, dodging laser beams). He reports back that he has found the loot, and its all in a large piggy bank in the center of the vault. The alarm sounds and he´s got to think fast. He jams the four fingers of his right hand in the piggy bank slot and tells his team to hoist him up, he´s got the loot!

column2:

column4: Recollection is about bringing ideas back to your mind.

column5: A teenager addicted to heroine must overcome the needle.

column5: Giving the police the finger and a colorful phrase is a surefire way to get arrested.

column2:
人: person
扁: level; small
column4: Mr. T is partial to konbini hentai. He reads them for hours every day after work at his local konbini. (Primitive: KONBINI HENTAI, all the magazines(scrapbooks) by every konbini door in Japan).
column5: Mr. T is very partial to hentai comic books. I know because he dropped a pile of them when I accidentally bumped into him at the door to kinokuniya!

column2:
雨: rain
分: part; minute of time; segment; share; degree; one's lot; duty; understand; know; rate; 1%; chances; shaku/100
column4: The part of the sky that is responsible for weather and rain is known as the atmosphere. It only occupies part of the sky though.
column5: (This is atmosphere as in ambiance, mood). Rain is only part of the atmosphere for a romantic porch date. Food, music, and candles are the rest.

column2:
禺: long-tailed monkey
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: On the road to my interview I accidentally bump into Jiminy Cricket who gives me some good advice.
column5: I was finally able to score an interview with the wisest being around: Jiminy Cricket. However, his schedule is really packed, so they had to squeeze me in while his tour bus rode between gigs. In fact, it was really short---after a few miles I was kicked out of the bus and stranded in the middle of the interstate. But man, it was worth it!

column2:
言: say
咨: investigate
column4: Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.
column5: Consulting with is having words with the next mouth.

column2:
卜: divination
早: early; fast
column4: The most eminent magician is he who learned to use his magic wand early in life.
column5: The eminent sunflower is the one that stands above the others.

column2:

日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.
column5: A tortoise is prosperity bound up with a tail. They are very lucky creatures.

column2:
米: rice; USA; metre
量: quantity; measure; weight; amount; consider; estimate; surmise
column4: Imagine Japanese army provisions like obentou boxes, always containing the same quantity of rice. (thanks darg_sama, emphasizing quantity and the nuance of food "rations", "food supply": the kanji also appears in "military provisions" and "army rice").
column5: All Japanese provisions contain a certain quantity of rice... they eat it with just about every meal!

column2:
竹: bamboo
溥: far and wide
column4: Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won´t stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon´s story.
column5: This doctor dilutes (see 227) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.

column2:
火: fire
戸: door; counter for houses; door radical (no. 63)
column4: This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive.
column5: -"Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?" -"Aagh, just use the frickin´ door!".

column2:
歹: bare bone; bad; wrong; death radical (n. 78)
朱: vermilion; cinnabar; scarlet; red; bloody
column4: A t-bone steak is vermilion - particularly if served rare.
column5: Castlevania -- The vermillion skeletons (bones) are particularly hard because they just keep regenerating.

column2:
歹: bare bone; bad; wrong; death radical (n. 78)
直: straightaway; honesty; frankness; fix; repair
column4: Advertisement for Breast Implants -- Tired of nights all alone? Want to get boned straightaway? AUGMENT your breasts and all your troubles will be solved!
column5: In the movie “Gattaca”, Vincent Freeman (played by Ethan Hawke) augments his size by straightening his bones (his legs), in order to match up with the genetically “perfect” population, and reach his goal of travelling in space. The stretching of his lower leg bones involved multiplying the bone cells, another sense of this key word.

column2:
舟: boat; ship
監: oversee; official; govt office; rule; administer
column4: The warship towers over the smaller benign boats, overseeing their safe path from port to port.
column5: A warship is a boat that oversees the seas. Think of it as the patroller of the ocean.

column2:
非: un-; mistake; negative; injustice; non-
車: car
column4: Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle.
column5: (+fuaburisu) But it´s the wrong jail cell! Your comrade is one floor above.

column2:
大: large; big
可: can; passable; mustn't; should not; do not
column4: I find it strange that so many people commit suicide in Tokyo by throwing themselves in front of the train. To me when I look at this kanji, I see a train just about to come out of a tunnel, and above the man waiting for his oppourtunity where he can end it all.
column5: Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How strange!

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
曼: wide; beautiful
column4: I´ll focus on the mandala primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it´s the "man" in mandara/mandala (曼荼羅). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, the crotch represents the animal instincts.
column5: He´ s often ridiculed for having his eye on crotches all day.

column2:
寉: crane (bird)
鳥: bird; chicken
column4: Do you know how cranes came to be? Well, they used to keep the poor bird cooped all the time. But the crane really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the coop trying to be free.
column5: The original version of the "Ugly Duckling" was about a crane who grew up in a turkey coop. All the other birds made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail...

column2:
言: say
某: so-and-so; one; a certain; that person
column4: I imagine a clique of catty girls conspiring against a another girl...they are exchanging lots of words, chatting about how so-and-so girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it.
column5: You might hear the words of someone conspiring... "If you do so-and-so...".

column2:
手: hand
白: white
column4: (Image: the most snooty prim and proper English Lord with white gloves clapping only with his fingers. "Oh bravo old chap. Bravo...").
column5: I clapped so hard, my fingers became white.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
乂: mow; cut grass; subdue
column4: Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.
column5: This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare "length" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldn´t show "it" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
莧: edible greens; amaranth
column4: A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.
column5: To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning "beautiful things") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.

column2:
襾: cover; place on top of; west radical variant (no. 146)
復: restore; return to; revert; resume
column4: The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright.
column5: Remember Oregon Trail? Remember how you had to float your wagon across rivers to get to the Old West? Well, sometimes that wagon capsizes. Once that happens you´d better quickly head to the nearest town to restore.

column2:
肉: meat
包: wrap; pack up; cover; conceal
column4: Imagine a newborn baby, fresh out of the womb, being entirely wrapped by the long piece of flesh, called a placenta, that once fed him.
column5: Placenta is flesh/part of the body wrapped around the foetus.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
鬲: tripod
column4: The Pinnacle, to me, is a city that makes itself out to be perfect but is filled with dirty secrets that photographers are always trying to reveal (see dissolve (#1044) The city´s councilmen have isolated all professional photographers to make sure they don´t photograph these "dirty secrets". (which are up to your imagination).
column5: The people of the pinnacle isolate themselves, dissolving any outside friendships.

column2:
水: water
争: contend; dispute; argue
column4: Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest.
column5: The water contends against the dirt in the ultimate battle for cleaninless.

column2:
水: water
殳: pike; windy-again radical (no. 79)
column4: (Note: this kanji is more collapse/cave-in/sink (#1888) than humans drowning) A water missile? A torpedo! And when it hits it´s target? The ship collapses then sinks and everyone drowns!
column5: The submarine´s hull was breached after being struck by a torpedo ("water missile"), causing the entire crew to drown.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video´s of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.
column5: Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it "hobby". REF: shrimp (#2689), haze (#2779).

column2:

column4: A magic wand is needed to make a clam stand upright.
column5: Just the thought of my magic wand on her clam makes my magic wand stand upright.

column2:

column4: The overseer tags his slaves with gold earrings, just like specimens.
column5: (Thanks bodhisamaya) The authorities are suspicious about the athlete that won GOLD at the olympics. They are now OVERSEEING a thorough drug test, taking all sorts of SPECIMENS.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
今: now
云: say
column4: There are three types of shade: 1. natural (a high pinnacle), 2. man-made buildings (a clock tower), 3. meteorological (a cloud).
column5: Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the shade. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!

column2:
金: gold
名: name; noted; distinguished; reputation
column4: A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription.
column5: I imagine ancient Egyptian inscriptions: Pharaohs´ names written in gold.

column2:

column4: [Image: Follow the ´Yellow-Brick Road´ to success] The pinnacle signifies your personal goal and destination. What you´re seeking to possess lies at the end of the yellow-brick road. You must follow the road to get what you want.
column5: I fled to The Pinnacle for safety, but the demon followed me right up the road!

column2:

column4: The nazis were ardent believers in the master arian race, see them marching everyone else into the oven fires, single file.
column5: The undead, marching single file, prove how ardent they are be walking across a field of flame. Fun fact, ardent used to mean to burn.

column2:

column4: The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.).
column5: As a verb this means, this means "to ask; to enquire; to search; to look for; to look into; to investigate;". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a crafty mouth and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut(glued) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they inquire.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)

column4: The first DRAFT of catcher in the rye was actually called "catcher in the TALL WHEAT"...good thing they changed it. I read it in 高校.
column5: Aliens often draft their plans for invasion by cutting designs among the tall wheat.

column2:
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)

column4: How about a rusty cinnabar colored dilapidated boat, found abandoned somewhere. The smoke-stack and the keel have fallen off...
column5: Rusty old boat with the bottom and top missing.

column5: You signed a non-disclosure agreement with the taskmaster but you opened your mouth as soon as you got out the door!

column2:

column5: At Capitol Hill proposals get axed on the floor.

column2:

column4: Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.
column5: Ok just a note to the ´ridgepole facing east story´ im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a ´sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is´, back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).

column2:

襄: rise; raise
column4: My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.
column5: On the island of JOU, in order to be considered a lot, a ground must be big enough to grow sufficient grass for a grass skirt.

column2:
水: water
曼: wide; beautiful

column5: Even NELSON MANDALA dreams of drops of WATER glistening on comic book/ anime girls with LOOSE morals. (This story has been edited in response reports).

column2:

column4: What could be more mysterious than a cocoon in a top hat trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: GANDALF).

column2:

column5: The gentleman gave the woman a bit of sperm...BAM PREGNANCY!

column2:

column5: Every quarter moon, the cost of a trojan horse rises one quarter by inflation.

column2:
豕: pig; hog; pig radical (no. 152)

column5: In association with pursue (#539), our sow has tracked down a suitable mate, they´ve consummated their relationship, and now the little sow is all grown up into a boar with horns.

column2:

column2:

column5: In a lot of Super Nintendo-era RPGs, there are mountain levels to get through. You view them from overhead, so you can see a mazelike path with many branches. Picture your sprite characters at one such fork in the mountain path, as it branches off in two directions.

column2:

column4: The thread that holds the locket around my neck is choker-length so it stays horizontal.
column5: Hint : this kanji also means "latitude", which are the horizontal lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 "black ink" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his "thread locket" to mark horizontal lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark horizontal lines. Imagine the "thread-locket" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
口: mouth
column4: To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it´s unruly, chaotic nature.
column5: The illegal immigrants cultivate the land but are socially and politically muzzled (wear muzzles while they work too).

column2:
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
口: mouth
column4: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.
column5: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, allowing people to rent him and play catch with him for money!

column2:
舟: boat; ship
廷: courts; imperial court; government office
column4: Rowboats are a classic way to court (go on a date with) someone...
column5: Courts in olden times would often punish convicts by sentencing them to a life of being the rower crew for large rowboat ships (there were no engines or boilers back then)... Yo ho, Yo ho....

column2:

column4: When yielding, soldiers raise the white flag before exiting from the trenches.
column5: If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you.

column2:
水: water
炎: inflammation; flame; blaze
column4: Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you´ll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below... THAT´s what it takes to become thin.
column5: Thin girls are twice as hot when they´re wet.

column2:
手: hand
由: wherefore; a reason
column4: [When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers.
column5: If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;).

column2:
手: hand
皮: pelt; skin; hide; leather; skin radical (no. 107)
column4: You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.
column5: Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to expose her “beaver” pelt, so you have to encourage her with your fingers to expose it.

column2:
壬: 9th calendar sign

column4: A porter has run away from his master. His punishment is to be stretched out on the rack. So say the courts in this barbaric time.
column5: The gentleman stretched the truth a bit in court.

column2:
金: gold
帛: cloth
column4: Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.
column5: Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest brocade in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It´s embroidered with gold and cocaine. Yes, cocaine - what you thought it´d be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel.

column2:

column4: Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn´t actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!
column5: An iced turkey is only quasi-as-good-as fresh turkey.

column5: Here we have a St.Bernard exhorting the vulture to become the leader in the race against the turtle, but he can´t because of the glue. see leader (#731).

column2:

彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)

column4: The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!).
column5: After being hit in the head with the broom, the condom salesman IMMERSED his head in some water.

column2:

column5: Remember the wheat we cut with scythes (farmer's equivalent of a saber) for profit (#906)?　Well, we harvested too much and have to use the surplus for silage. 過剰 (かじょう) : excess.

column2:

column4: The moon has a lot of gall sticking around after sunrise.
column5: All the month long I have to start working at nightbreak. This really activates my gall bladder (=I get angry).

column5: At the time of Thanksgiving, there´s a row of all sorts of food on the table, which you mustn´t eat if you want to stay as slender as a thread.

column2:

句: phrase; clause; sentence; passage; paragraph; counter for haiku
column4: The new My Little Ponies show is all about magic horses who utter cute catch phrases.
column5: A particular My Little Pony has a string that when you pull it, it repeats the same dumb phrase like "I love you".

column5: Warning to Sigfreid and Roy: Your entertainment contract will be null and void unless you can make all the tigers stand in a row.

column2:

column5: When it rains, two worlds come together and spirits can be seen in the forest, dancing in a row.

column2:

column4: For all have sinned... so everyone´s state of mind should be to repent.
column5: When you repent, you heal your state of mind by going over every thing you regret doing.

column2:

column4: Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind.
column5: Data feels wretched because he has no family to visit.

column2: 虍: tiger spots; mottled; tiger or tiger crown radical (no. 141)

column5: The "E" shape actually means claws here, and the real etymology is a tiger tyrannizing other animals with its claws (the etymologies actually make sense once in a blue moon!). I think of the claws here as two hooks, representing the front paws. (stroke order of that part: 二＋last of 直).

column2:

column5: When the birds out the back are playing dice, they flip their feathers (not their finger) at their opponents.

column2:
