column5: The regiment led by horny Miss Piggy wearing a viking helmet accidently falls off The Pinnacle and crashes into the ground below. // old story with wrong meaning of regiment: Kermit is so frustrated with horny Miss Piggy´s regimented sex schedule, he throws her off The Pinnacle and she crashes into the ground.

column2:
水: water
召: seduce; call; send for; wear; put on; ride in; buy; eat; drink; catch (cold)
column4: The marshlands near Mordor seduce Frodo into gazing upon them, and he falls into the water--splash!
column5: A marsh is where water is seduced into the ground.

column2:
手: hand
居: reside; to be; exist; live with
column4: The man set his finger firmly on the map and said "Here is where they reside, I am certain of it".
column5: Cf. reside (#1063): you set the flag with your fingers on the place where you reside: an old tradition.

column2:
彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)
余: too much; myself; surplus; other; remainder
column4: You can´t expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually.
column5: I set up a column chart next to my scales so I could record my weight gradually changing.

column2:
手: hand
荅: adzuki beans; thick
column4: Ok, this is a little wierd, but i took this back to the kanji for pagoda (#254). I think it helps simplify the image, and also helps anchor the pagoda kanji in memory better as an added bonus. say this aloud once, and i think it will bring out a vivid image very quickly: "Now boarding the pagoda ride. Please keep your fingers inside at all times...".
column5: When you board the ship on the way out from Hawaii a beautiful crewmember takes her fingers and fits a lei around you ....a lei is flowers fitted together with your fingers.

column2:
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
十: ten
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: You paint 10 huge eyes on your shield to scare the enemy, but consequently your shield is so big and heavy that you have to drag it.
column5: From Wikipedia: "If a Spartan hoplite were to return to Sparta alive and without his shield, it was assumed that he threw his shield at the enemy in an effort to flee; an act punishable by death or banishment." Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield.

column2:
水: water
竜: dragon; imperial
column4: The Water Dragon dwells in the waterfall.
column5: Ever went under a waterfall, vase in hand, trying to catch eels from the water as it pours down?

column2:
車: car
九: nine
column4: My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.
column5: I got my car stuck in a rut ! I´m gonna have to call 999 !

column2:
女: woman; female
方: direction; person; alternative
column4: Capt. Jack Sparrow´s compass gets disturbed every time a beautiful woman walks by him (just picture Keira Knightley in her sexy asian outfit as Elizabeth and the image will be fixed forever).
column5: One way to Disturb a woman is to give her directions while she is in the middle of driving -- she just can´t take that kind of stress.

column2:
手: hand
察: guess; presume; surmise; judge; understand
column4: If you mis-guess the cheese you´ll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).
column5: Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!).

column2:
魚: fish
京: capital; 10**16
column4: If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital.
column5: When the whale was first discovered it was the biggest fish people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire capital city!

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
壮: robust; manhood; prosperity
column4: A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.
column5: The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a villa with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don´t get suspicious.

column2:
言: say
若: young; if; perhaps; possibly; low number; immature
column4: The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.
column5: Delores might say, "Yes!", but she´s way too young give any legal consent.

column2:
雨: rain
田: rice field; rice paddy
column4: If it´s raining and you´re standing in the middle of a rice field, you´re sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal.
column5: Thunder is a sure sign of rain coming. When you hear the thunder, you´ve got time to get out of the field before it starts raining.

column2:
水: water
票: ballot; label; ticket; sign
column4: In Florida, Bush through Kerry´s ballots into the water, watching them drift away and setting the whole country adrift.
column5: The political fanatic stole all the ballots and dumped them in the stream. He calmly watched them drift away as the cops came to a screech behind him.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
十: ten
网: net; net or net crown radical (no. 122)
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
column4: (re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the "New York State of Mind": you need ten eyes to make sure no one will go through your garments and pick your pockets.
column5: Imagine Darth Vader´s state of mind when he discovers his garment has not pockets. " D O NOT WANT!".

column2:
甚: tremendously; very; great; exceedingly
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
column4: Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind.
column5: Using Zareon´s story for the previous frame "tremendously"... The two chessplayers who are eachother´s equals are so good at chess that they don´t have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don´t even have to think, really. Their intuition takes control. This is: extreme chess.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
戈: halberd; arms; festival car; float; tasselled spear radical (no. 62)
木: tree; wood
column4: The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.
column5: During Thanksgiving, all the trees on the plantation celebrate the harvest. It´s a good time for them, too.

column2:
手: hand
口: mouth
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: Wrap your FINGERS around someone´s MOUTH to keep them quiet, then put the KNIFE to their throat to ensure their cooperation. This is the best way to KIDNAP someone.
column5: After you beckon (#650) someone by seducing them, you kidnap them and hang them upside down (the reversed positions of seduce).

column2:
馬: horse
太: plump; thick; big around
column4: If a passenger is too plump and heavy, its too burdensome for the horse.
column5: If your horses get so plump to be good for nothing they just become burdensome.

column2:
水: water
忝: grateful; indebted
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Hawaii is a little drop of heaven nestled in the waters of the Pacific, most often visited by honeymooners and valentines. It was annexed to the U.S.A. in 1959, and more recently to Japan as well-- albeit only unofficially, and through private commercial holdings.
column5: Annexed to the U.S.A. in 1898, Hawaii is nestled in the waters of the Pacific, a little drop of heaven, often visited on Valentines.. (from Ihatobu with the date corrected. Hawaii became a state in 1959)...

column2:
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
元: beginning; former time; origin
column4: Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".
column5: A crown, from the beginning of the new king´s life, is glued to him. He must inherit it.

column2:
余: too much; myself; surplus; other; remainder
斗: Big Dipper; 10 sho (vol); sake dipper; dots and cross radical (no. 68)
column4: The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.
column5: The constellation of libra (meaning " scales" in latin) is diagonal to the handle of the big dipper.

column2:
水: water
良: good; pleasing; skilled
column4: Water is a good thing to have when you´re out wandering.
column5: John the Baptist with a halo sprinkling water on people as he´s wandering the wilderness.

column2:
二: two; two radical (no.2)
口: mouth
column4: In Asian countries, people use II chopsticks to get things into their mouths. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.
column5: A mouth barred up and not aloud to speak freely is the sign of asia (korea, China, pakistan etc).

column2:
言: say
乍: though; notwithstanding; while; during; both; all
column4: Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again.
column5: Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
亶: truly; wholly; cordial
column4: A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.
column5: Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.

column2:
動: move; motion; change; confusion; shift; shake
火: fire
column4: A meritorious deed? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe.
column5: Prometheus did a meritous deed for humanity by MOVING FIRE from the gods to us humans.

column2:
麻: hemp; flax
鬼: ghost; devil
column4: This modern version of the witch lives in some hippie community. She smokes a lot of hemp, and spends the day talking to ghosts, which not surprisingly appears only to her.
column5: The witch sold me some hemp that made me see ghosts don´t do drugs.

column2:
酉: west; bird; sign of the bird; 5-7PM; tenth sign of Chinese zodiac; sake radical (no. 164)
州: state; province
column4: Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.
column5: Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will repay the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.

column2:
此: this; current; next; coming; last; past
糸: thread
column4: Stop sitting for so long - or else you'll get those purple threads (veins) on your legs from bad circulation. [link purple with those huge purple, bulging, crawling, worm-like varicose veins .....].
column5: Why is your ass purple? Well, I stopped and sat for a bit on a pile of thread... (I guess it was freshly dyed).

column2:
糸: thread
文: sentence; literature; style; art; decoration; figures; plan; literary radical (no. 67)
column4: The Scottish weave their family crests with thread on plaid fabric.
column5: A family crest sown on to a garment with thread sometimes has a Latin sentence as a motto.

column2:
午: noon; sign of the horse; 11AM-1PM; seventh sign of Chinese zodiac
正: correct; justice; righteous; 10**40
卩: seal radical (no. 26)
column4: Wholesale refers to the sale of goods in quantity to retailers for resale. When this kanji was invented, large loads of goods needed to be transported by horses who left steep footprints because of the weight they carried. The wholesale goods needed a special stamp to indicate that they were legal for resale.
column5: If you need horseshoes (shoes that fit your horse´s footprint), buy them at the wholesale shop. They lick and paste stamps in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later.

column2:
木: tree; wood
闌: rise high; be well along
column4: [column; handrail; blank; space] I think about oriental (eastern) Torii gates: they have two supporting columns made of wood.
column5: A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.

column2:
免: excuse; dismissal
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Word play to differentiate elude/evade: elude ~= e-lewd. Alice is following Mr. Rabbit on the road. Mr. Rabbit flashes her in a lewd way and disappears, completely eluding her.
column5: Even though the white rabbit was late, he eluded the wrath of the the Queen of Hearts because Alice was coming up the road.

column2:
水: water
厓: precipice; shore; bank; surname; cliff
column4: Try to reverse Heisig´s story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant horizon is nothing but water.
column5: From the water, I can see the ivy-clad-cliffs on the horizon.

column2:
手: hand
石: stone
column4: A huge index finger coming down from the sky is kicking boulders of rock, clearing the land. Maybe it´s the finger of God preparing a place for his little people to live.
column5: I imagine clearing the land in order to set up your tent after a long day of backpacking. Using your fingers, you pick up all of the rocks and get them out of the way so that you can get a comfortable night sleep. If you don´t clear the land you can just picture the rock sticking into your back as you toss and turn all night long.

column2:
并: put together
瓦: tile; gram
column4: A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.
column5: To solve this puzzle all you need is to put the flower pot on top of the proper tile. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).

column2:
犬: dog
言: say
犬: dog
column4: The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.
column5: The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being ´initiated´ by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.

column2:
小: little; small
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
口: mouth
column4: An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.
column5: Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? That was Obi-Wan´s trick to get Luke to build his self-esteem, or his confidence in the Force.

column2:
周: circumference; circuit; lap
彡: three; hair ornament; short hair or fur radical (no. 59)
column4: A lathe is used to carve a shape with circumference into wood or metal.
column5: Start with a circumference and carve away until you get the shape you want.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)
爪: claw; nail; talon
彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: The farmer is calm knowing that his wheat fields are protected from vultures by his strawman with a heart (all the better to do the job properly).
column5: This whole kanji is a picture of calmness. The wheat has been harvested and even the vultures sit calmly watching the humans sweep and clean-up after the harvest is over. Hearts are peaceful and calm at this time of the year. Even the days are calm without storm.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
頁: page; leaf
column4: Somebody's head appears from behind the laundry in a row drying under the sun
column5: Clouds were covering the sky for months now. Rows upon rows of people spent whole days with their heads turned upwards, waiting for sun to appear.

column2:
工: craft; construction; katakana e radical (no. 48)
丂: obstruction of breath (qi) as it seeks release; variant of other characters
column4: Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I´ll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device.
column5: To be adroit one must have mastered the crafting of snares.

column2:
予: beforehand; previous; myself; I
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
column4: マオ Zedong always carried a halberd.
column5: Make the halberd a heroic warrior (perhaps of scandinavian origin) who weilds this polearm - the most effective, brutal and vicious one - with great skill. He can use it to hook, pierce and chop (the three strokes).

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
亘: span; request
column4: Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.
column5: The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.

column2:
其: that
欠: lack; gap; fail; yawning radical (no. 76)
column4: He escaped using deceit. That is, he ran past while the guard was yawning and hid in the bushel basket.
column5: Every day, a smuggler takes bushel baskets on donkeys across the border. But the border patrols can never arrest him for lack of evidence no matter how much they search the bushel baskets: they can´t find whatever he is smuggling. What was his deceit? He was smuggling donkeys!

column2:
金: gold
勺: ladle; one tenth of a go; dip
column4: All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I´m a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I´m a true ANGLING professional.
column5: Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago angling with a golden ladle instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because ´angling´ is just the roman-derived way to say ´fishing´ - use this to distinguish fishing from angling.).

column2: 缶: can, jar radical (no. 121)
column4: Horses kept in the mountains have a unique savory taste. At least so the text on this tin can would have us believe, which contains 100% authentic mountain horse.
column5: The starving horse, stranded on the mountain, is forced to eat a tasty tin can.

column2:
米: rice; USA; metre
庄: level
column4: Condy Rice is actually white, but she uses special cosmetics made from dirt she found in a cave to appear black - it´s better for the political situation.
column5: Modern cosmetics are just the descendants of the old RICE flour and CAVE DIRT (´cause it´s darker) used in the past.

column2:
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: On Vessels that travel long distances, sailors often get quite lonely. They keep TURKEYS on the VESSELS, but not for use as food. The lonely sailors take turns enjoying the turkey´s CROTCH.
column5: Donald Duck is a big bird that does not wear pants. It´s good to use him as a mnemonic because he is a sailor, and this kanji is used to count vessels.

column2:
聿: brush; finally; self; relate; follow; here; fast; writing brush radical (no. 129)
米: rice; USA; metre
column4: Even though it´s a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts.
column5: Note: This is not sieve as it has a full rice and not rice grains and the hook is missing from rake. Also the given stroke order is incorrect (fenceposts should come last).

column2:
禺: long-tailed monkey
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Don´t be foolish! says Jiminy Cricket as he lashes you with his belt. Follow logic, like me, not your heart.
column5: I simply imagine Jiminy Cricket jumping all over the place, like a mad man, yelling "yeeeeehaaaaa!". Maybe he just fell in love? Mnemonic - "Jiminy Cricket has a foolish heart".

column2:
曹: cadet; friend
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.
column5: Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an "encounter of the third kind" on the road. Reference to Steven Spielberg´s 1977 movie "Close Encounters of the Third Kind". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO´s while driving on the road.

column2:
加: add; addition; increase; join; include; Canada
木: tree; wood
column4: Instant wood. Just add Viagra.
column5: I´m not sure I know about erector sets or tinker toys but I do know about jenga. You play by taking wooden pieces from the middle of a wooden tower and adding them to the top. In this way you erect a very unstable structure.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
田: rice field; rice paddy
儿: legs radical (no. 10)
厶: I; myself; katakana mu radical (no. 28)
column4: 鬼(おに) is not a ghost. An ogre or a troll would be a more fitting translation. Such a thing has but a drop of brains and uses its legs and elbows as deadly weapons (a concept which should be familiar from the license (#765) to kill). I'll use "ogre" for this.
column5: A ghost, or oni, wandering slowly on its human legs, searching for brains to eat. What looks like an elbow here is actually a pictoral representation of the forked tail protruding out of its rear.

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
廿: twenty; 20
火: fire
column4: Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.
column5: If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: I can´t believe I brought you to the fanciest restaurant in town and you asked for turkey on wheat...how immature is that?!
column5: Immature turkeys are stuffed with wheat to make it look bigger.

column2:
水: water
茲: here
column4: Water is doubly mysterious. It´s in all our nourishment...and yet, it´s really not nourishing at all.
column5: Going off the idea of the right side meaning rapid growth/increase of small objects, I´ve decided to make the right side be Gremlins, those little mysterious creatures that double rapidly. Gremlins find water a little too nourishing, as it makes them instantly multiply.

column2: 幺: short thread radical (no. 52)
column4: After the play, The Phantasm of the Opera hangs up his cape on a clothes hanger and returns to his cocoon to sleep.
column5: You open your closet and find strange, glowing cocoons sitting on your clothes hangers... definitely a phantasm!

column2:
者: someone; person
火: fire
column4: I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use "puppet." So i thought of "voodoo doll" but then found "love doll" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit...
column5: There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a puppet over an oven fire, to really make your victim feel the heat!

column2:
女: woman; female
臣: retainer; subject
column4: Princess Leia becomes Jabba´s slave (“princess Leia is a woman slave”).
column5: Cinderella: A woman who was a slave who became a princess.

column2:
折: fold; break; fracture; bend; yield; submit
言: say
column4: This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- "the folded words are vows". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive "fold".
column5: A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with origami cranes with their vows written on the BOTTOM.

column2:
手: hand
巴: comma-design
column4: Japanese censorship laws require pornos to use a mosaic screen, so you can´t see what the porno chick is grasping with her fingers (but you can assume, neetch).
column5: Your fingers grasp the Rubic´s cube... if only your brain could too.

column2:
足: leg; foot; be sufficient; counter for pairs of footwear
戔: damage; remain; slight
column4: The pirate with the wooden leg chased after the parade float and was run over by the next one, leaving tread marks all over him and his leg.
column5: Pirates must tread carefully when walking on parade floats, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their wooden legs.

column2:
口: mouth
玉: jewel; ball
column4: The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.
column5: What a pathetic display! The king is sprawled on his throne, head back and mouth wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night.

column2:
疋: head; counter for animals
束: bundle; sheaf; ream; tie in bundles; govern; manage; control
column4: [True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.
column5: This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.

column2:
人: person
卬: lofty; high; raise; high-priced
column4: Mr T with the post package at the post office: ´these stamps don´t stick to the box, foo´ Postguy:´ Try it again but this time with the stamp, face-up.´.
column5: Mr. T, his "acting career" in its twilight, must now FACE-UP to the fact that his mug will never appear on a BOX of cereal or on a STAMP.

column2:
岡: mount; hill; knoll
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: Mount everest is very sturdy, you can hit it all day with a saber and it wont even wobble.
column5: Anything sturdy in Japan is associated with Mount Fuji. Perhaps this is because it´s symmetry is believed to make it rather sturdy itself, unlike all those crooked mountains that are around and tend to fall apart (think rock slides, avalanches, etc.). Here we see Sturdy-brand sabers with Mount Fuji engraved on the blade.

column2:
疒: trailing sickness; sick radical (no. 104)
矢: dart; arrow
column4: I picture a sick caveman, and two people rapidly blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how rapidly they fire.
column5: If shot with a poison dart, sickness develops rapidly.

column2:
彳: stop; linger; loiter; going man radical (no. 60)
正: correct; justice; righteous; 10**40
column4: America seeks to GO and CORRECT other nations. But really what they do is subjugate them...
column5: To subjugate is to have somebody stand still and stiff as a column and behave one hundred percent correctly.

column2:
石: stone
卆: soldier; private; die
column4: To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.
column5: The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they´ve done a new SMASH hit!

column2:
言: say
䍃: a vase; a pitcher; earthenware
column4: Noh chanting?!? I meant "NO CHANTING!" Now all you, just shut up! Not another word! Don´t you know that chanting can provoke attacks from the local condor? So, no chanting, and especially no Noh chanting.
column5: Picture guy dressed in a condor mask up on stage during Noh performance chanting some words nobody understands.

column2:
女: woman; female
家: house; home; family; professional; expert; performer
column4: Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she´s married into the house than into a relationship.
column5: Traditionally, it was the women who would marry into the households of their husband´s families.

column2:
言: say
兼: concurrently; and
column4: When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better.
column5: Though the man´s words were self-effacing, his actions concurrently made it clear that his modesty was false.

column2:
口: mouth
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
口: mouth
夫: husband; man
column4: A sigh escapes the mouth of the scarecrow, who laments: "...if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji".
column5: I will let out a huge sigh of relief from my mouth when I learn the last kanji.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)
column4: Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-).
column5: Actually it means germs as in microorganisms. So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn´t exposed to other plants. That way it can´t catch any germs (like fungi) from them.

column2:
金: gold
兼: concurrently; and

column5: There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a bottle of whiskey, you may get some revelations about their cruelty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.

It was in this corridor that Luke met Darth Vadar, cut off his head and found himself behind Darth Vadar´s mask. An early little hint that Luke was Darth Vadar´s son.

column2:

column4: The unmarried uncle´s house is the picture of lonlieness.
column5: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...

column2:

column2:

He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of corn : a bonsai - corn (a corn plant turned into a bonsai). The god was infuriated and yelled at him "HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!". The End.

column5: This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His crown of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his head and his heart. His walking legs can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How MELANCHOLY!

column5: A skeleton by the side of the road, holding a sign "Possess marrow, will travel". Yeah, it makes no sense but I don´t foget the kanji.

(a fitting end for a wicked wizard).
column5: Tigger, the tiger, (from Pooh stories) is happy to have found a magic wand. Using it he can bounce up to a the top of a cliff, seven times as high as some human legs could bounce. Tigger thinks "Its great to be a tiger!

So, a story: in the O-Bon festival, so many dishes are broken that all the parts have to be thrown into a deep oceanic basin.

column5: The "ear of a plant" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- "the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat".

He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in just so - there, I think it´s good enough. Pull it out -----yes! Success!

column2:

column5: Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand... he´s asking the bystander if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!).

column2:

Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as "flu", "plague", etc.
column5: SICKNESS / MISSILE ** Hint: True fact about biochemical warfare: in the medieval and ancient world, SICKNESS in the form of the corpses of those who had died from some EPIDEMIC or plague were often hurled at the enemy via the crude MISSILE launchers of the time. [C].

column2:

column5: (dingomick) Venom is upset because Spidey is just that much brainier than he is! He chooses to accumulate as many brains as he can, snatching them out of people´s heads and storing them on top of his own, till there´s just one massive brain on top of his head!

column2:
疒: trailing sickness; sick radical (no. 104)

column4: Of course caveman is stupid. He doesn´t know anything. He´s a caveman!
column5: This kanji shows stupidity as a "knowledge-sickness". Everybody can be stupid at times, and it usually happens because of a lack of experience. Hence the stupidity is a "knowledge sickness".

column2:

column4: When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a ´finger carrier´ in that case.
column5: During WWII, morse code was the primary means of communication from sea. The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code).

column2:

column4: (Think rpg!) We were in dire need of healing. Our party was fighting the cavemen, but we didn't fare too well. It was more like a butcher's meeting than a fight... just as they were about to pierce my heart, luckily a priest came along and used his healing spell in the nick of time (#2433).
column5: Note: meeting of butchers + heart are later combined into 愈 in the nick of time (#2433). Story: For healing to take place, you must catch the sickness in the nick of time.

column2:

column5: Even the tall kids can´t get out of the enclosure that is the city walls.

column5: Ugh, why does this shelf feel so coarse? Because it´s made of rice, of coarse! Get it? Of coarse?? Hahahahahahahahahah god i hate my life.

The hostess brings out a dish of hors d´oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, "I´d RATHER not.".
column5: Rather a house with a heart than an eye with a spike.

column5: A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think "Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers" from Star Wars).

column5: Someone with a razor blade stuck in their heart has to endure the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.

column5: Lead -> Dental fillings -> Metal that enters the mouth to fill a hole in a tooth.

column5: King Vermillion is a little queer and likes to wear pearl necklaces.

column4: I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox.
column5: Is there any doubt that ice is congealed stuff?

column2:

column4: If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.
column5: Crap! There are flowers in the rice field... Who let those seedlings get in there?!

column2:

口: mouth

column4: The owl looks for its prey in the rice field. It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006).
column5: I have a strange story for this one but it works. I imagine a owl getting into a rice field which serves as a boxing ring. His opponent is a little chihuahua. The fight starts, the owl takes one punch to the mouth and is out cold. In the chihuahua´s corner is that coach from Rocky saying "Your an ANIMAL!!". A vivid image of this story works pretty well for me.

column2:
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
口: mouth
column4: One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can´t see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it´s cool. I think it´s pathetic.
column5: A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun "pathos." The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos.

column2:
足: leg; foot; be sufficient; counter for pairs of footwear
兆: portent; 10**12; trillion; sign; omen; symptoms
column4: A girl with a wooden leg always wanted to play hopscotch with the other girls, but every time she tried to hop she´d lose her balance and injure another girl. That´s why the other girls make fun of her and see her presence as a portent to injury.
column5: A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.

column2:
匚: box-on-side enclosure radical (no. 22)
斤: axe; 1.32 lb; catty; counter for loaves of bread; axe radical (no. 69)
column4: Hint: Artisan/Ax Def: An artisan is a skilled manual worker; a craftsperson. Here we see his tools represented by the artisan's ax stored in his toolbox.
column5: We here have the axe-man who´s an artisan at making sculptures with his axe... The only thing is, he never shows anyone, keeping all his sculptures inside a box down in the basement. He doesn´t want any attention.

column2:
虫: insect; bug; temper
它: other
column4: A snake eats insects and he does that outside, while we eat another snake in the house and preferably with a spoon.
column5: Solid Snake crawled like a bug, infiltrated my house, and took out everyone with a spoon.

column2:
水: water
登: ascend; climb up
column4: Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.
column5: A few drops of acid/peyote and the Indians obtain lucidity on their vision quest, as if they were floating in the lucid sky.

column2:

逢: meeting; tryst; date; rendezvous
column4: Pointy primitive; with a pointy needle you sew a road (-------) of threads.
column5: Good thing I brought some thread, cause I need to sew my pants that I tore up walking through the bushes (see summit (#1562)) before we hit the road to go back down the mountain.

column2:
人: person
曽: formerly; once; before; ever; never; ex-
column4: While a waiter at the Buddhist temple (see FRAME 976), Mr T increases in wisdom and becomes a Buddhist priest.
column5: Mr. T and the artist formerly known as Prince, who by the way is a buddhist, want to form a new heavy metal band. Instead of "Judas Priest" they will be called "Buddhist Priest".

column2:
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
兆: portent; 10**12; trillion; sign; omen; symptoms
column4: Sauron´s One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.
column5: You lost a staring contest with a turtle because you blinked your eye before he did. (The contest wasn´t fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don´t need to blink so often.) Eye comes first, because stare is most associated with eyes. And compare with challenge (#658) where this same obstreperous turtle challenges you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl´s story with some notes that helped me).

column2:
广: dotted cliff radical (no. 53)
彑: pig's head radical variant (no. 58)
口: mouth
column4: Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, "What about this – T´ang, do you think?" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, "Yes, it does tang a bit".
column5: Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it´s tasty or not.

column2:
口: mouth
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, "My uncle gave me this watch." Following -て form of another verb, means "to do the favor of": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, "Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?" Usu. written in hiragana.
column5: I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!

column2:
几: table; table enclosure; table or windy radical (no. 16)
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: A drop of breeze is naught but a mediocre wind.
column5: Is there anything as mediocre as a drop of piss in the wind?

column2:
舌: tongue; reed; clapper
息: breath; respiration; son; interest (on money)
column4: Recess to me is a school break. At recess some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!
column5: Ah recess; tongues slandering, noses being turned up, and beneath it all, young hearts being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first.

column2:
女: woman; female
爰: lead on to; therefore; then
column4: You want to know about a beautiful woman? There´s a woman that´s so beautiful, the birds migrate to her instead of the sun!
column5: As I saw the most beautiful woman on Earth, a flock of migrating ducks passed by and let their poop fly. That just ruined the moment...

column2:
水: water
冓: put together; inner palace
column4: A gutter funnels water.
column5: A gutter takes the water that falls as rain and funnels it off to where it can be dealt with appropriately.

column2:
共: together; both; neither; all; and; alike; with
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: If you wanna stay together you have to show your valentine respect.
column5: As I like Aretha Franklin's song "R-E-S-P-E-C-T", I cut out each of the letters from pieces of card, then string them all together and send it to her as a valentine.

column2:
乂: mow; cut grass; subdue
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: A SABRE is used to cut the stalks of plants being REAPED at harvest. They are then combined into a SHEAF.
column5: The Grim Reaper´s name is メリ(Mary)…

column2:
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
垂: droop; suspend; hang; slouch
column4: Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.
column5: Hint : the eyes of Droopy Dog (see droop (#1582)). When you are drowsy you have "droopy eyes". That is, you have Droopy´s eyes!

column2:
金: gold
昔: once upon a time; antiquity; old times
column4: A long time ago, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.
column5: Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.).

column2:
人: person
白: white
column4: If Mr T was white I am sure he would have been commander in chief of the USA, he just the sort of clown Americans love to vote for. (NB: I tried with the indian chief motif but kept adding feathers by mistake).
column5: Mr T was originally supposed to be the chief of the A-Team, but then the producers realized that America didn´t want to see a Black guy as the chief of a prime-time TV show. So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin´ on some crack cocaine. You make the call.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
坴: clod of earth; land
column4: Ancient Japanese built a mausoleum for the "unknown rice farmer". It's on the pinnacle of Mt. Fuji, and it has a statue of a guy with huge walking legs planting rice seedlings as he goes.
column5: At the pinnicle is a mausolem. The ground is sown with rice seedings to stop the dead from rising on walking legs.

column2:
雨: rain

column4: This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.
column5: FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.

column2:

column4: When you die, your SOUL either goes to the RISING CLOUDS (heaven) or to the ONI (hell, the devil).
column5: When we die, our soul rises up in a ghostlike rising cloud of mist up to heaven (we hope) (Adapted from darg_sama,28-10-2005).

column5: You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to ABUSE your plants by shredding them into wood chips.

column2:
女: woman; female

column4: Cleopatra.
column5: Be careful you don´t pick up a drag queen at a club - they might look like women, but they have a snake down there!

column2:

column5: A liner is to boat as an emperor (#261) is to a king (#255), or a chief (#967) is to a person (#951): in each case we need only add white to the latter in order to get the former.

column2:

column4: All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to eat, but their ego (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!
column5: He starves for FOOD but his EGO won´t let him beg.

column4: Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.
column5: This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.

column2:

column4: It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I´ve gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.
column5: We have a shelf in our house where we put Christmas cards from people who send best regards for the holiday season...

column2:

column5: The sign of the dragon falls off the cliff, to our great embarassment (see sign of the dragon (#2008)) We should have glued it there!

column2:

column5: Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. Few people realize the harm they can cause just by losing control of their car for a second. Tremendous harm. Stay in control!

column5: To catch a monkey, chase him with wild dogs into a lidded crock, then tie it with a scarf.

column5: Here we have a Hole and Climax to mean PLUG UP. This is so butt-f**king easy, pun intended. If you PLUG UP her Hole, she will Climax.

column4: Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi.
column5: This character shows the difference between a cook and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a cook only stands there with a pan over a fire, with no passion and just yawning.

column5: I put my fingers in my ears to avoid going deaf while getting a vicarious thrill from watching kids light off sparklers and fireworks on Chinese New Year.

column2:

column4: My gluttony was only sated after I ate the hamburger AND the wrapper!
column5: This guy is sated only after eating the hamburger AND its wrapping!

column2:

几: table; table enclosure; table or windy radical (no. 16)
column4: The king´s crown was blown off by the wind. "Oh well," he said, "it´s just a superfluous symbol.".
column5: The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King´s court. This kanji is read as "JOU" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-employee (#56).

column2:
木: tree; wood
兆: portent; 10**12; trillion; sign; omen; symptoms
column4: The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.
column5: King Koopa consistently captures Princess Peach. Eventually he´s going to run out of castles and just set her in a tree.

column2:
犬: dog

column4: Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard.
column5: After a pack of wild dogs hunt some food, they will guard it fiercely.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
未: un-; not yet; hitherto; still; even now; sign of the ram; 1-3PM; eighth sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: It´s autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.
column5: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (未)[correction wrong character before] vermilion (朱).

column5: A whirlpool is water opening its jaws to swallow anything whole.

申: have the honor to; sign of the monkey; 3-5PM; ninth sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire.
column5: From the fairy tale ‘emperor’s new clothes.’ sire, i know you say it's made of the finest threads, but i’m afraid someone has made a monkey of you.

column2:

column4: Make sure you install the hinge the right way. If it opens treeward (= tree ward), you won't be able to get the fence open, make sure it opens houseward.
column5: You notice a hinge on a tree and realize there´s a secret door. You open it up to find an Xbox!!!

column2:

column4: There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.
column5: A STONE makes a LOWLY TOMBSTONE.

column2:

段: grade; steps; stairs

column5: Metal has to be forged many times over in order to reach a high grade.

column2:
吉: good luck; joy; congratulations
豆: beans; pea; midget

column4: Japanese festivals have drums so big, a samurai has to SIT (not stand) on a table to beat one with a tree branch! http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg.
column5: I really hate the primitive meaning of "table" for "bean." I just use "bean." Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: "DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH".

column2:

column5: Hey honey, I´m naked underneath this cloak. I´ve got some nice melons and a fresh peach waiting for you. Don´t you want to taste my forbidden fruits...?

column2:
犬: dog

column4: The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.
column5: I wavered when the pack of wild dogs was blocking the way, but then I drank some Red Bull and charged through. (thanks shakkun).

column2:

column5: All too often I find myself vaccuming clods of dirt with my Dirt Devil.

column2:

column5: Don´t confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner.

column2:

甘: sweet; coax; pamper; be content; sugary
column4: Thanks raulir - As many Japanese perverts know, navy blue threads conceal school girl sweetness underneath.
column5: Much like Violet Beauregarde from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Spiderman failed to heed Willy Wonka´s warnings, and upon chewing on the 3 course meal chewing gum turned a very navy shade of navy blue.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
荒: laid waste; rough; rude; wild
column4: (re: wazzab) The state of mind of the people of New Orleans as they examined their city´s concert hall laid waste can best described as disconcerted.
column5: Data walks in and sees Picard weeping. "What is the matter, Captain?" Picard looks up, and replies that his entire home planet has been laid to waste. Data, the master of tact, offers up this consolation: "Ah. I can see how that would be DISCONCERTing". It turns out that the flow of tears was really just because Picard had lost his chance at getting at some rare (and thus valuable) flowers on his home planet.

column2:
女: woman; female
呉: give; do something for
column4: A woman gives up her recreation time in order to raise a family.
column5: Typical male fantasy of recreation: women "giving it up".

column2:
网: net; net or net crown radical (no. 122)
維: fiber; tie; rope
column4: Lots of girls in Japan wear gauze patches over one eye made of course white fibers. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too.
column5: Rocky won the match but left with a nasty eye injury, and needs some gauze for it. I use a modified version of the Rocky theme song to remember this one -- "the eye and the fiber".

column2:
山: mountain
夾: insert between
column4: A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html.
column5: A kid cuts a gorge into a paper mountain, with a pair of scissors.

column2:
人: person
奉: observance; offer; present; dedicate
column4: The stipend is given to the student-PERSON who has come to Japan DEDICATED to study.
column5: People who are highly dedicated to their jobs get good salaries/stipends.

column2:
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
里: ri; village; parent's home; league
column4: I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it´s worth less than a rin.
column5: A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.

column2:
山: mountain
夂: winter radical (no. 34)
丰: abundant; lush; bountiful; plenty; fat face; luxurious growth of grass
column4: Walking legs over "bushes" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 sew (#1563), 逢 tryst (#2417), 蜂 bee (#2687), and 鋒 sword´s point (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. "Pointy" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain.
column5: Upon reaching the summit of the mountain, I noticed my walking legs were all gouged up from walking through prickly bushes.

column2:
酉: west; bird; sign of the bird; 5-7PM; tenth sign of Chinese zodiac; sake radical (no. 164)
襄: rise; raise
column4: Grass Skirt primitive: Picture some Hawaiian girls, wearing grass skirts and tropical scarfs (or leis), doing a dance. "3, 4, 5, 6 pick up all the celery sticks!".
column5: A classic alcohol commercial: whiskey being brewed while girls dance around, scantily clad in their grass skirts.

column2:
弓: bow; bow (archery, violin)
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier´s weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.
column5: Send your condolences to the old geezer whom you shot the walking stick into with your bow. (see pull (#1232)).

column2: 乙: second, latter, second radical (no. 5)
column4: This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.
column5: You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its fish guts silly!

column2:
水: water
十: ten
column4: To make soup you just take water and add (+) the rest of your ingredients.
column5: To make soup you just take water and add ten tasty ingredients.

column2:
尸: corpse; remains; flag radical (no. 44)
匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
column4: Red cross nuns sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry.
column5: A nun sits in protests under an American flag.

column2:
扁: level; small
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road.
column5: Go down any road in Japan and you´ll find konbini hentai everywhere.

column2:
行: going; journey
魚: fish
column4: To maintain the social equilibrium in a future dystopian society, the brains of citizens are bound up (hypnotized). The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like St. Bernard´s dogs put alongside the boulevards.
column5: I think BALANCE is an easier keyword. I was walking down a busy French boulevard when between the rushing traffic I saw the wierdest thing. BALANCING on the central crash barrier was a St. Bernard dog, BALANCING a fish on its nose. As I looked closer, I realised it was a trick; it was holding the fish´s tail in its teeth, and only pretending to BALANCE it. (keeps the position of the elements!).

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
重: heavy; heap up; pile up; nest of boxes; -fold
火: fire
column4: Do you know how they make those FRAGRANT air fresheners? Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while... (cmp perfume (#493)).
column5: The heavier the flowers the stronger their fragrance when you burn them.

column2:
犬: dog
鼠: rat; mouse; dark gray
column4: [game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (mouse (#2065)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I´ll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it´s hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats.
column5: The WILD DOGS are GAME HUNTING the OWL who flies like the WIND through the CORN STORKS.

column2:
士: gentleman; samurai; samurai radical (no. 33)
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
欠: lack; gap; fail; yawning radical (no. 76)
column4: Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!
column5: For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings.

column2:
門: gate; counter for cannons
兌: exchange
column4: A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you´re evil enough to get in.
column5: As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that´s cheating. Besides, I´m just reviewing things I already know. I won´t fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates.

column2:
人: person
貞: upright; chastity; constancy; righteousness
column4: Mr. T is a terrible spy. He walks around upright. "Why should I hide?! I´ve got nothing to be ashamed of!".
column5: NOTE: The second primitive is upright, not eminent. There is an error in the book.

column2:
口: mouth
曷: why; how; when
column4: If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice.
column5: After taking a siesta, you find that your mouth is hoarse (after all you ARE thirsty remember).

column2:
耳: ear
攴: strike; hit; folding chair radical (no. 66)
column4: Only a truly daring Japanese student would wear a spike in his ear under the gaze of the Japanese teacher taskmasters!
column5: See that ear nailed over there ? It´s the ear of the last person who was too daring with the taskmistress.

column2:
肉: meat
台: pedestal; a stand; counter for machines and vehicles
column4: The body part feminists like to put on a pedestal is the womb, especially when they hear a man complain about some responsibility. "We give birth, so it´s your duty to do so-and-so".
column5: If any body part deserves to be put on a pedestal, it is the womb from which new life springs forth.

column2:
酉: west; bird; sign of the bird; 5-7PM; tenth sign of Chinese zodiac; sake radical (no. 164)
孝: filial piety; child's respect
column4: The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.
column5: Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn´t, sink back some whiskey and it will.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
賁: decorate
column4: Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn´t seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!
column5: Data was aroused/indignant when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their haystacks and the fishermen collecting their shells . The tragedy of it all aroused him so much he didn´t even notice he was feeling emotion.

column2:
肉: meat
豕: pig; hog; pig radical (no. 152)
column4: Pork comes from the flesh of a sow.
column5: One possible pictograph for "sow" primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow´s legs.

column2:
庶: commoner; all; bastard
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!
column5: If don´t want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a commoner while traveling on the road.

column2:
戸: door; counter for houses; door radical (no. 63)
非: un-; mistake; negative; injustice; non-
column4: The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.
column5: An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers "Which door?", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - "The front door !".

column2:
石: stone
㐬: a cup with pendants; a pennant; wild; barren; uncultivated
column4: Sulphur is like a rock, but it can stink like a stream of infant doodie.
column5: Infants are baptised in streams inorder to prevent their descent into a place of sulphur and brimstone.

column2:
赤: red
攴: strike; hit; folding chair radical (no. 66)
column4: The student blushed until his face was red, so the schoolmaster decided to pardon him.
column5: There aren´t many pardons given by the Red taskmasters in China. 80% of the world´s death penalties are performed there...

column2:
穴: hole; aperture; slit; cave; den
切: cut; cutoff; be sharp
column4: This more commonly means "steal", like how a thief cuts a hole to steal the jewels.
column5: Stealth bombers cut holes through the enemy radar.

column2:
水: water
包: wrap; pack up; cover; conceal
column4: When water forms a bubble, it wraps a pocket of air.
column5: To prevent people from popping bubble wrap for fun, the post office has started filling the bubbles with water.

column2: 又: again, right hand, right hand radical (no. 29)
column4: After her boyfriend´s crotch has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, "Or again, we could fool around . . . ".
column5: This keyword should really be "again" not "or again" Here is some context: think of the phrase "Jya mata" "じゃ又" which is a farewell similar to "then again". Also "Mata ne" "又ね" and mata ashita (again tomorrow) "又明日"。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out "mata" except for in the last example: 又明日.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
既: previously; already; long ago
column4: If you don´t leave some silver as a tip, you will rue the day you earned the resentment of your waitress.
column5: The resentment of a waitress who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). She rues that decision ever since she got dumped by him (just after he graduated).

column2:
糸: thread
方: direction; person; alternative
column4: Spiderman can spin his webs in any direction.
column5: You keep me spinning right round, baby right round, like a compass baby. Spidey is making a retro 80s music video, spinning right round on his giant compass, singing his favourite song.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
column4: The athlete´s state of mind is nothing but resentment after getting the silver medal.
column5: Data´s greatest resentment is getting a silver medal in Science Olympiad. (Image: Data fuming on the podium muttering about being half robot).

column2:
肉: meat
方: direction; person; alternative
column4: Flesh in all directions = obese.
column5: Yo momma so obese, she changed the direction of the moon.

column2:
手: hand
夫: husband; man
column4: Using his finger the husband sometimes is an erotic aid to his partner.
column5: In Homer Simpsons´ house, the first aid kit is usually used for when he smashes his fingers trying to build something (there are countless Simpsons episodes you can draw from for this).

column2:
虚: void; emptiness; unpreparedness; crack; fissure; untruth
戈: halberd; arms; festival car; float; tasselled spear radical (no. 62)
column4: This is a story about the end of the universe. The universe is turning into a featureless void. There´s nothing we can do about it except for throw a fiesta and frolic a little bit before it´s all over.
column5: Sigfreid and Roy´s contract having been voided, the tiger is free to frolic about at the fiesta.

column2:
己: self; snake; serpent
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was MOURNING the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.
column5: You are mourning the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. -- "mourning feels like snake-bitten heart".

column2:
水: water
蜀: green caterpillar; Szechwan
column4: The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing "Help me, Help Me" under the watchful eye of the spider who´s venom is dripping like water from her fangs.
column5: Pour water over the eyes of a bound up insect if you want to hear a pitiful buzz that is very similar to a VOICED consanant.

column2:
大: large; big
卉: grass
column4: Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.
column5: A bustle is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here´s a St. Bernard dog jammed ass-first into the top of a haystack, looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out.

column2: 丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.
column5: Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?

column2:
卂: to fly rapidly
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.
column5: In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero ´froggy´ forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait.

column2:
小: little; small
月: month; moon
column4: Using DNA matching, a very little bit of flesh can be used to show the resemblence between family members.
column5: Hey baby, it might be a little bit of flesh now, but in a moment it´ll bear a strong resemblance to a candlestick.(nudge nudge, wink wink).

column2:
金: gold
本: book; present; main; origin; true; real; counter for long cylindrical things
column4: This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?
column5: If I was begging with a BOWL, I would want GOLD and BOOKS.

column2:
木: tree; wood
丂: obstruction of breath (qi) as it seeks release; variant of other characters
column4: This snare isn´t terribly effective, because it´s swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess.
column5: 枯 wither The decay of an animal in the TREE was from something caught in a SNARE.

column2:
壳: casing; shell; husk
殳: pike; windy-again radical (no. 79)
column4: Samurai´s husk/shell/armour is superflous to missile attacks 甲殻　卵殻　貝殻.
column5: husk or shell. Japan´s recent history in a nutshell: first the samurai became superfluous and then the Americans started to throw missiles and bombs during WWII.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
口: mouth
子: child; sign of the rat; 11PM-1AM; first sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention.
column5: Tall children receive all the attention. They also make great receivers in football... this kanji also means ´catch´ (therefore a football receiver is a great image).

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
潘: water in which rice has been washed
column4: This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans´ location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.
column5: In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers.

column2:
水: water
少: few; little
column4: Wet sand is simply sand but to see beautiful grains of sand, the water must be few.
column5: Near the water is one of the few places you will find grains of sand.

column2:
女: woman; female
某: so-and-so; one; a certain; that person
column4: The woman 女 hoped her friend would act as mediator to set her up with the guy she liked. She didn't mention his name, just referred to him as "A certain unnamed person -- I'll call him 'Mr. So-and-So 某' ...."
column5: The two little gossiping girls with their lollipops are having a fight. Now an adult woman (mom or teacher) has to come between them an serve as a mediator.

column2:
奚: servant; what; why
鳥: bird; chicken
column4: There are two types of birds often compared to husbands. Yes there are a few vultures out there, but most husbands are CHICKENS. 鶏 【にわとり】 (n) (domestic) chicken, (P) 鶏肉 【けいにく】 (n) chicken meat, (P).
column5: The vulture´s husband is a chicken...heck...who am I to judge their interspecies love? They´re both birds so its cool.

column2:
示: show; indicate; point out; express; display
単: simple; one; single; merely
column4: Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE.
column5: Simple-minded blond girl (see frame 1928) is very good at Zen, which isn´t surprising since she doesn´t think much. She has this bad habit of meditating perched on the main temple altar, which infuriates the Zen buddhists. When they get up to her and tell her rudely to step down the altar, she just smiles and teases them : "Not very zen are you ?". Who would have thought simple-minded blond girl would teach the Zen buddhists a lesson !

column2:
口: mouth
属: belong; genus; subordinate official; affiliated
column4: Entrust is to confer trust in someone else. My mouth belongs to you and your secret is safely entrusted with me.
column5: If you entrust me with something, my mouth belongs to you.

column2:
肉: meat
同: same; agree; equal
column4: A trunk, a trunk // The body of a monk // The body of a monk in a trunk, a trunk.
column5: Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I´m appalled at how gruesome this story is too.

column2:
失: lose; error; fault; disadvantage; loss
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: When you get lost, you just take an alternate road to get back on track.
column5: When you lose your way, you can always try to tell the wife that you merely took an alternate road. To save time you know. I´m not LOST, I´m just taking an alternate road. Ahem.

column2:
手: hand
千: thousand
十: ten
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field.
column5: Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest.

column2:
山: mountain
風: wind; air; style; manner
column4: Storm is a full-blown wind that rips the mountains off the ground (you see one flying here).
column5: Winds are gathering at the base of the mountain (note the hint to primitive placement), going up, and turning into a huge mountain storm.

column2:
木: tree; wood
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: Why is the sweet oak so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like turkey (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet.
column5: Sweeter than Shiit~ake? Turkeys gobble Shiitake mushrooms椎茸 off the sweet oak tree. 　http://www.flickr.com/photos/tinyhare/13963627/.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
口: mouth
column4: In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they´re needed.
column5: When you climb the pinnacle you´ll need to take a muzzle of auxiliary oxygen.

column2:
立: stand up; rise; set up; erect
口: mouth
刀: sword; saber; knife
column4: When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That´s why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.
column5: Divide and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).

column2:
言: say
普: universal; wide(ly); generally; Prussia
column4: Musical scores are in a universal language.
column5: A musical score can be read, but not like ordinary words. Music is a universal language.

column2:
攸: relaxed; at ease; place
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Mr. T ventured out into a remote area to visit with his wise, old taskmaster who must use a walking stick to get around and originally gave Mr. T the heart to fight crime for the good of the community.
column5: Yoda, the Jedi with the walking stick who was a hard taskmaster for Luke but who had a big heart, was permanently exiled on the remote planet Dagobah.

column2:
水: water
叔: uncle; youth
column4: Uncle (the one who is lonely and coaches kids in his spare time) is actually a graceful guy once he hits the water, as he used to be part of the swimming team in his youth.
column5: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...

column2:
巾: towel; hanging scroll; width; cloth radical (no. 50)
凡: mediocre
column4: When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND.
column5: A towel makes a mediocre sail.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
尭: high; far
column4: The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.
column5: The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.

column2:
人: person
桀: measuring box
column4: My wise person says greatness does not come from wearing shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone.
column5: Mr T stands in front of you, his greatness radiating out from him so brightly. You need to put on your sunglasses and hide behind a tree to even talk to the guy. "Recognise, foo!".

column2:
女: woman; female
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
column4: That GUY stole my WOMAN so I kicked him in the CROTCH. (This story helps keep the word "GUY" as someone you hold in contempt).
column5: Guys only care about 2 things: women and their crotch (preferably at the same time).

column2:
金: gold
定: determine; fix; establish; decide
column4: Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.
column5: The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let´s try this one: My girlfriend wears a metal chastity belt with a lock but I am determined to open it! I must get inside!

column2:
二: two; two radical (no.2)
人: person
手: hand
column4: 1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.
column5: Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of quarters in your hand, your fist will deliver a much more effective punch.

column2:
襾: cover; place on top of; west radical variant (no. 146)
大: large; big
己: self; snake; serpent
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads.
column5: The west has gone through quite a transition, gone are the days when dogs and snakes roamed the desert, it´s all roads and casinos now.

column2:
手: hand
出: exit; leave; go out; come out; put out; protrude
column4: With fingers fumbling around trying to get the key in the door so he could exit, the bungling husband woke his wife as he tried to leave for a rendezvous with his mistress.
column5: Horror movie cliche 769: Bungling victim´s fingers fumble & bungle trying to open the exit door.

column2:
人: person
寺: Buddhist temple
column4: Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: attend (#960)).

The Fellowship of the Ring first tried for the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes above, but were halted by the wizardry of Saruman at Caradhras, and so are forced to take the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes below, through the mountain - a path long feared by Gandalf for the ancient evil that lurks there. Note : the kanji does in fact refer to a "mountain pass".

You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...

The samurai views his sermon as a sieve of character: those of good character pass through and see the merit; those of poor character - slaves to their passions - are blocked from understanding.
