column4: Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).
column5: You need a SCAFFOLD made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.

column2:
女: woman; female
胥: together; mutual; subordinate official
column4: The virgin bridegroom tries to understand the new, mysterious part of his woman´s body - but with little success. It´s a zoo down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is ´down there´ - the woman is ´left´ unsatisfied).
column5: The only reason anyone talks about a bridegroom is if they´re about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your woman to the zoo for a month. Pretty cool honeymoon.

column2:
莫: must not; do not; be not
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: Pining, yearn for... etc. Presumably for lost love. An easy one here, someone standing in the graveyard, placing an old valentine card amonst all the existing tributes.
column5: Morticia and Gomez (of the “Addams Family”) are spending their Valentine´s Day at the graveyard, pining for each other´s affection.

column2:
网: net; net or net crown radical (no. 122)
能: ability; talent; skill; capacity
column4: Hey, screw you! Don´t you look down on me! I have the ability to quit anytime I want!
column5: My eye doesn´t seem to have the ability to quit staring at her...

column2:
矢: dart; arrow
喬: high; boasting
column4: Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man...
column5: The darts of the angel Cupid are supposed to bring people joy, but usually just make things a lot worse. Here we see another angel flying around shooting people with the anti-darts (antidote), to rectify the situation.

column2:
甘: sweet; coax; pamper; be content; sugary
木: tree; wood
column4: I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket.
column5: Two girls with a lollipop in a tree gossiping´ so-and so did this.´ ´really? so-and what did she do´ ´ o she is sooo wrong..´.

column2:
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
人: person
column4: A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.
column5: Mr. T can´t be captured. This kanji is lying.

column2:
虫: insect; bug; temper
工: craft; construction; katakana e radical (no. 48)
column4: Little is it known that a rainbow is actually created by insects of different colours flying in formation, a craft they have perfected to create the rainbows we see today.
column5: Rainbow is of course created by billions of colored insects (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the insect primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this: rainbow is an Insect-Craft. Mnemonic: I.C. Rainbow (I see rainbow).

column2:
水: water
必: invariably; certain; inevitable
column4: Anything full of water will invariably begin to ooze.
column5: When you pierce a heart with a stake, it invariably oozes blood.

column2:
水: water
斬: beheading; kill; murder
column4: I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.
column5: Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.

column2:
虫: insect; bug; temper
文: sentence; literature; style; art; decoration; figures; plan; literary radical (no. 67)
column4: The mosquito (an insect) knows only one sentence: Bzzzzz.
column5: Mosquitoes are the insect who love Scots in plaid kilts because it makes for easy access to the best parts.

column2:
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
卩: seal radical (no. 26)
column4: Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.
column5: Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
澡: wash
column4: Goods + wood = paper. You know how nori, ie: seaweed, comes in sheets for putting in your ramen or for your sushi? Well that's because it's water paper! Seaweed is also a sea flower of sorts, so it all just works out.
column5: Let wooden goods = furniture. Then: Walking along the sea shore you see some washed-up furniture with water (waves) splashing against it. From a distance it looks like flowers are growing out the top, but as you get closer you see it is in fact seaweed.

column2:
女: woman; female
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
古: old
column4: Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.
column5: Your legitimate wife is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes...

column2:
口: mouth
赫: suddenly; brighten; illuminate; light up
column4: To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red).
column5: Tip: Heisig later names 赫 "red + red" as incandescent (#2908). Story: "So the boss upbraided you, huh?". "Yep, his mouth was incandescent.

column2: 凵: open box enclosure; open box radical (no. 17)
column4: When I get vexed, I give people the middle finger.
column5: Convex has a convex shape.

column2:
音: sound; noise
員: employee; member; number; the one in charge
column4: What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.
column5: Dr Seuss´s employee finally rebels against him: "I´m tired of odd sounds all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in RHYME!".

column2:
雨: rain
相: inter-; mutual; together; each other; minister of state; councillor; aspect; phase; physiognomy
column4: FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.
column5: The freezing RAIN formed FROST on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, frost-y then think Frost Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: FROSTY the snowman? It´s RAIN that FROSTS that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.

column2:
石: stone
肖: resemblance
column4: That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.
column5: Salpetre is the common name for Nitrate coming from Latin "sal petrae" or stone salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a candle in this kanji can be quite explosive!

column2:
束: bundle; sheaf; ream; tie in bundles; govern; manage; control
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
column4: This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.
column5: Imperial order carries quite a bundle of executive power.

column2:
木: tree; wood
官: bureaucrat; the government
column4: The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in.
column5: An excellent use of wood is to make coffins for bureaucrats.

column2:
人: person
需: demand; request; need
column4: No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it´s raining combs!".
column5: One day, Mr. T started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a Confucian scholar. He was suddenly in high demand as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, "You will find happiness with a new love".

column2:
秋: autumn
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: In AUTUMN, the farmer´s HEART is in DISTRESS as to if he has enough crops. Even better, the farmer will experience great DISTRESS in his HEART if his WHEAT catches FIRE!
column5: Here we have distressed (think "gloomy") people with "seasonal mood disorder" during the autumn season. Hence "autumn heart" is distressed (gloomy).

column2:
木: tree; wood
婁: frequently; tie
column4: The young taskmaster (see number (#929)) uses a tree as a watchtower to get a better view of his rice-carrying women. "I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!".
column5: On the top of the woodmade watchtower we look for our enemies, who will come to steal our rice and our women.

column2:
丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
column4: The eyebrows hover over the eyes like a divided flag.
column5: Pictograph: opera glasses over eyes ビ ミ まゆ.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
新: new
column4: New flowers grow in areas of forests which have been chopped down for firewood.
column5: If your firewood is too new and still has flowers on it, it´s unsuitable for burning. You need drier wood.

column2:
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
曷: why; how; when
column4: Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in BROWN garments taking a siesta. What can BROWN do for you?
column5: Mexicans use a cloak (pancho) for their siestas. Their color is usually brown.

column2:
貝: shellfish
易: easy; ready to; simple; fortune-telling; divination
column4: A grant is easy money.
column5: Do you want free shells from the government? It´s easy with my new book, "How to Get a Free Grant from the Government!" Call today!

column2:
糸: thread
善: virtuous; good; goodness
column4: After a day being virtuouos and keeping the city safe, Spiderman´s outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do.
column5: Darning is too obscure a word for me, I prefer to just think of it as repair. And obviously, repairing someones broken cloth things is a virtuous thing to do, and you need thread to do it.

column2:
木: tree; wood
全: whole; entire; all; complete; fulfill
column4: The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. "You´ll need the whole tree to plug that gap". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they´re doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the "whole" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).
column5: To plug the hole, you need to use a whole piece of wood - like a cork or something.

column2: 凵: open box enclosure; open box radical (no. 17)
column4: The letter "U" is concavely written.
column5: Concave has a concave shape.

column2:
豊: bountiful; excellent; rich
色: color
column4: To print something with bountiful colour, they use glossy paper.
column5: Glossy prints bring out bountiful colors more so than matte...

column2:
金: gold
東: east
column4: In the East, especially Japan ...there are masters of tempering metal to great strength....on the Spring of Trivia show in Japan I saw how a Japanese sword ...actually split flying bullets...all because of special Eastern tempering techniques.
column5: Tempering should be done with the metal facing east. (If not, the metal may pick up the earth´s magnetic field).

column2:
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
口: mouth
丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.
column5: Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!

column2:
豕: pig; hog; pig radical (no. 152)
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: In association with consummate (#540), our sow is on the road pursuing a mate.
column5: The pig is on the road in the pursue of the turtle who is trying to escape (#283). (See story on escape (#283) & consummate (#540)).

column2:
斤: axe; 1.32 lb; catty; counter for loaves of bread; axe radical (no. 69)
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?
column5: The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there´s one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.

column2:
言: say
召: seduce; call; send for; wear; put on; ride in; buy; eat; drink; catch (cold)
column4: The mnemonic "words to seduce the masses" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus "seducing" the masses.
column5: The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
童: juvenile; child
column4: A paedophile´s state of mind is to yearn for juveniles.
column5: A juvenile´s state of mind tends to go apeshit when they see something they yearn for. Usually involving jumping up and down, tantrums, and other bullshit. (Imagine giving them a big backhand across the face.).

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
肖: resemblance
column4: I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!
column5: I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means "early evening", not "wee hours" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 "but of course" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] "Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours". E.G. 宵の口（よいのくち）early evening; 今宵（こよい）this evening; tonight.

column2:
亡: deceased; the late; dying; perish
女: woman; female
column4: I had a problem with remembering that "deceased" went over the "woman". So, here´s my story: The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.
column5: If you think you should perish for that woman, you have a major delusion.

column2:
酉: west; bird; sign of the bird; 5-7PM; tenth sign of Chinese zodiac; sake radical (no. 164)
勺: ladle; one tenth of a go; dip
column4: At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.
column5: Ever seen the anime Bartender? Bartending isn´t just about bottles of whiskey, it´s about ladling out advice.

column2:
分: part; minute of time; segment; share; degree; one's lot; duty; understand; know; rate; 1%; chances; shaku/100
頁: page; leaf
column4: The PART of my HEAD where I remember the KANJI is in the kanji PARTITION.
column5: The last time I tried to partition a hard drive under Linux, I got a severe migraine that parted my head.

column2:
肉: meat
支: branch; support; sustain; branch radical (no. 65)
column4: The limbs that this kanji represents are parts of the body that are connected to the trunk, like the main branches to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words, limbs are "flesh branches".
column5: Limbs are body parts that branch off.

column2:
朕: majestic plural; imperial we
言: say
column4: Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.
column5: As a prank, a guy sits with his butt flesh on the facsimile machine, inserts a quarter, and tries to fax it to his boss. However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word "asshole". Don´t forget it´s flesh, not words, on the left side; the flesh image gets transformed into words.

column2:
口: mouth
冊: tome; counter for books; volume
司: director; official; govt office; rule; administer
column4: The lawyer called all the heirs into a meeting. Everybody else received cars, property, and the like. When it got to be my turn the lawyer informed me I would be receiving a scrapbook. My mouth dropped open. A scrapbook?! No Ferrari, no mansion, ...scrapbook?! Turns out the scrapbook was of my great uncle's company, and I had been named the new director of the multi-million dollar business. My mouth literally hit the scrapbook when I learned I'd be director.
column5: My mouth hung open when I found out I was the heir to not only my father's scrapbooks, but he also left me as director of the company.

column2:
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
田: rice field; rice paddy
久: long time; old story
column4: Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!
column5: A mummy tries to furrow his brow but realizes that he´s got no head - just a brain with a top-hat on it. So he furrows his brain. [trigger: furrow your brain].

column2:
手: hand
少: few; little
column4: You can extract her juices by inserting a few fingers.
column5: The mafia want to extract information from you. You don´t say a word, so out comes the knife. They cut of your fingers until you only have a few left and then you speak.

column2:
大: large; big
爻: to mix with; to associate with; to join; double X radical (no. 89)
爻: to mix with; to associate with; to join; double X radical (no. 89)
column4: The St Bernard is bracing itself for an operation requiring four stitches.
column5: St. Bernard dog had a refreshing bracing bath and now is shaking all the water out of his fur. The drops are thrown in all direction and that's why the have an x shape in the pictogram.

column2:
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
左: left
月: month; moon
column4: When I am in a LAZY state of mind I use my left hand to play with my meat...it feels like someone else is doing it, which is good cause I´m to lazy to get a date.
column5: When in a lazy state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month.

column2:
亦: also; again
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: The barbarian picks an apple from above and eats it even though there is a worm (insect) in it.
column5: Barbarians eat apples with worms still in them.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
玉: jewel; ball
column4: The Sun King (Louis XIV) was known for his effulgent reign.
column5: [+katsuo] This is the Sun King. Sayeth Wikipedia: "The Sun King (in French le Roi Soleil) because of the idea that, just as the planets revolve around the Sun, so too should France and the court revolve around [the king] ("http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France). And just like the sun, he was quite effulgent and actually emitted sunlight.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
column4: I am ´the one´ , says the samurai with the crown around his waist and a spoon up his a***.
column5: The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.

column2:
玉: jewel; ball
留: detain; fasten; halt; stop
column4: “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.
column5: The king was detained, by men in marine blue; Must be the marines, planning a coup. (thx Katsuo/gavmck).

column2:
人: person
矢: dart; arrow
column4: Marquis Keydartee (make-believe french name, Key+dart+T).
column5: (Going off various) Mr. T. is made a marquis and given the key to the city. But somebody disagrees with it and assassinates him with a dart.

column2:
弓: bow; bow (archery, violin)
瓜: melon
column4: When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are.
column5: Joan of Arc ("arc" also means "bow" in french) is practicing with a bow, shooting at melons in a distant field.

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
付: adhere; attach; refer to; append
column4: A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.
column5: The Pinnacle is firmly affixed to the top of the mount with bubble gum. (adhere (#1000)).

column2:
人: person
旦: daybreak; dawn; morning
column4: However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T.
column5: MR.T leads a busy life, however he always makes sure to be in bed by NIGHTBREAK, however much he might want to stay up watching A-Team re-runs.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
于: going; from
column4: If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster.
column5: If your potatoes are growing flowers, you need to store them in a more dry place, like hanging them on hooks so they don´t accumulate moisture on the floor.

column2:
波: waves; billows; Poland
女: woman; female
column4: An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).
column5: You know "The Old Man and the Sea." Well, this is the sequel, "The Old Woman and the Sea Waves.".

column2:
人: person
放: set free; release; fire; shoot; emit; banish; liberate
column4: Mr T downloads an emulator so that he can play his favorite game, Pokemon. He plays for a different reason, though - he hates to see them poor little foos in the ball so he spends his entire time setting them free.
column5: The black slave who was set free (#496) decides to emulate Mr. T, his role model. He uses his compass to head to Cali to start anew.

column2:
人: person
僉: all
column4: Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.
column5: Khatzumoto needs to be frugal after spending all his money on Japanese media and none on food. His waist has shrunk and he needs a new belt, but being frugal he just punches another hole with his awl.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
糸: thread
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.
column5: The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.

column2:
言: say
曷: why; how; when
column4: The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta.
column5: The man talking during his siesta (in his sleep) is saying strange things and drawing an audience.

column2:
竹: bamboo
固: harden; set; clot; curdle
column4: Dragon Quest - You find a hardened bamboo stick, perfect for a weapon, but you can´t pick it up because your items are full.
column5: You´ve entered in a chinese shop where apparently the only item in sale is old, dusty, hardened bamboo (for construction for example). It looks like these items have been there forever. Asking the clerk if anything else is available, he doesn´t understand and instead asks - "Two items? Three items?" (the kanji is a counter for items) - thinking you want to buy something.

column2:
月: month; moon
一: one; one radical (no.1)
column4: Moreover is a literary term to shelve what you had just been talking about, to come back to it later.
column5: Same as darg_sama. Play on words. I imagine visiting someone who has an impressive collection of medals and trophies (chess champion, for example). After spending an hour showing you all the trophies in the glass shelf, you think "Whew! It´s over." ... but the person says "... and wait, there´s "moreover" !", pointing at more trophies lined atop the glass shelf.

column2:
人: person
支: branch; support; sustain; branch radical (no. 65)
column4: Mr T is dancing and singing and all that, but he´s doing it on a branch. All that talent and can still still keep his balance? That´s a real performing artist.
column5: (note: this is the ´ki´ from kabuki).//The performing artist is a person doing Kabuki theater and dancing around with a branch in his hand.

column2: 斤: axe, axe radical (no. 69)
column4: Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.
column5: The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).

column2:
虍: tiger spots; mottled; tiger or tiger crown radical (no. 141)
呉: give; do something for
column4: I feel a sense of uneasiness about giving this HUGE tiger a steak.
column5: My dear friend, a Bengali merchant, gave me a tiger as a birthday present. I felt uneasiness, knowing that I´ll have to reject it. Or was it horror?

column2:
豸: snake; legless insect; badger or clawed dog radical (no. 153)
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success.
column5: I got sprayed by a skunk, so no one is helping me with the groundbreaking of my farm. On a positive note, I found silver laying all over the soil. Mine all mine!

column2:
爪: claw; nail; talon
木: tree; wood
column4: You ever wondered why this appeared as a primitive in so many RTK1 kanji? Well, you should know that once a vulture grabs hold of a tree, he can never let go. Even Heisig couldn´t shake him loose.
column5: A common meaning for this kanji is ´DICE´. --- Ever wonder what vultures do up in the trees? They play DICE. But of course, being vultures, they are always grabbing the dice away from each other.

column2:

column4: The imperial seal is usually an impressive mark made with a jewel. However when the letter arrives it has been raining on it and you see that the drops of rain have been transformed into little x’s where some animal legs have run over it.
column5: Primitives (to give correct stroke order): tool bench, towel, 4 Xs, jewel. Story: the Imperial Seal is like a kind of coat-of-arms the Emperor can stamp on stuff. Picture that coat-of-arms as depicting a big jewel (say, a diamond) with a motto on a banner above it saying 'let it be (#2074)'. (The emperor must have been a huge Beatles fan).

column2:
爪: claw; nail; talon
网: net; net or net crown radical (no. 122)
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
寸: measurement; foot/10
column4: The baron is very suspicious, always looking around with vulture eyes and keeping the silver glued to the table so no one can steal it.
column5: Here we see an evil baron - a vulture perched on his shoulder, and a siver eye-patch glued to his eye.

column2:
尊: revered; valuable; precious; noble; exalted
辶: walk; walking; road radical variant (no. 162)
column4: You must abide by the revered rules of the road! No devil´s brew and stay glued to your lane in the road!
column5: Even the most revered person must still abide by the rules of the road -- no exceptions are granted to anyone.

column2:
朔: conjunction (astronomy); first day of month
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
column4: This guy is such a gifted sculptor. He can model a MOUNTAIN GOAT and a MOON with just SOIL mold.
column5: A legend says that if you model a mountain goat (with tail and everything) from dirt and leave to the light of the moon on the first day of the month (#2846), the dirt will became flesh. (blackstockc).

column2:
水: water
太: plump; thick; big around
column4: I couldn´t find any reference to this kanji as meaning cleanse. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰（さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to ´select´ so maybe Heisig meant cleanse in the ethnic sense here.. I´m going to use the keyword "selection", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out.
column5: Water is used to cleanse a plump man´s colon.

column2:
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
一: one; one radical (no.1)
column4: A nightbreak happens when the sun rises over the horizon (floor).
column5: It may be easier to think of the keyword "DAYBREAK" or "MORNING" for this kanji (other kanji dictionaries do). Then the mnemonic phrase "SUN rising over the HORIZON" works better. It is an infrequent kanji, but can be found in: 旦夕　（たんせき） morning and evening, or 元旦　（がんたん） New Year´s Day.

column2:
肉: meat
天: heavens; sky; imperial
column4: The queen is not happy. "We (majestic plural) are not amused that the hunger for the flesh of the wooly mammoth has caused it's extinction. Poor Charles is particularly upset.
column5: The king says "Only We are allowed to partake of the flesh of the golden calf.".

column2:
疒: trailing sickness; sick radical (no. 104)
豆: beans; pea; midget
column4: Caveman has horrible pox. They look like edamame beans oozing bight green paste.
column5: Pox is a sickness which symptoms include bean-shaped bumps on the skin.

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
弋: piling; ceremony radical (no. 56)
二: two; two radical (no.2)
column4: II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).
column5: Once you have two old arrows left in your quiver, you better start running...!

column2:
貝: shellfish
武: warrior; military; chivalry; arms
column4: A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.
column5: Drove my Chevy to the levy but the levy was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you´ll die. Pay up the clams or you´ll die....

column2:
一: one; one radical (no.1)
内: inside; within; between; among; house; home
column4: In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it´s almost pictographic here!).
column5: But third class is so small Mr. T´s head hits the celing.

column2:
耒: come; plough; 3-branch tree radical (no. 127)
毛: fur; hair; feather; down
column4: The amount of "fur" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn´t look all that good.
column5: Real fur coats and real christmas trees are dereasing the last couple of years. Plasctic chrismas trees and fake fur it is nowadays.

column2:
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)
台: pedestal; a stand; counter for machines and vehicles
column4: The secrets of metallurgy and smithing: get your redhot metal and bang it against the pedestal as an anvil. Then cool it quickly with lots of ice.
column5: An ICE PEDESTAL is useless in METALLURGY since it will just melt.

column2:
水: water
監: oversee; official; govt office; rule; administer
column4: Who´s job is it to oversee the water level on the dam? It´ts overflowing!
column5: The overseer isn´t doing his job and he lets the slaves overflow the sink!

column2:
丈: length; 10feet; measure; Mr.; Ms.; height; stature; all (one has); only; that's all; merely

column4: One officer can change the course of history.
column5: One officer, namely Napoleon, changed the course of history. (Thanks, ayoung24). Napoleon is also my primitive meaning.

column2:
玉: jewel; ball
亠: kettle lid radical (no. 8)
凶: villain; evil; bad luck; disaster
禸: rump; footprint radical (no. 114)
column4: Michael Jackson is the king of pop, wearing his crystal rhinestone glove (see detach (#1492).
column5: In my story for detatch detach (#1492), the left side primitive was junkie. The top-hatted villian of society with a belt around their elbow. Here, the junkie is getting a fix of crystal meth: the jewel in the crown of today´s drugs.

column2:
目: eye; class; look; insight; experience; care; favor
大: large; big
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
小: little; small
column4: Open your eyes, it's obvious that not all of us can fit into that small puptent!
column5: It´s obvious that the pup tent with a huge eye on the side belongs to the dark lord Sauron.

column2:
十: ten
早: early; fast
韋: tanned leather radical (no. 178)
column4: There´s a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama´s picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called "Winter Sonata".
column5: This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.

column2:
冂: upside-down box radical (no. 13)
山: mountain
column4: White mount , Fuji mount , olympus mount whatever ....The choice is yours but wherever you go they sell those snowglobe souvenir : under a GLASS HOOD you can see the mount with a MOUTAIN GOAT standing on top of it .... So kitsch you just can´t forget it .
column5: This has the same meaning as 丘, so my "Mount" is a hill with mountain goats on it under a glass canopy. It´s obviously an effort by the locals to add some Mount atmosphere to their hill. As a primitive, it has the meaning "sturdy" (really), which Heisig has not used for some reason, but I will. The glass canopy must be pretty sturdy to keep the goats inside (bulletproof glass, I´m sure).

column2:
阜: hill; mound; left village radical (no. 170)
反: anti-
column4: If you´re scared of Heights, you don´t want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with "mountain".
column5: People are being displaced in 大阪 to make room for a new development, Osaka Heights, the pinnacle of modern Japanese housing. An angry mob of protestors are outside with Anti-Osaka Heights signs.

column2:
犬: dog
且: moreover; also; furthermore
column4: When her home was invaded by a pack of dogs, the little girl climbed on the shelf and aimed various items at the dogs below.
column5: I think the dogs purposely aim at your shelves to deal the most damage.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
奇: strange; strangeness; curiosity
column4: This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.
column5: Cape Cod "odd" is a land where odd=strange things happen.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
次: next; order; sequence
column4: To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them.
column5: The briar patch may look unremarkable now before it blooms, but there will be flowers next, and it will be beautiful.

column2:
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
田: rice field; rice paddy
日: day; sun; Japan; counter for days
column4: The Artist formerly Known as Prince has the horniest brain around, and I think you can imagine what his wagging tongue is doing...
column5: Formerly, horned animals were used to plough the ricefield, and it took all day. Nowadays it´s done by machine.

column2:
木: tree; wood
厂: wild goose; trailing cliff radical (no. 27)
万: ten thousand; 10,000
column4: There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people´s heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain´t did shit about it.
column5: There is a horse chestnut tree that has grown by a cliff for so long, it has deposited 10,000 horse chesnuts that lie at the bottom. Don´t worry over this one too much, you´ll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won´t forget it.

column2:
𠂤: None
十: ten
column4: The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn.
column5: Note to those who have not got this far in the book: This is the full kanji for the Pinnacle primitive (i.e. only the left-hand version of the primitive). The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is city walls (#2180). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer´s afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県　ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
曷: why; how; when
匂: fragrant; stink; glow; insinuate; (kokuji)
column4: Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave.
column5: The muchacho takes a siesta under the flowers of the kudzu.

column2: 戌: sign of the dog; 7-9PM; eleventh sign of Chinese zodiac
column4: People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs.
column5: How many brains does it take to run the capital suburbs?

column2:
尸: corpse; remains; flag radical (no. 44)
九: nine
column4: The baseball team stick flags in their buttocks and wave them at the opposing team to put them off.
column5: I wonder if this story will be flagged for saying i give her buttocks a score of 9.

column2:
木: tree; wood
市: market; city; town
column4: Nobody buys persimmons at the market, because there´s a tree in the middle where you can pick them for free.
column5: The guy at the market says: I´ll give you one persimmon tree per every Simon you bring me!

column2:
臣: retainer; subject
又: or again; furthermore; on the other hand
肉: meat
column4: When the sex slave misbehaves, threaten to sell his body parts starting with his kidney.
column5: If you have a weak KIDNEY, you´ll become a SLAVE to your CROTCH´s need to pee. Oh well, it´s just a weakness of the FLESH.

column2:
父: father

column5: Whilst on holiday, my father was captured by cannibals and put in a metal cauldron.

力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
力: power; strength; strong; strain; bear up; exert
column4: What part of the body has a very, very, very powerful smell? The armpit, of course!
column5: (no important on yomi) The part of Conan´s body that is three times more effective at defeating foes than his muscles are his stinky ARMPITs. [Note: Typically, when the flesh primitive is on the left side it refers to a body part - this helps distinguish in from threaten (#871)].

column2:
金: gold
咼: crooked mouth; evil; dishonest
column4: A gruesome kind of cauldron that Snape might have used is a metal pot in the shape of a skull.
column5: A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.

column2: 丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: Horror scene: Hanging from the ceiling, a plough and fishhook dripping with blood down onto the tiled bathroom floor.
column5: [true stroke order] First draw T for Tile, which then becomes I. Then draw an ´L´ fish hook with a dash in the middle to make a mediocre ´e´ that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa).

column2:
手: hand
坐: sit
column4: I sprained my fingers when I sat in meditation (by sitting in a strange position).
column5: I sprained in my finger doing a complicated mudra while sitting in meditation.

column2:
言: say
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: Do you remember that song where they say "Who let the turkeys out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?
column5: [who; someone; somebody] You´re alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone speaking. "Who´s there?", you say, but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a turkey gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir).

column2:
人: person
奄: cover; suffocate; obstruct
column4: I did it all by myself! Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He´s brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy.
column5: As astridtops mentions, this is "Ore". In Japanese r = l, so could write it "Ole". So picture a bullfight with person as the matador and a dachshund replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting "Ole! (Ore)".

column2:
疒: trailing sickness; sick radical (no. 104)
艮: northeast (Oriental zodiac); stopping; good radical (no. 138)
column4: I suffer from silver-sickness, that is, if anything made of silver even touches my skin it leaves a scar.
column5: I got sick and needed surgery, but the silver lining is that now I have these awesome scars I can show off!

column2:
衣: garment; clothes; dressing
由: wherefore; a reason
column4: Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves.
column5: The bad magician says, "As you can see, there´s nothing up my sleeves!" Then he trips over his cloak and brussel sprouts fall everywhere.

column2:
女: woman; female
夭: early death; calamity
column4: If you don´t want to get bewitched (and who would?), then avoid any woman you see carrying what might appear to be a sapling. It´s really a wand in disguise, and if you´re not aware you might get bewitched.
column5: I was bewitched by the woman fairy (like an angel, but not as tall).

column2:
門: gate; counter for cannons
音: sound; noise
column4: I like to think of a horror movie where the protagonists enter a graveyard when suddenly their flashlights go out and it becomes pitch dark, whereupon they hear the sound of the gate creaking shut behind them.
column5: Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all pitch dark.

column2:
手: hand
足: leg; foot; be sufficient; counter for pairs of footwear
column4: I felt a finger on my leg as someone tried to nab my wallet.
column5: Fingers nabs Davy Jone´s wooden leg: Argh! Bring me back me leg, ya scurvy dog!

column2:
貝: shellfish
者: someone; person
column4: When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll.
column5: People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.

column2:
水: water
凡: mediocre
column4: Yeah, all our water is fairly mediocre, but if we work together in some pan-continental union, we can make some better water! As if.
column5: This is pan- as in the prefix meaning "all". I think of Pangea as being a mediocre continent with water covering the rest of the planet. This was before it broke up into the first-class, well-distributed continents we got now.

column2:
匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
頁: page; leaf
column4: An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head.
column5: After spooning for hours it´s about that time he got some head. Dayum woman.

column2:
言: say
迷: astray; be perplexed; in doubt; lost; err; illusion
column4: Words meant to lead you astray are those of a riddle.
column5: I led Socrates astray with my riddle. He quit philosophizing and thought only about the riddle.

column2: 丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)
column4: A pictograph of Wolverine´s adamantium claws.
column5: Pictograph, see book. * I prefer the primitive meaning of an eagle rather than vulture. Somehow vulture makes me think more about meat and dead corpses than claws. An eagle however immediately brings to my mind the image of an eagle plunging into a stream catching fish in his claws, or that of the great eagles rescuing Bilbo and his party in Jrr Tolkien´s novel “Bilbo the Hobbit”.

column2:
金: gold
建: build
column4: The metal thing you need in order to enter things you build is a key.
column5: 鍵盤key (#2761) ケン, かぎ ... Parts: 金, 建 ... Story: The most important Metal in any building is the lock on the front door, and without a key you ain´t getting in. This kanji means both lock and key to most Japanese people. 錠前 is technically the word for lock but it´s not used in daily conversation. ... 熟語: ... cf: 錠前.

column2: 臼: mortar, mortar radical (no. 134)
column4: I removed all the back to back staples and grinded them in a mortar to create metal dust.
column5: The mortar bomb exploded, ripping the sun in half.

column2:

丿: katakana no radical (no. 4)

column5: He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.

column2:
木: tree; wood
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
八: eight; eight radical (no. 12)
column4: The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. "If I´m gonna be sleeping with the fishes," he said, "can I at least have a pillow? I´m real sensitive." The mafia bosses laughed. "Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow.
column5: WOODEN PILLOWS do not sink (#1888) in water.

column2:
井: well; well crib; town; community
丶: dot; tick or dot radical (no. 3)
column4: A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!
column5: I drop a domburi down into the well for the goblin living there.

column2:

具: tool; utensil; means; possess; ingredients; counter for armor, suits, sets of furniture
column4: My mind found the tool disquieting.
column5: Its disquieting to my state of mind when tools are arranged messily.

column2:

善: virtuous; good; goodness
column4: Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh.
column5: The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it.

column2:
口: mouth
兄: elder brother; big brother
column4: Caution: this means a spell, not to swear. I put a curse on my elder brother so that he can never open his mouth.
column5: Your older brother´s mouth often curses.

column2:
車: car
斤: axe; 1.32 lb; catty; counter for loaves of bread; axe radical (no. 69)
column4: A "chop shop" is a place where stolen cars are taken, and parts chopped off with an axe, to be sold.
column5: I wanted a convertible so I chopped off the top of my car with an axe.

column2:
夕: evening
卩: seal radical (no. 26)
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: I couldn´t drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig´s heart in his mailbox. He got the message.
column5: To hold a grudge is actually the act of keeping negative feelings you received in the mailbox of your heart.

column2:
口: mouth
中: in; inside; middle; mean; center
column4: Naka naka , "who´s there?" shish kebab .... "shish kebab who?".
column5: This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.

column2:
肉: meat
重: heavy; heap up; pile up; nest of boxes; -fold
column4: A tumor is a useless body part that is nothing but heavy.
column5: When flesh clumps together and gets heavy, it forms a tumor.

column2:

并: put together
column4: Call your friend and he answers the phone "Mochi, mochi!" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come.
column5: Mochi ice cream is a puzzling food, I still have no idea how they get that ice cream in there, but it sure tastes good.

column2:
竹: bamboo
者: someone; person
column4: Bamboo, lovedoll: At dinner, my lovedoll decided to eat her meal the Japanese way using chopsticks. But well, what a problems she had getting those bamboo shoots into her mouth (which should not be that difficult, I would say!).
column5: I´ve always wanted to use bamboo chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this love doll will have to do.

column2:

文: sentence; literature; style; art; decoration; figures; plan; literary radical (no. 67)
玉: jewel; ball
column4: Speckled is a pattern, like plaid, but with lots of little balls all over the place.
column5: The sentences exchanged between the two kings got more and more heated, finally leading to a fight which left the whole area speckled with blood.

column2:
執: tenacious; take hold; grasp; take to heart

column4: When you clasp something you tenaciously 執 hold on to it with your hand 手, te. 真摯、しんし, sincerity, earnestness.
column5: This kanji shows Santa Claus (refer to frame tenacious (#1506)) clasping the reins of his deers with his hands, holding onto dear life as he almost falls off his carriage.

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey
隹: bird; old bird radical (no. 172)
column4: After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we piled high all the turkey corpses atop the soil of the farmyard.
column5: During the Turkey Holocaust (this is what the animal kingdom calls Thanksgiving - they have really short memories and thus don´t recall that it actually happens every single year), turkeys are killed en masse, and their bodies are piled high. To keep them from tumbling down, a pile of dirt is piled high right next to them to keep them standing upright so that they will be fresh when it is time to eat them.

column2:
艸: grass; plants; grass radical (no. 140)
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: My favorite are heart shaped candles that smell like sweet flowers. The trick is to find one with a thick wick, they give off the most flower scent (but burn the quickest).
column5: Giving a girl flowers is like lighting the wick to her heart.

column2:
宀: shaped crown; katakana u radical (no. 40)
必: invariably; certain; inevitable
虫: insect; bug; temper
column4: When I think of honey, I think of a bee hive, which is a HOUSE that INVARIABLY has INSECTS.
column5: A house with a lot of honey will invariably attract many insects.

column2:
肉: meat
殳: pike; windy-again radical (no. 79)
column4: Where´s my flesh missile? Between my thighs, naturally...
column5: My thigh is the part of the body that my missile smacks against.

column2:
勹: wrapping enclosure; wrapping radical (no. 20)
匕: spoon; spoon or katakana hi radical (no. 21)
column4: The muchacho sits down bound up to enjoy his own aroma.
column5: If you bind up a person and let him sit for several days, an unpleasant aroma will result.

column2:

column4: The ball was the only thing that people at the beginning of time had to use as a toy. Poor cavemen.
column5: And so it was, the ball marked the beginning of all the toys that were to come.

column2:

丨: number one; line; rod radical (no. 2)
column4: A bee is an insect with a pointy (see summit (#1562)) stinger.
column5: The insect that interrupted our tryst (#2417) was a bee!

column2:

奇: strange; strangeness; curiosity

column5: A strange kind of tree grows in the shape of a chair.

column2:

七: seven
column4: A kid gets scolded if they don´t put the spoon properly into their mouth when eating.
column5: If I got scolded, I could expect a spoon of castor oil in my mouth.

矣: sentence particle

column5: Your fingers slip when someone´s elbow shoves you, causing you to drop the dart you were about to throw. But as you can see, their elbow is very small, so you decide they´re too weak to shove back.

column2:

耳: ear
column4: Food made of ears is animal feed.
column5: Do you know Mike Tayson favorite feed? Ears! He eats ears!

column2:

column5: A pictograph of a spinal column. The umbrella representing the shoulder blades, the I Ching as the shoulder muscles and the part of the body as the spine itself.

column2:
冫: two-stroke water radical or ice radical (no. 15)

column4: His wife has a nifty way of making all types of ice cream in her home freezer.
column5: Sugoi! Sugoi! Ice Wife Sugoi!

column2:
女: woman; female
疾: rapidly
column4: If you go through women rapidly you will be the object of envy.
column5: Ah, puberty ... the girl that starts her journey towards womanhood the most rapidly will become the subject of envy from all her classmates.

column2:
肉: meat
木: tree; wood
水: water
column4: Before lacquer (#932) was made with water, it was made by draining this body part of fluid: the knee!
column5: Back in ancient Japan, people didn´t have knee pads for things like rollerblading and such (what, come on. Ninjas on rollerblades. Ultimate 90s flashback). Instead, they would simply dip their knees in laquer, and wait until it dried (hence the flesh, and the abscence of any drops of water). Unfortunately, this meant that you would have to wait about 30 minutes after deciding to go rollerblade until you could actually do it (took some time to dry) - and removing it was a serious pain.

column2:
次: next; order; sequence
心: heart; mind; spirit; heart radical (no. 61)
column4: A selfish person doesn't care about the next person's heart, only their own.
column5: Selfish lover breaks your heart and moves on to the next lover. (And yawns with a heart of ice at your suffering).

column2:
麥: wheat
面: mask; face; features; surface
column4: #NAME?

column4: "This is the kanji for the classical form of ""is"". I think Heisig's keyword ""est"" is the old english or latin word for ""is"". The Scorpion this est!"
column5: """Est"" is the latin third person singular of the verb ""esse"" (to be) in Latin. So, this word has been chosen to point out that this character is found chiefly in Classical Japanese (also names). I imagine an incredibly haughty Latin Scorpion, looking down at his vast estate and saying ""Mihi est"". This literally mean ""It is to me"" and means ""It's mine"" ... this is gramatically similar to how Japanese express possession too, incidentally."

The kanji here refers to ivy, or vine, and is used in a particular compound for "Hedera rhombea", which is a type of ivy native to Japan. This vine here produces a lot of flowers, and attracts many small birds, which is sure to cheer up even the most depressed Japanese gardener.

column2:

column4: "[+brose] The cormorant was historically used in Japan and China to catch fish. The fisher would use some rope or something to tie its throat so that it could only swallow small fish. If it caught something too big to swallow, it would take it back to the fisher's boat and the fisher would take it out. This particular cormorant is going after bigger and bigger prey - but one day it goes too far, and tries to swallow your little brother! Imagine trying to yank your brother out of its throat."
column5: The cormorant is a bird you use like your younger brother to fetch things for you.

column2:

column4: "An ancient Japanese dragon, beautiful and terrifying. Here it is depicted standing on a piece of meat (its prey) and a description is written on the right margin. It is said to be like a snake that has three toes on its feet and can sometimes use its head as a flamethrower (kind of like a sling, but with fire instead of stones). (Note: The Japanese dragon has three toes, unlike other Asian dragons. Asian dragons generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a dragon!)."
column5: "(insp by raulir) The ancient Japanese Dragon, now extinct, is depicted in a book of lore STANDING on a pile of freshly slaughtered MEAT. The column describes how the last Japanese Dragon was killed by a party of adventurers, who struck its SNAKE body simultaneously with a SLINGSHOT and THREE swords."

column4: Malt made from barley is often bound up with rice for brewing.
column5: "This means kouji mould, so I think malt is a poor keyword. Sake, shochu and other East Asian spirits use this mould in place of yeast, which is used to make most other alcoholic spirits in the world. Mould and yeast are two different types of fungus. Yeast might have been a better keyword, as it is the organism doing the fermenting. Story: Kouji mould is grown on rice specially bound up to form a starter culture. To make mugishochu, the starter culture is added to a barley mash."

column2:

column2:

column5: "A person should try to make his own luck, but sometimes you have to make do with happenstance."

column2:

column2:

column2:

column5: "Plants wilt, wither and die when ice envelopes the circumference of their roots."

column2:

column5: "In front (drops), dagger: The gardener is pruning his roses. He closes up to the one in front of him until he can see the dewdrops on the petals. Then he gets out his dagger and prunes."

column4: To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.
column5: Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both ´spoon´ and ´seven´, the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in ´seven´ it is a strong line from left to right.

column2:

column5: A spoon used to measure ingredients just so is a measuring spoon.

column2:

column5: This pup is immense! It's head is almost level with the edge of this tall cliff. Who ever heard of a chihuahua with a human leg with a shape so immense?

column2:

column5: To glue your mouth shut it only takes an inch of it.

column2:

column2: 各: each; every; either

column5: A squirrel's mouth coughs up an acorn.

column2:

column2:

column2:

column5: "The hula girl got a cyst on her lips after she placed her mouth on my ""crown"" ten times."

column2:
口: mouth
聶: whisper

column5: "It's funny how if I just talk, no one listens, but if I whisper, many ears are eager to hear what's coming from my mouth."

column2:
土: soil; earth; ground; Turkey

column4: "While ""autochthonous"" can mean ""indigenous"" in ENGLISH, that is NOT one of the potential meanings of this character (thus, the majority of these stories will not help you with meaning). Rather, the kanji is ""autochthonous"" in the sense of being Earthly, mystic, and portentous (the ancient, primitive, sacred power of DIRT and SOIL). A vague, poorly-chosen keyword all around. Mantixen's story does the best job of conveying accurate meaning--> ""A monkey likes the earthy/autochthonous feel of soil""."
column5: A monkey likes the earthy feel of soil.

column2:

column5: The empress gets a soil mask at the spa to treat a blemish.

column2:

column5: Note: Right side 阜 is large hill (#2928).

column2:

column2:

Both are women; however, the wife gets a brush for her hair; whereas the concubine is stood upon and trampled."

column2:

This assembly line of death is giving all kinds of hints that something is wrong. ""Oh hey, green onions!"" Indy ducks down to grab them and the trap misses him completely... fiestas ensue..."

column2:

column2:

column5: "I bow with hands clasped, my fingers holding the microphone (with an opening that's like an ear for receiving sound) after giving my own interpretation of the karaoke song."

column2:

column2:

column2:

column2:

column5: The Sunshine looks Murky in Hades.

column2: 曰: say, say radical (no. 73)

column2:

column2:

column5: "The owl is a very snooty bird, one could say that it has a tree stuck up it's ass. キョウ."

column2:

column2:

You run up to him asking him all sorts of crazy questions, and he looks at you and smiles. ""Brah, man, just chill, man. Braaaaah#."" Apparently he's a surfer brahman. You ask him the meaning of life, and he smiles, and waits...waits...waits...until a bit of wind blows by. He lets out a small fart in the wind, and nods knowingly at you."
column5: "Brahman who are mediocre don't get the sweet meditation spots on the beach. Instead, they have to settle for a grove of trees."

column5: "You are sitting in a nice easy chair and all of a sudden there's a loud fart sound. Everyone looks at you, but you shrug your shoulders. They go back to what they're doing...""pyuuuun!"" They look back at you. ""It's not me,"" you say, ""it's just this armrest rubbing against my flesh."" They seem satisfied, and go back to their work. Little do they know that you're making armpit farts (my primitive for the right side) and really putting all of your flesh into it!"

column2:

column5: The part of the body that golden rays of light seem to pour out from.

I've been using Ninja Turtles and stuff though, so I'll have to use this as a series of narrow, long, lead pipes that bring floods of water to the city. Here, someone has taken a lead sewer pipe and hit you in the part of your flesh that is most vulnerable to impact: your shin (after years of soccer/football, I can't think of the word shin without thinking of pain)."
column5: The body part that gets wet when you wade through the sewers (a crafted flood underneath the ground) is your shin (thanks brian44).

Note: this is indeed flea, not louse, which has its own character (虱). I'm not sure of the stroke order, but by the rule of drawing from top to bottom, the crotch drop should come first. The louse (虱) then is of course a drop-like insect that attaches itself to body hairs by little hooks."

""o ok"", she replies. Looks like your prevarication worked! You go home later, only to find her sitting there, waiting for you - maybe you shouldn't have brought the girl back home this time..."

Story: just like everything else in the East (writing, utensils, etc) bells are harder to work than necessary, being hit from the outside and all. The correct way is to put the gong on the inside, makes it so much easier."

Perhaps this is some sort of sabotage, done in a place that is not readily visible to the outside."

此: this; current; next; coming; last; past
column4: """Please stop and sit down to look to the painting up there"", the tour guide says. ""We don't know exactly who is on the painting, but from the shape of the hair and the distinctive beard, we think they meant to depict President Lincoln.""."
column5: "A beard is hair that, instead of wanting it SHAPED like your friends, you grow it LONG so that you can STOP, SIT DOWN and scratch it thoughtful while considering this here and that there."

column2:
魚: fish
付: adhere; attach; refer to; append
column4: "Due to its oxygenating properties, it is crucial that you adhere to a crucian fish if you plan on spending a long time underwater."
column5: The crucian fish adheres strongly to Crucianism principles.

column2:
魚: fish
旨: delicious; relish; show a liking for; purport; will; clever; expert
column4: Japanese consider fish to be most delicious when eaten as sushi.
column5: SUSHI is FISH that is DELICIOUS.

column2:
魚: fish
有: possess; have; exist; happen; occur; approx
column4: "Tuna is the fish that posesses the most toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, mercury)."
column5: Maguro tuna is a must-have (possess) fish.

column2:
魚: fish
青: blue; green
column4: Holy mackarel! That fish just turned blue!
column5: "Fish, blue: After the young girl found that disappointing mackerel fish (see story horse mackerel (#2818)), she felt a bit blue."

column2:
魚: fish
参: nonplussed; three; going; coming; visiting; visit; be defeated; die; be madly in love
column4: "Fish, visit: Mother to daughter: ""I bought you a hors..."". The girls started a joyous screaming. ""Let's visit it"", the girl says. Daughter follows mother to.. the kitchen, showing her the fish she bought. Mother: ""I wanted to tell you that I bought a horse mackerel for dinner!""."
column5: The horse mackerel is the fish that is nonplussed – it isn't sure whether it's a horse or a mackerel.

column2:
魚: fish
秋: autumn
column4: "Fish, autumn: Old man to his son: ""You are bullheaded if you think you can catch a bullhead fish in the middle of autumn. It's out of season!""."
column5: "Perhaps a bit of a misnomer. Bullhead is a river fish (カジカ). This kanji is most likely to refer to young Japanese yellowtail or amberjack. It is a fish of many names depending on age: fry (もじゃこ), young (鰍・いなだ or 魬・はまち), mature (鰤・ぶり). I suppose these kanji might crop up on a fish menu. STORY: Young Amberjack is not at its best in summer. Eat from autumn onwards (when it becomes more fatty). Also its tail is amber - the colour of autumn leaves."

column2:
魚: fish
咢: outspokenly
column4: """Dude! What happened to your chin?"" ""Well, I was out fishing...""."
column5: Saltwater crocs swim in the sea like fish. Right side = crocodile primative. Pictograph - 2 big eyes and one massive snare for a mouth.

column2:
魚: fish
耆: senility
column4: "Fish, old man, sun: An ominous fish fin approaches the old man, who went for a swim as the sun was going down. Soon, he'll sleep with the fishes."
column5: The old man thinks fish fin sushi is delicious.

column2:
魚: fish
堅: strict; hard; solid; tough; tight; reliable
column4: The bonito is a fish with strict preparation procedures for making 出汁（だし） and 鰹節（かつおぶし）.
column5: "Fish, strict: La Isla Bonito. Madonna is very strict on the type of fish imported to the island. Only the best is good enough..."

column2:
魚: fish
曼: wide; beautiful
column4: The only fish that Nelson Manadala got to eat in prison was うなぎ eel...sounds like punishment to me!
column5: Manga fish: picture a manga version of an eel and you're done.

column2:
魚: fish
雪: snow
column4: Cod is a fish that is packed in snow to reach the inland parts of Japan.
column5: "たら, cod is a beautiful fish whose flesh is the colour and texture of snow."

column2:
小: small, insignificant
冖: wa-shaped crown radical (no. 14)
鳥: bird; chicken
column4: The nightingale is a bird that goes to a schoolhouse at night to learn to sing.
column5: "This character is actually a 俗字 (unofficial simplification) of the character 鶯. As such, it is actually far less common than the traditional character according to a google search. Story for the correct character: The nightingale is bird with a crown (mane) as bright as a deep fire (two fires)."

column2:
武: warrior; military; chivalry; arms
鳥: bird; chicken
column4: "A parrot is a bird of the warrior, for example pirates."
column5: "A parrot makes a terrible bird for any warrior. As soon as the warrior tries to sneak up on its enemy, Polly wants a freaking cracker."

column2:
嬰: sharp (music); baby
鳥: bird; chicken
column4: The parakeet is a bird that acts like a suckling infant when it drinks from the water dropper.
column5: "Ariel, that little mermaid with the shells over her ""ha-ha"" 's is good friends with a parakeet voiced by Gilbert Godfried... or wait, is that some other Disney film?"

column2:
卜: divination
囗: box or enclosure radical (no. 31); box
column4: "The fortune-teller tells Wolverine that in a past life, she sees him covered in rocksalt from working in a salt mine."
column5: You see a block of rocksalt containing a pent-in ladybird (US = ladybug). Touch it with your magic wand and the ladybird is set free. (Note: Let ladybird = sheaf + four drops. It's pictographic: the sheaf showing the curved back and the four drops the spots on the ladybird).

column2:
鹵: salt
僉: all
column4: Lye is white like rocksalt and sharp like an awl.
column5: Lye is white like rocksalt and can be broken up with an ice pick.

column2:
禾: 2-branch tree radical (no. 115)
水: water
column4: "Millet is a small grain whose importance was greater in prehistoric times. Nowadays, it has been supplanted in the West by wheat, and in the East (""under the bamboo umbrella""), by rice."
column5: Millet is grown primarily in African countries where there is little rain. As opposed to wheat and rice grains which are grown in areas one would need an umbrella.

column2:
敝: be worn-out; be dilapidated; be defeated
黽: green frog; industry
column4: "The snapping turtle is ordering lunch at a restaurant, ""I'll have the shredded old eel -- and make it snappy!"". (Picture the waiter putting old eels through the shredder before serving them)."
column5: (Note: Bottom 黽 means Green frog /industry. Check your Japanese dictionary.) Story - The Snapping turtle eats through green frogs like a shredder eats through paper.

column2: 臼: mortar
column4: "You are chasing the famous three blind mice and try to catch them by slamming a mortar on top of them. Success! You can see their three tails sticking out from under the mortar. In fact the impact has broken the first two tails, as you can see from the sharp angle they bend at, and the two drops (blood) on each. The third tail still curves nicely though, and hence has no drops of blood on it."
column5: "A pictograph of an elaborate mouse-catching device. A hook on the front to grab them, a couple of alternating ploughs to slice them (spattered with drops of blood) and a mortar on top for the big jobs."

column2:
鼻: nose; snout
干: dry; parch
column4: "If you snore, your nose becomes dry. I try to remember the slightly different bottom part by wanting to hit the snoring nose with two hands but can't quite reach. KUN yomi reading いびき."
column5: Stay dry (from alcohol) and wear a nose plug if you tend to snore.
